Entry of your power of attorney on the CAF system enables IRS personnel, who do not have a copy of your power of attorney, to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the CAF. It also enables the IRS to automatically send copies of notices and other IRS communications to your representative if you specify that your representative should receive those communications. You can have your non-IRS power of attorney entered on the CAF system by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and submitting it to the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, your attorney-in-fact must sign the Declaration of Representative(see Part II of Form 2848).

The IRS will accept a copy of a power of attorney that is submitted by facsimile transmission (fax). If you choose to file a power of attorney by fax, be sure the appropriate IRS office is equipped to accept this type of transmission. !This is an Image: taxtip.gif Your representative may be able to file Form 2848 electronically via the IRS website. For more information, your representative can go to IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative, who will retain the document.

Submit any update or modification to an existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the individual(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by sending the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously sent the original(s), including the service center where the related return was, or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or delegate representation in the original power of attorney. To make a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written declaration of representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the substitution or delegation.

A newly filed power of attorney concerning the same matter will revoke a previously filed power of attorney. However, the new power of attorney will not revoke the prior power of attorney if it specifically states it does not revoke such prior power of attorney and either of the following are attached to the new power of attorney. A copy of the unrevoked prior power of attorney, or A statement signed by the taxpayer listing the name and address of each representative authorized under the prior unrevoked power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to name a new representative, you must write “REVOKE” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below this annotation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to the IRS, using the Where To File Chart in the Instructions for Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office handling the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you want to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is revoked, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name and address of each recognized representative whose authority is revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you are completely revoking authority, write "remove all years/periods" instead of listing the specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw from representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below the annotation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the withdrawal annotation to the IRS in the same manner described in Revocation by taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney he or she wants to withdraw, he or she must send the IRS a statement of withdrawal that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is withdrawn, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name, TIN, and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. A power of attorney held by a student will be recorded on the CAF system for 130 days from the receipt date. If you are authorizing a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

!This is an Image: caution.gif For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which repealed the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and the rules applicable to electing large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, has eliminated the role of “tax matters partner” and replaced it with “partnership representative.” Pursuant to Treasury Regulation section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships can elect to have the new regime apply to partnership returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015, and before January 1, 2018.

A power of attorney will be recognized after it is received, reviewed, and determined by the IRS to contain the required information. However, until a power of attorney is entered on the CAF system, IRS personnel may be unaware of the authority of the person you have named to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, IRS personnel may request that you or your representative bring a copy to any meeting with the IRS.
How the power of attorney is processed and handled depends on whether it is a complete or incomplete document.

If Form 2848 is incomplete, the IRS will attempt to secure the missing information either by writing or telephoning you or your representative. For example, if your signature or signature date is missing, the IRS will contact you. If information concerning your representative is missing and information sufficient to make a contact (such as an address and/or a telephone number) is on the document, the IRS will try to contact your representative. In either case, the power of attorney is not considered valid until all required information is entered on the document. The individual(s) named as representative(s) will not be recognized to practice before the IRS, on your behalf, until the document is complete and accepted by the IRS.

If the power of attorney is complete and valid, the IRS will take action to recognize the representative. In most instances, this includes processing the document on the CAF system. Recording the data on the CAF system enables the IRS to direct copies of mailings to authorized representatives and to readily recognize the scope of authority granted.

Specific-use powers of attorney are not processed on the CAF system (see Preparation of Form — Helpful Hints , earlier). For example, a power of attorney that is a one-time or specific-issue grant of authority is not processed on the CAF system. These documents remain with the related case files. In this situation, you should check the box on line 4 of Form 2848. In these situations, the representative should bring a copy of the power of attorney to each meeting with the IRS.

After a valid power of attorney is filed, the IRS will recognize your representative. However, if it appears the representative is responsible for unreasonably delaying or hindering the prompt disposition of an IRS matter by failing to furnish, after repeated requests, nonprivileged information, the IRS can contact you directly. For example, in most instances in which a power of attorney is recognized, the IRS will contact the representative to set up appointments and to provide the representative with lists of required items. However, if the representative is unavailable, does not respond to repeated requests, and does not provide required items (other than items considered privileged), the IRS can bypass your representative and contact you directly. If a representative engages in conduct described above, the matter can be referred to the Office of Professional Responsibility for consideration of possible disciplinary action.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are safe and secure. We can help you resolve problems that you can’t resolve with the IRS. And our service is free. TAS works to resolve large-scale problems that affect many taxpayers. If you know of one of these broad issues, please report it to us at IRS.gov/SAMS.

Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs) are independent from the IRS. LITCs represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection disputes. This publication discusses the general rules for filing federal income tax returns. This material supplements the information in the instructions for your tax return. It explains the tax law to make sure you file only the amount of tax you owe, no more.

This publication will help you determine which tax filing status you qualify for, who you can claim as a dependent, and whether the income you receive is taxable. It also explains the standard deduction, the types of expenses you can deduct, and the types of credits you may claim to reduce your tax. Throughout the publication, examples are given to show how the tax law applies in typical situations. Throughout the publication, flowcharts and tables are also provided to present tax information in a clear and easy-to-understand way. Many of the topics discussed in this publication are discussed in more detail in other IRS publications. References to those other publications are also provided so you can learn more.

The four chapters in this section provide basic information about the tax system. These chapters guide you through the first steps to file a tax return. This section also provides information about dependents and discusses the recordkeeping requirements, IRS electronic filing (e-file) requirements, certain penalties, and two methods of paying taxes for the year: estimated tax and estimated tax payments. The schedules listed on Form 1040 and 1040-SR are explained in these chapters: Schedule 1, Additional Income and Adjustments to Income; and Schedule 3, Part II, Other Payments and Refunds of Taxes.

The five chapters in this section discuss various types of income and adjustments to income. These chapters explain which income is taxable and which is not, as well as discuss some adjustments to income that you may make to calculate your adjusted gross income. The schedules listed on Form 1040 and 1040-SR are discussed in these chapters: Schedule 1, Additional Income and Adjustments for Income; Schedule 2, Part II, Other Taxes; and Schedule 3, Part II, Other Payments and Refunds of Taxes.

After you've calculated your adjusted gross income, you're ready to subtract your deductions used to calculate your taxable income. You can subtract the standard deduction or itemized deductions, and both business income deductions if you're eligible. Itemized deductions are deductions for certain expenses listed on Schedule A (Form 1040). Three chapters in this section discuss the standard deduction and some itemized deductions. See Chapter 10 to consider the factors to decide whether to take the standard deduction or itemized deductions. The schedules listed on Form 1040 and 1040-SR are explained in these chapters: Schedule 1, Additional income and adjustments to gross income; Schedule 2, Part II, Other taxes; and Schedule 3, Part I, Nonrefundable credits.

Two chapters in this section explain how your taxes are calculated. These chapters also explain about tax credits, unlike deductions, that are subtracted directly from your taxes and reduce your taxes dollar for dollar. The tables listed on Form 1040 and 1040-SR are explained in these chapters: Table 1, Additional Income and Adjustments for Income; Table 2, Additional Taxes; and Table 3, Credits and Additional Payments.
This section explains your rights as a taxpayer and the processes for audits, appeals, tax collection and tax refunds.

Taxpayers have the right to object and submit additional documents to respond to an IRS formal action or a proposed action, the IRS will timely review their objection, promptly and fairly consider their documents, and receive a response if the IRS does not agree with their argument.

Taxpayers have the right to fair administrative review of most IRS decisions, including penalties, and to receive written responses to their appeals from the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Taxpayers generally have the right to sue over their appeals.

Taxpayers have the right to demand any question, examination, or action by the IRS to be in accordance with the law and not more than necessary, and will respect all due process rights, including search and be free from seizure, and be given a full hearing on the levy.

Taxpayers have the right to use an authorized representative of their choice to represent them in dealings with the IRS. Taxpayers are entitled to assistance from the Taxpayer Assistance Center if they do not have enough money to pay for a representative.

We accept most tax returns as filed. If we query your return or select it for review, that does not imply that you are not honest. The query or review may result in you owing more tax or less. We can close your case without change; or you may be entitled to a refund. The process of selecting a return for review usually begins within one or two days. First, we use computer programs to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs can base on tax return data, such as Form 1099 and W-2, base on prior review experience or base on certain issues identified by compliance projects. Second, we use information from outside sources that indicate a return may have incorrect amounts. These sources can include the media, public records, and individuals. If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, we can base on that to select a return for review. Publication 556, Examination of Returns, Rights of Appeal, and Claims for Refunds, explains the rules and procedures we follow in conducting examinations. The following provides an overview of how we perform reviews.

If you do not agree with the changes proposed by the IRS examiner, you can appeal to the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Most differences of opinion can be resolved without costly and time-consuming hearings. Your right to appeal is explained in both Publication 5, Your Appeal Rights and How to Prepare an Appeal if You Disagree, and Publication 556. If you do not want to use the IRS Independent Office of Appeals or do not agree with their conclusion, you can take your case to the United States Tax Court, the United States District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims where you live. If you take your case to court, the IRS will have the burden of proving certain facts if you keep sufficient records to show that you owe the tax, that you have cooperated with the IRS, and that you meet certain other requirements. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that our position is unreasonable, you may be able to recover some of your administrative and litigation costs. You will not be eligible to recover these costs if you did not try to resolve your case administratively, including through the appeals process, and you did not provide us with the necessary information to resolve your case.
Your right to appeal the assessment is explained in Publication 1660, Your Right to Appeal the Assessment.

Generally, the IRS will work directly with you or your authorized legal representative. However, sometimes we will communicate with others if we need information that you cannot provide, or to verify information that we have received. If we communicate with others, such as a neighbor, bank, employer, or employee, we usually have to tell them some limited information, such as your name. The law prohibits us from disclosing any information beyond what is necessary to obtain or verify the information we are seeking. We may still need to continue to communicate with others as long as it is necessary to carry out the activity in your case. If we communicate with others, you have the right to request a list of those contacted. You may request this by telephone, in writing, or in a private conversation.

After you've calculated your business income and business expenses, you're ready to calculate your net profit or loss from your business. You do this by subtracting your business expenses from your business income. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is your net profit and becomes part of your income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). If your expenses are more than your income, the difference is a net loss. You can usually deduct this loss from your total income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). However, in some situations, your loss is limited. This chapter briefly explains three of those situations. Other situations that may limit your loss are explained in the instructions for Schedule C, line G and line 32. If you have more than one business, you must calculate your net profit or loss for each business separately on its own Schedule C.

Your business or trade losses may be limited. Use Form 461 to determine the amount of business loss that exceeds, if any. Your business loss excess will be included in your income on line 8p of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and will be treated as a NOL that you must carry forward and deduct in the next tax year. For more information about business loss excess limitations, see the instructions for Form 461.

If you don't continue to operate your business to make a profit, there will be a limit on the deductions you can take. You can't use losses from this activity to offset other income. Activities you carry on as a hobby, or mainly for recreation, are subject to this limit. To find out more about non-business activities, see Hobby or business: what you need to know about side jobs.
If you are self-employed as a sole proprietor or independent contractor, you usually use Schedule C (Form 1040) to figure your net self-employment income.
Self-employment tax rate for 2024 net income is 15.3% (12.4% social security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

If any income from a business or trade, other than from a partnership, is income from a community property under the laws of the state, then that income is included in your spouse's or your own self-employment tax income from the business or trade.

Do not include in taxable income SE the interest or loss from the liquidation of non-inventory assets held for sale or not held primarily for sale to customers. This is not subject to whether the liquidation is voluntary or involuntary.

If you are self-employed and reduce or cease your business activities, any payments received from insurance or other sources for business income are included in your SE tax income. If you are not working at the time you receive a payment, the payment is still related to your business and is included in your SE tax income, even though the business is temporarily not being conducted.

If you work for a church or a church-controlled organization that is eligible for Social Security and Medicare tax exemption (not a minister, member of a religious order, or practitioner of Christian Science) and you receive $108.28 or more in wages from the church or organization, you must pay self-employment tax. For more information, see Publication 517, Social Security and Other Information for Ministers and Religious Workers.

If you are a member of the crew on a fishing vessel or other type of fishing vessel, your income is subject to SE tax if all of the following conditions are met. 1. You do not receive any payment for work other than your share of the catch or a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the catch, except where the payment meets all of the following conditions. 1. The payment does not exceed $100 per trip. 2. The payment is only received if there is a minimum catch. 3. The payment is only for additional duties (such as assistant, engineer or cook) for which cash payment is customary in the fishing industry. 2. You receive a share of the catch or a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the quantity of the catch. 4. The number of crew members on the fishing vessel is typically less than 10. (A crew is considered to be typically less than 10 if the average number of crew during the four most recent quarters of fishing trips is less than 10.)

You must be subject to SE tax if both of the following conditions are true. 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, U.S. Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, or the U.S. Virgin Islands by: 1. A foreign government, 2. An agency wholly owned by a foreign government, or 3. An international organization. 2. Your employer is not required to withhold Social Security and Medicare taxes from your wages.

If you are a U.S. citizen or a non-U.S. resident who is self-employed and living outside the U.S., in most cases, you must pay self-employment tax. Income earned abroad from self-employment cannot be reduced by the foreign earned income exclusion when calculating your self-employment tax.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries to prevent double taxation under two social security systems. Under these agreements, you usually pay only social security and Medicare taxes to the country where you live. The country where you must pay taxes will issue a certificate showing that you are exempt from social security taxes in that country. For more information, see Social Security and Medicare Tax Guide (Form 1040).

You may want to use the optional method (will be discussed in the next section) when you have a small net loss or net income, and any of the following apply. You want to claim a tax credit for social security benefits. You must pay child care or dependent care expenses, so you may be able to claim a tax credit. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase your tax credit.) You are entitled to a tax credit for earned income. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase your tax credit.) You are entitled to a child tax credit. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase your tax credit.)

Using the optional method may increase your SE tax. Paying more SE tax may result in higher retirement benefits. Using the optional method may also reduce your AGI because it deducts half of the SE tax from your Form 1040 or 1040-SR, which may affect your eligibility for certain tax credits, deductions, or other benefits that are based on AGI limits. Calculate your AGI with and without using the optional method to see if it makes sense for you. If you use one or both of the optional methods, you must calculate and pay the SE tax using those methods even if you have a lower or no tax liability when using the regular method. The optional method can only be used to calculate your SE tax. To calculate your income tax, add your actual income to your total income, regardless of which method you use to figure your SE tax.

Please use only the non-farming method for income not from farming. You can use this method if you meet all the following considerations. 1. You are regularly self-employed. This means that your actual net income from self-employment is $400 or more in at least 2 of the 3 tax years before the year you use this method. For this purpose, net income in the previous year can come from farming or non-farming income or both. 2. You have not used this method for less than 5 years. (There is a lifetime limit of 5 years.) These years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your non-farming net income: 1. Is less than $7,493 and 2. Is less than 72.189% of your total non-farming income.
Generally, non-farming gross income is the total amount from: Line 7 of Schedule C (Form 1040); and Line 14, code C, Schedule K-1 (Form 1065) (earned from non-farming partnership).

Use Schedule SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report your self-employment taxes. If you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter your self-employment taxes on line 4 of Schedule 2 (Form 1040) and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you file Form 1040-SS, enter your self-employment taxes on line 3, and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you must pay self-employment taxes, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-SS, if applicable (with Schedule SE attached) even if you don't have to file a federal income tax return.

We accept most tax returns filed by taxpayers. If we investigate or select your return for examination, this does not mean you are not honest. An examination or audit may or may not result in an increase in tax. We may close your file without change or you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a return for examination begins in one of two ways. One way is to use computer programming to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs can be based on return information, such as Form 1099 and W-2; prior examination history; or on issues identified from special projects. The other way is to use information from outside sources that indicate a return may have incorrect amounts. These sources can include the news media, public documents, and individuals. If we determine that this information is accurate and reliable, we can use it to select a return for examination. Publication 556, Examination of Returns, Rights of Appeal, and Claims for Refunds, explains the rules and procedures we follow in our examination activities. The following sections provide an overview of how we conduct examinations.

If you do not agree with the changes proposed by the examiner, you may file a protest with the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Most disputes can be resolved without costly and time-consuming hearings. Your right to protest is explained in both Publication 5, Your Rights to Protest IRS Decisions and How to Prepare a Protest if You Do Not Agree, and Publication 556. If you do not want to resolve the matter through the Appeals Office or do not agree with the decision of the office, you may take your case to the United States Tax Court, the United States Court of Federal Claims, or the United States District Court in the district where you live. If you go to court, the IRS will have the burden of presenting evidence that you kept adequate records to show your tax liability, that you cooperated with the IRS, and that you met other requirements. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that most of our positions are unreasonable, you may be able to recover some of your administrative and litigation costs. You will not be eligible to recover these costs unless you have tried to resolve your case administratively, including through the appeals process, and provided us with the information we need to resolve your case.
Your right to appeal a tax assessment is explained in Publication 1660, Your Right to Appeal a Tax Assessment.

Generally, the IRS will deal directly with you or your authorized representative. However, sometimes we also communicate with others if we need information that you cannot provide or to verify information that we have received. If we communicate with others, such as neighbors, banks, employers, or employees, we usually will need to tell them some limited information, such as your name. The law prohibits us from disclosing any information beyond what is necessary to collect or verify the information we are seeking. The need to communicate with others may continue if your case is still open. If we communicate with others, you have the right to be told who we contacted. Your request can be made by phone, in writing, or during a personal interview.

After you receive all your wage and income statements (W-2s, W-2Gs, 1099-Rs, 1099-Ms, 1099-NEs, etc.); unemployment compensation statements (paper or electronic format) or other government payment statements (1099-Gs); and interest, dividend, and pension statements from banks and investment companies (1099s), you have several options to prepare and file your taxes. You can prepare your own tax return. see if you qualify for free tax preparation or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about assistive technology services may call 833-690-0598. The Assistive Technology Help Line can answer questions about current and future assistive technology products and services available in alternative media formats (e.g., braille, large print, audio, etc.). The Assistive Technology Help Line cannot access your IRS account. To get help with tax law, filing a return, or other account issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.
Access IRS.gov/DisasterRelief (English) to see tax relief available for disasters.

You will need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete forms that are mobile-friendly and require a signature. You will have the option to submit the form online or download a copy to mail in. You will need scanned copies of your documents to support your filing. Visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms (English) for more information.

Access IRS.gov/Account to securely access your federal tax account information. View the amount you owe and analyze by tax year. See details of your payment plan or enroll in a new payment plan. Make payments, view a 5-year payment history, and all pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax records, including important data from your most recent tax return, your payment impact amount, and your transcript. View electronic copies of selected IRS notices. Approve or reject tax preparer authorization requests. Update your address or manage your preferred ways of communication.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can get your records, review your most recently filed tax return, and get your adjusted gross income. Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/Account.

The safest and easiest way to receive your tax refund is to e-file and choose direct deposit, which will electronically deposit your refund directly into your financial account. Direct deposit also helps prevent lost, stolen, destroyed, or failed to be returned checks to the IRS. Of the 10 taxpayers who file, 8 choose direct deposit to receive their refunds. If you don't have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out where to find a bank or credit union that can help you open an account online.

The IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers by email, phone, text message (including short codes) or social media to request personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center web page, to learn about identity theft and protecting taxpayer data for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If you are a victim of identity theft, you can learn what steps you should take. Get an IP PIN. An IP PIN is a six-digit number that is issued to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of their Social Security number in tax fraud. When you have an IP PIN, it will prevent someone else from filing a tax return with your SSN. To learn more, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Electronic assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about how to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay personal tax bills or estimated tax bills directly from a checking or savings account for free. Debit cards, credit cards, or e-wallets: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): Best for businesses. Registration is required. Checks or money orders: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay taxes in cash at a participating retail location. Same-day wire transfers: You can make same-day wire transfers from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about availability, fees, and timing.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. File an Online Payment Agreement Application (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill in monthly installments if you currently can't pay your tax bill in full. After you complete the online process, you will be notified immediately to let you know whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Offer in Compromise (OIC) Tool (English) to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the total amount you owe. For more information about the OIC program, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.
Access IRS.gov/Notices to find more information about responding to an IRS notice or letter.

You can use the Document Upload Tool to electronically respond to certain IRS notices and letters by securely uploading the required documents online through IRS.gov. To learn more, visit IRS.gov/DUT (English).

You can use the LEP Table (Form 1040), Change of Language Preferences Request, to state your preference for receiving notifications, letters, or other written communications from IRS in a language other than English. You may not immediately receive written communications in the requested language. IRS's commitment to LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year schedule that is expected to begin providing translations in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including notices and letters, in English until they are translated into your preferred language.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, provides administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are Your Voice at the IRS.
The translation is correct, but it is not a direct translation.

If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership, or S corporation, you can view your tax information stored in your IRS file and do more with your business tax account. Visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

Visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia (English) to see the different social media tools that IRS uses to share the latest tax news, scams, initiatives, products and services. At IRS, privacy and security are our top priorities. We use these tools to share public information with you. Please do not post your Social Security number or other confidential information on social media. Always protect your identity when using any social media site. The following IRS YouTube channels have short informative videos in English, Spanish and ASL on various tax topics. Youtube.com/irsvideos (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosASL (English).
You can view information at IRS.gov/MyLanguage (English) if English is not your native language.

The Small Business Administration (SBA) offers training and education programs, consulting services, financial assistance, and contract support to small business owners. SBA also has publications and videos on a variety of business topics. Here is a brief overview of the support that SBA provides.

The SBDC centers provide consulting, training and technical assistance to current and future small business owners who do not have sufficient funds to use private consulting services. Assistance will be available in starting, improving or expanding a small business.

SCORE provides business consulting and training services to current and future small business owners. SCORE is comprised of current and former entrepreneurs who provide their expertise and knowledge to help people start, manage and grow small businesses. SCORE also hosts a series of workshops for small businesses.
You can access the SBA website at SBA.gov (English). While on the SBA website, you can find a wealth of information useful to small business owners.
Please call the SBA's Customer Assistance Line at 800-U-ASK-SBA (800-827-5722) to get general information about the programs available to assist small business owners.
You can visit the SBDC without an appointment to make requests for your small business. To find the one nearest you, please visit the website or call the SBA's Help Desk.
Call GPO at 866-512-1800 or 202-512-1800 from the Washington, DC area.

Generally, use your SSN as your TIN. You must report this number on every individual income tax return, such as Form 1040 and the schedules attached to it. To apply for an SSN, use Form SS–5, Application for a Social Security Number. This form is available at Social Security Administration (SSA) offices or by calling 800–772–1213. This form is also available on the SSA website at SSA.gov/forms/ss–5 (English).

The IRS will issue an ITIN if you are a non-resident alien or a U.S. resident alien and do not have and are not eligible to obtain a SSN. An ITIN will expire for any tax payer who fails to file a federal income tax return (or who is not considered a dependent on the return of another tax payer) for three consecutive years. In short, if you need to obtain an ITIN, you must attach Form W-7, Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, with a signed and properly completed original tax return and any other required documentation and mail them to the address in the instructions for Form W-7. There are exceptions to this requirement. If you must include the SSN of another person on your tax return and that person does not have, or is not eligible to obtain, an SSN, please enter the ITIN of that person. This form is also available in Spanish. The form is available at IRS.gov/FormW7 (English). An ITIN is for tax purposes only. It does not allow the holder to receive Social Security benefits or change their employment or immigration status.

If you must have an EIN, please include your EIN with your SSN on Schedule C as directed. You can apply for an EIN: Online by clicking the Employer Identification Number (EIN) link at IRS.gov/businesses/small as long as your principal place of business is located in the United States or U.S. territories — an EIN is issued immediately after the information on the application is verified; By phone at 267-941-1099 (not a toll-free number) only if your principal place of business is located outside the United States or U.S. territories; or By mail or fax Form SS-4, Application for Employer Identification Number.

When you operate your business, you may make certain payments that must be reported on your information return. These payments are discussed in the Information Return, in the back of this chapter. You must give the payee (the person you pay) a report showing the total amount paid during the year. You must give the payee's identification number and your identification number on your tax returns and reports.

If you have employees, you must get a SSN from each of them. Record the name and SSN of each employee exactly as they appear on their Social Security card. If the employee's name is not correct as on their card, the employee should request SSA to issue a new card. This may happen if the employee's name has changed due to marriage or divorce. Each employee completes Form W-4, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate, so that federal income tax can be withheld from their pay correctly. If your employee does not have a SSN, they should file Form SS-5 with SSA.

If you make payments to someone who is not an employee of yours and are required to report these payments on a Form 1099, get the SSN of the person you are paying. If you are required to report payments to an organization, such as a corporation or partnership, you must get the EIN of the organization. To get the SSN or EIN of the person being paid, use Form W-9, Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification (English). A person who does not provide you with a tax ID number may be subject to backup withholding. For more information about backup withholding, see Form W-9 Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification and General Instructions for Forms 1099 and 5498.
This section explains whether you have to file a tax return and when to file. This section also explains how you pay your taxes.

You must file a 2024 income tax return if you had net self-employment income of $400 or more. If you had net self-employment income of less than $400, you must file a 2024 income tax return if you meet any other filing requirements listed in the Instructions for Form 1040.

It's easier to file without paper than you think and is available to most taxpayers filing electronic returns — including first-time filers age 16 and older by the end of 2024. If filing electronic returns using tax software or through a tax preparer, you will sign your return using a Self-Selected PIN for IRS e-file. If you and your spouse are married filing jointly, each of you will need to create a PIN and enter those PINs as your electronic signature. To create a PIN, you must know your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from your original 2023 tax return (not from a 1040-X, or after receiving any mathematical error notices from IRS). You will also need to provide your date of birth (DOB). Make sure your DOB is correct and matches the information in your SSA record before you e-file. To do this, check your Social Security Administration Annual Report. With a Self-Selected PIN, you don't need to sign or mail anything — even your W-2. For more information about Self-Selected PIN, visit IRS.gov.
In most states, you can file your state tax return electronically and your federal tax return on paper. For more information, check with your state tax agency, tax professional, or IRS.gov.

You can receive your refund check by mail or have your refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. With e-file of IRS, your refund will be issued in half the time it takes to file on paper. Most refunds are issued within 21 days.

Also, as with a paper tax return, you may not receive the full refund amount if you (or your spouse, if filing jointly) owe a certain amount of money past due, such as federal taxes, state taxes, student loans, or child support. You will be notified if the refund amount you requested has been applied to your past-due debts. You can file Form 8379, Allocation for Injured Spouse or Form 8857, Request for Exemption for Injured Spouse, to recover part or all of the joint refund that was applied to your spouse's individual debts.

The IRS cannot issue a refund before February 2024 for tax returns that request earned income tax credits or additional child tax credits. This applies to the entire refund, not just the parts related to these credits.

If your tax return shows that you owe taxes, you must pay before the due date of your tax return (not including any tax extension) to avoid paying interest and penalties for late filing. For tax year 2024, please pay by April 15, 2025. You have several options to make your tax payments, including setting up electronic funds transfers from your checking or savings account or by using your credit card. For more information about payment options, please visit IRS.gov/Payments.

You will be required to complete IRS Form 8879, e-file Authorization for IRS to sign, to allow the provider to enter the provider's own PIN on the return. Depending on the provider and specific service required, a fee may be charged. To find an IRS-authorized e-file provider near you, please visit IRS.gov/Efile/Providers (English).

A computer connected to the Internet is all you need to file your tax return via IRS e-file. Using a personal computer, you can e-file from home at any time, day or night. Sign your tax return electronically by entering your self-selected PIN to complete the process. You do not need to file a signed paper return or a W-2 form.

If your AGI is $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free tax software to prepare and e-file your return.If your AGI is $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free tax software to prepare and e-file your return.

IRS also provides electronic versions of IRS forms, which can also be e-filed for free. The Free File fillable forms are the best choice for those who have experience in preparing their own tax returns. There is no income limit for using these forms. The Free File fillable forms perform basic calculations. These forms only support federal tax forms.

For tax year 2024, Form 1040 or 1040-SR is due on April 15, 2025. If you use calendar year reporting (explained in Chapter 2), your tax return is due on the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of your calendar year. If you file late, you may owe penalties and interest. If you cannot file on time, please use Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, to request an automatic extension of 6 months. For calendar year filers, this will extend the due date of your tax return to October 15. Filing an extension does not extend the time to pay your tax, it only extends the time to file your tax return.

Federal income tax is a pay-as-you-go tax. You must pay taxes on your income when you earn or receive it during the year. An employee usually has income tax withheld from their wages. If you don't pay your tax through withholding, or don't pay enough tax that way, you may have to pay estimated tax.
Other options include carrying over a refund from your 2023 tax return to your 2024 estimated tax, or mailing a check or money order with your Form 1040-ES payment coupon.

1. To register for EFTPS, visit EFTPS.gov (English) or call 800-555-4477. 2. When requesting a new EIN, you may be automatically enrolled in EFTPS. 3. The benefits of EFTPS include the following. 1. The likelihood of payment errors will decrease. 2. You will receive immediate confirmation for every transaction.

If you don't pay enough tax on your income and self-employment taxes for 2024 by withholding or paying your estimated tax, you may have to pay a penalty for the amount you don't pay. IRS will calculate the penalty and send you a bill. Or you can use Form 2210, Underpayment of Estimated Tax by Individual, Estate, or Trust, to see if you have to pay a penalty, and to figure the amount of the penalty. For more information, see Publication 505.

Self-employment tax is a social security and Medicare tax primarily paid by self-employed individuals. This tax is similar to social security and Medicare taxes withheld from the paychecks of most wage earners. If you earn income as an employee, you do not have to pay self-employment tax on that income. Social security and Medicare taxes should have been withheld from that income.

Social Security benefits are also available to self-employed individuals, just as they are to wage earners. SE tax payments will contribute to your insurance in the Social Security system. Social Security insurance provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and hospital insurance (Medicare). Be sure to report all of your self-employment income. Underreporting can result in lower Social Security benefits when you retire.

For 2024, you are entitled to one credit, up to four credits, for each $1,730 ($1,810 for 2025) of earned income. Therefore, in 2024, if you have earned income (self-employment and wages) of $6,920 that has been subject to Social Security tax, you will receive four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). To get information about the number of credits you must have to be insured and to receive benefits for yourself and your family under Social Security, please call the SSA office nearest you. False statements about your income to get or increase Social Security benefits can result in penalties.

Generally, SSA will only recognize self-employment income reported on a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months, and 15 days after the tax year in which you earned the income. If you file a tax return or report a change in your self-employment income after this time, SSA may change your record, but only to remove or reduce the amount. SSA will not change your record to increase your self-employment income.

Only $168,600 of your total compensation, tips, and net income in 2024 must be subject to any combination of the 12.4% Social Security tax, the self-employment tax, or the Railroad Retirement Tax Tier 1. All of your total compensation, tips, and net income in 2024 must be subject to any combination of the 2.9% Medicare tax, the self-employment tax, or the Railroad Retirement Tax Medicare. If your compensation and tips received as an employee are subject to the Social Security tax or the Railroad Retirement Tax Tier 1, or both, and total at least $168,600, you must not deduct the 12.4% Social Security tax from any of your net income. However, you must pay the 2.9% Medicare tax on all of your net income. Deduct one-half of your self-employment tax as a net income adjustment on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

If you have both salary and self-employment income, the amount of self-employment income that is subject to the additional Medicare tax will be reduced (but not below $0) by the amount of salary that is subject to the additional Medicare tax. Use Form 8959, Additional Medicare Tax, to figure this tax.

For more information, please see Publication 15 (Tax Guide for Employers), Tax Guide for Employers (English). That publication explains your tax responsibilities as an employer. Do not reduce your Social Security and Medicare tax deductions for the non-refundable and refundable parts of the FFCRA and ARP 2021 tax credits for qualified sick and family leave pay. Instead, report the credits as income on your employment tax return. To help you determine whether the people working for you are employees or independent contractors, please see Publication 15-A. That publication contains information to help you determine whether an individual is an independent contractor or an employee. If you misclassify an employee as an independent contractor, you may have to pay employment taxes for that employee, plus penalties.

If you make or receive payments in your business, you may have to report them to the IRS on a Form 1099. The IRS compares the payments on the Form 1099 with the individual's income tax return to see whether the payments are included in income. You must give a copy of the Form 1099 to the person who made the payment or who received the payment. In addition to the forms described below, you may need to use other tax forms to report certain types of payments or transactions. For more information about Form 1099 and when to file, see General Information About Form 1099.

You must also file Form 1099-NEC for each person you have withheld any federal income tax from (reported in box 4) under the rules for the amount withheld on wages to pay taxes annually regardless of the amount paid. If using Form 1099-NEC to report sales of consumer products with a total value of $5,000 or more, you must file Form 1099-NEC with the IRS by March 31.

You must file Form W-2 to report payments to your employees, such as wages, tips, and other compensation, income after withholding, Social Security and Medicare taxes, and other taxes. You can file Form W-2 online. For more information about Form W-2, see General Instructions for Forms W-2 and W-3.

The law provides the following penalties if you fail to file Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC, or Form W-2 or fail to report information correctly. For more information, see Publication 1096, General Instructions for Certain Information Returns. Failure to file. This penalty applies if you fail to file the return before the due date, fail to include all required information, or report information incorrectly. Failure to provide accurate reporting of payees. This penalty applies if you fail to provide the required Form 1099-MISC to payees before the due date, fail to include all required information, or report information incorrectly.

These penalties will not be applied if you can demonstrate that the failure to file was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. In addition, no penalty will be imposed in the case of a return that is not fully completed or contains incorrect information on a small (de minimis) number of returns if you correct the error before August 1 of the year that the return is due. (The de minimis number of returns is the larger of 10 or ½ of 1% of the total number of returns you must file in the year).

You must file Form 8300, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000 Received in a Trade or Business, if you receive more than $10,000 cash in a single transaction or in a series of related transactions. Cash includes coins and currency of the United States and of foreign countries. Cash also includes some monetary instruments such as bank checks, traveler's checks, and money orders. Cash does not include checks drawn from an individual's personal account (personal checks). For more information, see Publication 1544, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000.

Civil and criminal penalties, including up to 5 years in prison, may be imposed for failure to file Form 8300, filing (or causing the filing of) a false or fraudulent Form 8300, or structuring a transaction to evade reporting requirements.

You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return on a fiscal year basis, which is called a tax year. In addition, you must use a consistent method of accounting, through which you clearly present your income and expenses in the tax year.

If you do not have a mandatory tax year, you will apply a tax year by filing your first income tax return using that tax year. A mandatory tax year is a tax year that is required by the Income Tax Act or the Income Tax Regulations.

If you have filed your first tax return using calendar year and then started doing business as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use calendar year for your tax year unless you get IRS approval to change or are permitted to change without IRS approval. For more information, see Change of tax year, later. If you use calendar year, you must keep books and records and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 each year.

Tax year under the fiscal calendar is 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of any month except December. A 52-53 week tax year is a tax year under the fiscal calendar that extends from 52 to 53 weeks but need not end on the last day of the month. If you use a fiscal calendar tax year, you must maintain your books and records and report income and expenses in the same tax year. To learn more about fiscal calendar tax years, including 52-53 week tax years, see Publication 538.

Accounting methods are a set of rules used to determine when and how to report income and expenses. Your accounting method includes both the overall accounting method used and the method of accounting used for any individual item. You choose an accounting method for your business when you file your first tax return that includes Schedule C for your business. If you later want to change your accounting method, you usually must get IRS approval. See Change of Accounting Method, later.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and keep your books. You must also use a clear accounting method to present your income.

You can account for business and personal items using different accounting methods. For example, you can calculate your business income using an accrual method, even if you use a cash method for personal items.

"English": "Most individuals and many sole proprietorships do not use the cash method of accounting because they find it easier to keep records with the accrual method. However, if inventory is necessary to account for your income, you generally must use the accrual method to account for sales and purchases, unless you are a small business tax payer (defined later in this chapter). For more information, see Inventory, later.

Under the cash method, you must include all income that you actually received or that you were considered to have received in the tax year in your gross income. If you received property or services, you must include the fair market value of them in your income.

You have income from a trust when you receive a payment into your account or are given money that is not restricted. You do not have to own it. If you authorize someone else to act as your agent and receive income on your behalf, you are considered to have received the money when the agent receives it.

You cannot hold a check or defer the ownership of similar assets from one tax year to the next to avoid paying income tax. You must report income in the year you receive or are entitled to the asset without restrictions.
A valid check at the end of the tax year is a presumed receipt of income for that year, even if you cannot cash it or deposit the check until the following year.

If you have debts that are paid by someone else or are canceled by the creditor, you may have to report all or part of the debt forgiveness as income. If you receive income in this way, you will be treated as having received the income when the debt is canceled or paid. For more information, see Debt forgiven in the Income from other sources topic in Chapter 5.

Nếu bạn nhận được một khoản tiền gộp vào thu nhập và trong một năm sau đó phải hoàn trả toàn bộ hoặc một phần số tiền đó, bạn thường có thể khấu trừ khoản hoàn trả vào năm thực hiện việc hoàn trả. Nếu số tiền bạn hoàn trả lớn hơn $3.000, một quy tắc đặc biệt sẽ được áp dụng. Để biết chi tiết về quy tắc đặc biệt, vui lòng xem Khoản hoàn trả trong chương 8 của Ấn phẩm 17.

Under the cash method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year that you actually pay them. This includes business expenses that you are responsible for on a debt. However, you may not be able to deduct a prepaid expense or you may be required to capitalize certain expenses, as explained in the following section under the Unified Capitalization Rules.
You can deduct a cost that you pay in advance only in the year that the cost applies.

Under the accrual method, you typically report income in the year you earn it and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year they occur. The purpose of the accrual method is to match income and expenses in the year they occur accurately.

Under the accrual method, you generally include an amount in your total income for the tax year that all events that determine the right to receive income have occurred and you can determine that amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer who has a proper financial statement or other financial statement that the Minister may prescribe, the standard of consideration “all events” for a class of total income is considered to be satisfied no later than the time it is included in a proper financial statement or other financial statement similar.

If you include a reasonable estimate of the amount of income not subject to expenses and taxes, and then determine a different amount than the actual amount, please take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine it.

If you perform services at the basic rate specified in the contract, you must accrue income at the basic rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate until you complete the services and then receive the difference.

Generally, you report a payment in advance as income in the year you receive the payment. However, if you receive a payment in advance, you can choose to defer the payment in advance into income until the next tax year. You cannot defer any payment into income after that tax year. For more information, see Publication 538 and section 451.

Under the accrual method, you generally deduct or capitalize business expenses when both of the following conditions are met. 1. The accrual standard of accounting has been satisfied. The accrual standard of accounting is satisfied when: 1. All of the events that determine the existence of a liability have occurred and 2. The liability can be determined with a reasonable degree of accuracy. 2. The economic activity has occurred.

Generally, you can't deduct or capitalize business expenses until economic benefit occurs. If you have a cost for a property or service provided, or for the use of a property, then economic benefit occurs when the property or service is provided or when the property is used. If you have a cost for a property or service that you provide to others, then economic benefit occurs when you provide the property or service. An exception allows certain types of recurring items to be considered as occurring in the tax year even if economic benefit has not occurred. For more information about economic benefit, see Economic Performance in the Accrual Method topic in Publication 538.

When the production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in generating income for your business, you usually have to include inventory at the beginning and end of your tax year, unless you are a small business tax payer. If you must account for inventory, you usually have to use the accrual method for your purchases and sales transactions. For more information, see Inventory, in the back of this guide.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest on a related person's debt using the cash method until you make the payment, and the corresponding amount is included in the related person's gross income. For this rule, determine the relationship at the end of the tax year that the expense or interest will be deducted. If a deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with the person ends before the expense or interest is included in the person's gross income. Related persons include immediate family members, including siblings (same or different parents), your spouse, your parents, ancestors, and your immediate descendants. For a list of other related persons, see Section 267 of the Tax Code.

Generally, you can use any combination of special method, cash method, and accrual method if the combination clearly presents your income and expenses and you use it consistently. However, the following restrictions will apply. If you need inventory for the accounting of your income, you usually must use the accrual method for purchases and sales. (See Inventory in the following section.) You can use the cash method for all other income and expenses. If you use the cash method to calculate your income, you must use the cash method to report your expenses. If you use the accrual method to report your expenses, you must use the accrual method to calculate your income. If you use a combination method that includes the cash method, please consider that method to be the cash method.

If you are a small business tax filer, you can choose not to keep inventory, but you must still use a method of accounting that clearly reflects inventory income. If you choose not to keep inventory, you will not be considered to be clearly reflecting inventory income if your inventory accounting method treats inventory as a significant raw material or supply or follows your own financial inventory accounting method. However, if you choose to keep inventory, you usually must use an accrual and valuation method to determine inventory cost of goods sold in Part III of Schedule C.

You are eligible to be treated as a small business tax payer if (a) your average annual gross receipts are $30 million or less in the 3 tax years before and (b) you are not a tax avoidance entity (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business is not in operation for the entire 3 tax years used to calculate the average gross receipts, please base the average on the period it was in operation and if your business has a predecessor unit, include the gross receipts of that unit from the 3 tax years in the calculation of the average gross receipts. If your business (or predecessor unit) has a short tax year in any of the 3 tax years, include the annual gross receipts of your business for those short tax years in the 3 tax years in the calculation of the average gross receipts. See Publication 538 for more information.

You must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the cost of goods sold (Form C, Line 42). To determine the value of your inventory, you need to have a method of identifying the items in your inventory and a method of valuing those items. Inventory valuation rules cannot be the same for all types of businesses. The method you use to value your inventory must comply with the generally accepted accounting principles for businesses of a similar nature and must clearly reflect income. Your inventory practices must be consistent from year to year.

Under the uniform capitalization rule, you must capitalize direct and indirect costs for production or resale activities. Add these costs to the book value of the property you produce or buy to sell, instead of deducting them as a current expense. You recover the costs through depreciation of tangible property, depreciation of intangible property, or cost of goods sold when you use, sell, or otherwise dispose of the property.

You may have to follow the uniform capitalization rules if you do any of the following, unless the property is produced for you to use outside of business or a profit-making activity. Produce real property or personal property that is tangible. For this purpose, tangible personal property includes films, sound recordings, video tapes, books, or similar property. Buy property to resell.
These rules do not apply to the following. 1. Small business tax filers, as defined above under Inventory. 2. Assets you produce if the indirect costs to produce the asset are $200,000 or less.

There are special accounting methods for certain types of income or expenses. They include the following. Depreciation of intangible fixed assets, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication 225. Bad debts, discussed in Topic 453, Deduction for Bad Debts. Depreciation of tangible property, discussed in Publication 946, Depreciation of Property. Installment sales, discussed in Publication 537, Installment Sales. Long-term contracts. See Section 460.

If you handle business assets, you may have a taxable profit or a loss and you report them on your tax return. However, in some cases, you may have a taxable profit or a loss that is not deductible. This chapter discusses whether you dispose of an asset, how to calculate a profit or loss, and where to report them.
For information on damaged, destroyed, or stolen property, see Publication 547, Damage, Disaster, and Theft. For information on other types of liquidation, see Chapter 1 of Publication 544.

Some transfers of property are exempt from tax. This means that any profit from the exchange is not recognized and you cannot deduct any losses. Your profit or loss will not be recognized until you sell or dispose of the property received.

Like-kind exchanges are exchanges of this property for another property of the same kind. This is the most common type of non-taxable exchange. To be a like-kind exchange, the property exchanged and the property received must be both (a) real property and (b) business or investment property. Report a like-kind exchange on Form 8824, Like-kind exchanges. For more information about like-kind exchanges, see Chapter 1 of Publication 544.

A sale-leaseback is a sale of a property when you receive at least one payment after the tax year of the sale of the property. If you finance the buyer when purchasing your property, rather than having the buyer borrow money or a mortgage from a third party, you may be making a sale-leaseback. For more information about sale-leasebacks, see Publication 537.

The sale of a business is usually not the sale of an asset. Instead, all of the business's assets are sold. Typically, when this happens, each asset is considered to be sold separately in order to determine the gain or loss. Both the buyer and the seller participating in the sale of a business must report to the IRS on the allocation of the sale price among the business's assets. Use Form 8594, Section 1060 Purchase of Property, to provide this information. The buyer and seller must attach Form 8594 to their federal income tax return for the year the sale occurs. For more information about the sale of a business, see Publication 544.

The cost or purchase price of an asset is usually the original price used to determine the gain or loss from the sale or other disposition of the asset. However, if you acquire the asset by gift, inheritance, or some other means other than purchase, you must use a different original price than the cost basis of the asset. For more information about original price, see Publication 551, Basis of Property.

Adjusted cost of assets is generally your cost or other basis plus additional amounts and minus certain deductions such as depreciation and losses from damage. When determining profit or loss, transfer costs of assets to new owners, such as sales expenses, are added to adjusted cost of assets.

Generally, the net proceeds from the transaction are the total amount of money you receive plus the reasonable market value of all assets or services you receive. Net proceeds also include any of your debts that the buyer assumes and any debts that the property you transfer must pay, such as property taxes or a mortgage.
Affordable market price is the price at which the property will be exchanged between the buyer and the seller, who are not obliged to buy or sell, and both are aware of all the things to be done.

Your net profit or loss from the operation of assets is usually the profit or loss determined for tax purposes. Profits are recognized as income. Losses are recognized as deductions. However, profits or losses from trading assets are not recognized. Please see Tax-free trading in the previous section. In addition, you cannot deduct a loss from the operation of assets held for personal use.

You must classify your capital gains and losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this to calculate your net capital gains or losses. Generally, you will have capital gains or losses if you dispose of a capital asset. In most cases, everything you own and use for personal or investment purposes is a capital asset. Some assets you use in your business are not capital assets. Any gain or loss from the disposition of these assets is an ordinary gain or loss. However, if you hold the asset for more than 1 year, you may treat the gain or loss as a capital gain or loss. These gains and losses are called Section 1231 gains and losses. For more information about ordinary and capital gains and losses, see Chapter 2 and 3 of Publication 544.
