All of the following tax credits are part of the general business tax credit. The form you use to calculate each credit is shown in parentheses. You must also complete Form 3800. Some tax credits have expiry dates. Check the instructions for each credit to make sure that there are credits for 2024.
This credit applies to the cost of any qualified fuel-efficient vehicle. To get more information, see Form 8911.

This credit applies to startup costs for a new defined benefit or defined contribution (including 401(k)) retirement plan, a SIMPLE plan, or a simple employee pension plan. For more information, see Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Businesses.

This credit is a nonrefundable credit for eligible small businesses that pay or incur expenses to provide accommodations for people with disabilities. You must pay or incur expenses to operate your business in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. For more information, see Form 8826.
You may be eligible for this tax credit if you have employees and are engaged in a business activity in a distressed area where the tax credit is available. For more information, see Form 8844.
This tax credit is available to contractors of certain homes sold for use as a residence. For more information, see Form 8908.
This credit is generally applied to each low-income building that meets the requirements and is placed in service after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
Tax credit for renewable energy produced at U.S. or U.S. territory facilities from qualifying sources. For more information, see Form 8835.
This tax credit encourages businesses to hire individuals from target groups with particularly high unemployment rates or other special employment needs. For more information, see Form 5884.

This tax credit encourages businesses to continue paying wages to employees providing at-home services to uniformed members of the U.S. armed forces for more than 30 days. For more information, see Form 8932.
This credit applies to expenses you pay for child care services for your employees, as well as for child care support and referral services. For more information, see Form 8882.
This credit applies to some health insurance costs that you pay for some of your employees. To get more information, see Form 8941.

To claim a general business tax credit, you must first complete the forms required to claim the business tax credits for the current year. In addition to the tax credit form, you must also file Form 3800.

This chapter primarily explains business income and how to report that income on your tax return, as well as what is not considered business income, and provides guidance for certain selected trades. If there is a connection between any income you receive and a business, then that income is business income. A connection exists if the payment for the income is clearly not made if you do not have a business. You can have business income even if you do not regularly engage in the activity full-time. Income from work you do outside of your regular job may be business income. For example, you may operate a ride-sharing business as a second job. You report most business income, such as income from selling your products or services, on Schedule C. However, you report income from selling business assets, such as land and office buildings, on other forms instead of Schedule C. To learn about selling business assets, see chapter 3.

Business income includes the amount you received from your business activity that is shown correctly on your 1099-NEC. This income includes the amount reported as nonemployee compensation in box 1 of the form. You can find more information in the instructions on the back of your 1099-NEC form.

NIL opportunities may be classified as self-employment income. If your NIL income is more than $600 from any source, including non-cash income, you will receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC from that source reporting the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you are engaged in business, you may receive Form 1099-K showing the total amount (including taxes, fees) of all payment transactions reportable. This may not be the amount you should report as income, because it may not include all receipts and may include amounts not in your receipts (such as sales tax).
Your income reported on Schedule C may be business income that qualifies and allows you to deduct on line 13 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to calculate your deduction, if any.

You must report all income you receive from your business activity on your tax return, including income not reported to you on a 1099 form by the person paying you. In most cases, your business income will be in the form of cash, checks, and credit card payments. But business income can be in other forms, such as property or services. These and other forms of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen with business income from sources outside the United States (foreign income), you must report that income on your tax return unless it is exempt from U.S. tax by law. If you live outside the United States, you may exclude all or part of your foreign business income. For more information, see Publication 54, Tax Guide for U.S. Citizens and Foreign Residents Living Abroad.

Exchange of goods is the exchange of property or services. You must include in your gross income, at the time you receive them, the fair market value of the property or services you receive in exchange for something else. If you exchange services with another person and both of you have previously agreed on the value of the services, that value will be accepted as the fair market value unless that value can be shown to be unreasonable.

If you are a real estate dealer receiving rental income from real estate or are a hotel, motel, or similar owner who provides services to tenants, you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule C. If you are not a real estate dealer or a type of owner described above, you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule E. For more information, see Publication 527, Rental Income and Expenses.

You are a real estate broker if you are engaged in the business of selling real estate to customers for the purpose of making a profit from those transactions. The rental income you receive from the real estate held for sale to customers is subject to self-employment tax. However, rental income you receive from the real estate held for speculation or investment is not subject to self-employment tax.

Rental income from mobile home parks is generally treated as self-employment income if you are the owner of the mobile home park, the provider of the land and the mobile homes, and the provider of the essential services that make the park convenient for the tenants. You will generally be considered to be providing essential services to the tenants if the services are primarily directed toward making the park convenient for them and are not generally provided for the purpose of maintaining the land in a condition to be rented for living purposes. Services are essential if the compensation for the services is a substantial part of the rental payments from the tenants. Examples of services that are generally not provided to make the park convenient for the tenants include the supervision and maintenance of the recreation room that the park provides, the distribution of monthly newsletters to the tenants, the operation of a laundry facility, and the assistance to the tenants in buying or selling their mobile homes. Examples of services that are generally provided to maintain the land in a condition to be rented include drainage systems, utility connections, and city streets.

Rents you receive from letting or renting out a hotel, boarding house, or apartment are subject to self-employment tax if you provide lodging services to tenants. Generally, you are considered to provide lodging services if the services are primarily for the convenience of the tenants and are not merely the rental of rooms for occupancy. An example of a service that is not typically provided for the convenience of tenants is maid service. However, heating and lighting, cleaning of stairways and hallways, and garbage collection are typically services provided for the convenience of tenants.

Prepaid expenses received under a lease agreement that are not restricted as to when they can be enjoyed or used are income in the year you receive them. This is generally true whether you use the cash or accrual method of accounting.
Additional rent is money you receive from a tenant when you rent them a property. Include this amount in your gross income for the year you receive it.
Reporting payments you receive from a tenant when they terminate a lease to gross income in the year received.

If your tenant pays someone else under a contract to pay your debts or obligations, you must include the payment in your gross income when the tenant makes the payment. A common example of this type of income is when the tenant pays your property taxes for the rental property.

Any payments you receive to restore the leased property to its original condition are rental income to the extent that the payments exceed the adjusted basis of the leased property that was destroyed, damaged, removed, or separated by the tenant.

If you are renting personal property (apparatus, vehicles, formal wear, etc.), include the rental income you receive in your total gross income on Schedule C. Any advance payments and other payments described in Rental of Real Estate in the previous section may also be received when renting personal property. If you receive any of these payments, include them in your gross income as explained in that discussion.

Interest income from notes receivable that you have accepted in the ordinary course of business is business income. Interest income from loans is business income if you are in the business of lending money.

If a loan to you becomes uncollectible in the tax year in which you use the accrual method of accounting, you must include in your gross income the amount of accrued interest to the time the loan becomes uncollectible. If the accrued interest is later uncollectible, you may be able to deduct it as a bad debt. See Bad debts in chapter 8.

If little or no interest is charged on a contract sale, you may have to treat a part of each payment as interest not stated in the contract. See Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID) in Publication 537.

Generally, dividends are business income of stockholders. However, for most individual businesses and employees, dividends are non-business income. If you hold shares as a separate investment separate from your own business activities, dividends from shares are non-business income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums that you have deducted in a previous year, you must report all or part of the dividends as business income on your tax return. To determine the amount you must report, see Withdrawing previously deducted items in the Other Income section, later in this publication.
This section explains the general rule for calculating the amount of cancelled debt included in income, as well as the exceptions to the general rule.

Generally, if your debt is canceled or forgiven, except in the case that it is a gift or a property left to you, you must include the amount canceled in your gross income for tax purposes. Report the amount canceled on line 6 of Schedule C if you must bear the debt in your business. If it is a nonbusiness debt, please report the amount canceled on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

If you owe a seller a sum for a property you have purchased and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you usually have no income from the reduction. Unless you are bankrupt or insolvent, please treat the reduction as a purchase price adjustment and a reduction in your basic value of the asset.
You do not actually receive income from a cancelled debt in the event that the debt repayment will result in a deduction.

If a debt is discharged, it is excluded from income because it arises in a bankruptcy case, then the exclusions in situations 2 through 5 do not apply. If this discharged debt arises when you are insolvent, then the exclusions in situations 3 and 4 do not apply to your insolvency case.
For the purposes of this discussion, debt here includes any debt that you owe or that is attached to the property you hold.

You can elect to exclude (within a specified limit) the cancellation of business real property debt that is qualified. If you make this election, you must subtract the amount excluded from the adjusted basis of your real property subject to depreciation. Make this reduction at the beginning of the tax year following the year in which the cancellation occurs. However, if you dispose of the property before that time, you must reduce the adjusted basis of the property before the disposition.

Real property business indebtedness that meets the requirements described in (3) above, but only to the extent that it does not exceed the amount of the indebtedness being refinanced. If you are the owner of a non-qualified entity (e.g., a single-member LLC), please see Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness in Chapter 1 of Publication 4681 to determine whether you qualify for this exclusion. You cannot exclude more than one of the following two amounts. 1. The excess (if any) of: 1. The unpaid principal of the qualified real property business indebtedness (immediately before being canceled); over 2. The fair market value (immediately before being canceled) of the business real property that secures the indebtedness, reduced by the unpaid principal of any other qualified real property business indebtedness secured by the same property immediately before being canceled. 2. The adjusted basis of the depreciable real property that you hold immediately before being canceled. These adjusted bases are determined based on any depreciation taken due to the cancellation by bankruptcy or default, or of qualified farm indebtedness. Do not include real property that is to be cancelled in anticipation of its being disposed of.

To make this election, you must file Form 982 and attach it to your tax return for the tax year in which the cancellation occurs. You must file the return by the due date (including any extension period). If you file the return in the year in which the cancellation occurs without making the election, you still can make the election by filing an amended return within six months after the due date of the return (including any extension period). For more information, see When to file in the instructions for the form.
The discussion below explains how to handle different types of business income that you may receive.

Restricted assets are assets whose value is affected by certain restrictions. If you receive restricted stock or other assets for services performed, the fair market value of the asset over and above the cost will be included in your income on Schedule C when the restrictions are lifted. However, you may choose to be taxed in the year you receive the asset. For more information about including restricted assets in income, see Publication 525, Tax Guide for Small Business and Self-Employed.
In the following cases, you must reclaim the depreciation deduction. This means that you include in income part or all of the depreciation that you have deducted in previous years.

If the use of property listed in your business activities (explained in Chapter 8 in the section Depreciation) decreases to 50% or less in a tax year after the year you placed the property in service, you may have to reverse a part of the depreciation deduction. You do this by adding back to income on Schedule C the depreciation you took in prior years. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to figure the amount to add back. For more information, see What Is the Business-Use Requirement? in Chapter 5 of Publication 946. This chapter explains how to determine whether the property is used more than 50% in your business.

If you take a deduction under section 179 (explained in chapter 8 in the section on Depreciation) for a property and before the end of the property's depreciation period and the business use percentage drops to 50% or less, you must recover a part of the section 179 deduction. You do this by adding to your income on Schedule C a part of the deduction you took. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to figure the amount to add to your income. See Chapter 2 of Publication 946 to figure when to recover the deduction.

If you sell or exchange property that has been depreciated and you have a gain, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income. You figure the income from the recovery of depreciation in Part III of Schedule 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Publication 544.

Not reporting in Schedule C any profit or loss from the liquidation of property not held primarily for sale in the ordinary course of business. Instead, you must report those profits and losses on other forms. For more information, see Chapter 3.

Reporting the debt-forgiveness income and other evidence of the debt issued to you in a sale or exchange of property held primarily for sale to customers in Schedule C. Typically, you report them at the original amount stated in the loan agreement (minus any interest not stated in the agreement) or the issue price (or debt instrument with OID) when you receive them.

If you reduce or cease your business activities, report any payments you receive for lost business income from insurance or other sources in Schedule C. Report the payment in Schedule C even if your business is not active at the time of payment.

You must combine any compensation you received in the tax year from any of the following losses related to your business. Patent infringement. Contract or fiduciary liability. Loss from antitrust violations.

You may deduct from your income if the deduction compensates for a net loss. Your deduction is less than the following. The amount you receive or accumulate for the loss in the tax year minus the amount you must pay or bear in the tax year to recover that amount. The loss from that loss that you have not deducted.

If you recover a bad debt or any other deduction taken in the previous year, include that recovery in your income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the deduction in previous years did not reduce your tax, you may deduct the part that did not reduce your tax. If deducting a part of the recovery from income, you must include in your tax return a calculation showing how you computed the deduction.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income.
The increase in value of your assets is not income until you realize the additional value through a sale or other taxable disposition.

If the tenant builds or repairs buildings on your property, then the increase in value of the property from the repairs is not income to you. However, if the facts show that the repairs are actually a rental payment to you, then the increase in value will be income.
Money borrowed through a charitable loan is not income.
State and local sales taxes are levied on the buyer, which you must collect and remit to the state or local government, not income.

Short-term leases are leases (or other arrangements for the use of) retail space for a term of 15 years or less. The following rules are applied to determine whether a lease is a short-term lease of 15 years or less. Please consider renewal options when determining whether a lease is a short-term lease of 15 years or less. However, please do not consider any options to renew at a market rate determined at the time of renewal. Two or more consecutive leases that are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or substantially similar retail space are considered to be a short-term lease.
Retail space is real estate that you rent out, or use as a tenant in the business of selling personal property or public services.
Long-term residential property is a non-residential property that is part of a retail floor or is currently located at your retail floor and will be returned to the landlord when the lease ends.

Generally, if you exchange real property used for business or held as an investment solely for other real property or business of the same kind, no gain or loss is recognized. This means that no gain is taxable and no loss is deductible. For more information, see Form 8824.

You must report this income even if it is reported to you on a W-2 form. You are a direct seller if you meet all of the following conditions. 1. You are engaged in one or more of the following business or commercial activities. 1. Selling or offering for sale consumer products at your home or other place of business that is not a fixed retail establishment or to any purchaser on the basis of a buy-sell or cash-deposit-commission arrangement with the purpose of reselling at your home or other place of business that is not a fixed retail establishment. 2. Furnishing or distributing newspapers or shopping news (including any service directly related to the business or commercial activity). 2. In general, all payments you receive (whether in cash or otherwise) for the services described above are directly related to sales volume or other output (including the performance of the service) rather than time worked. 3. The services you perform are under a written contract between you and the person for whom you perform the services, and the contract provides that you will not be considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a licensed real estate agent or a direct seller, your income is reported on Schedule C if both of the following apply. Basically, all payments you receive for services as a real estate agent or a direct seller are directly related to sales volume or production rather than hours worked. You perform the services under a written contract that states that you will not be considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

Nếu bạn là một nhà môi giới mua bán quyền chọn hoặc hàng hóa, thì lợi nhuận và lỗ của bạn khi mua bán hoặc đầu cơ theo các hợp đồng theo đoạn 1256 (hợp đồng kỳ hạn được quy định, hợp đồng ngoại tệ, quyền chọn phi vốn chủ sở hữu, quyền chọn vốn chủ sở hữu đại lý và hợp đồng kỳ hạn chứng khoán của đại lý) hoặc tài sản liên quan đến những hợp đồng đó (chẳng hạn như cổ phần được sử dụng để bảo đảm quyền chọn) được khai báo trong Bảng C. Để biết thêm thông tin, vui lòng xem đoạn 1256 và 1402(i).

You are a securities or commodities trader if you are engaged in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities for your own account. As a securities or commodities trader (including if you make an election under section 475(f) to treat your securities or commodities trading as a trade or business), your income or loss from trading securities or commodities is not reported on Schedule C. For more information about securities or commodities traders, see Publication 550, Investment Income and Deductions and Topic 429, Securities Traders.

The termination payments you receive as a former independent insurance agent from an insurance company for services you performed for the company are not reported on Schedule C if all of the following conditions are met. You received the payments after the service performance agreement with the company ended. You did not perform any services for the company after the service performance agreement ended and before the end of the year you received the payment. You signed a non-compete agreement with the company for a period of at least 1 year beginning from the date the service performance agreement ended. The payment amount is primarily based on the insurance contracts you sold or were credited to your account in the last year of the service performance agreement or the period that the insurance contracts remain effective after the service performance agreement ends or both of these conditions. The payment amount is not dependent on any period of service performed or total income from services performed for the company (regardless of whether the payment eligibility is dependent on the period of service performed).

Income from insurance companies paid to a retired independent insurance agent based on a percentage of the commissions earned before retirement reported on Schedule C. Additionally, deferred commissions as well as commissions deferred on sales earned before retirement are also typically reported on Schedule C. However, deferred commissions paid under a contract for life insurance on the life of a surviving spouse of an insurance agent are not reported on Schedule C.
This rule applies whether you hire someone to help you deliver the goods or you purchase the newspaper from the publisher or you are paid based on the number of newspapers you deliver.

Government employees in general do not report what they earn while serving at the office in Schedule C. This rule applies to payments that a tax collector who is elected or appointed receives from the state's treasury on the basis of a fixed percentage of the taxes collected. The office includes any elected or appointed office of the United States or territory of the United States, the District of Columbia, a state or any political subdivision of it, or a means wholly owned by any of these offices. Government employees of the state or local government report their fees in Schedule C if they are paid only on the basis of fees and if their service is eligible for (but not paid by) social security under a federal-state agreement.

Your income for tax purposes is sometimes different from your income for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the more common differences that may affect your business transactions. Calculate your business income on the basis of a tax year and according to your usual accounting method (see Chapter 2). If the sale of products is a source of income in your business, you usually have to use inventory to present your income clearly. Real estate brokers are not allowed to use inventory. For more information on inventory, see Chapter 2.

You must use the method you have chosen each year for all your purchase discounts. If you use the second method, the balance in your account at the end of the tax year is business income. Under this method, you do not deduct any cash discounts you receive from the cost of goods sold. When you value inventory at the end of the tax year, you cannot deduct the average or estimated discount you will receive for goods on hand at the end of the tax year from the cost on the delivery receipt for those goods.

If the buyer of your property places a portion or all of the purchase price into a escrow account held by a third party, you will not include any portion of that amount in your gross sales income until you actually or are deemed to have received it. However, after the terms of the contract and the escrow agreement of the third party are completed, you will have taxable income, even if you have not accepted the money until the following year.

If you contribute inventory (assets that you sell in the course of your business), the amount you may claim as a contribution deduction will be the lesser of the fair market value of it on the date you contribute and its basis. The basis of donated inventory is any cost incurred for the inventory in the year before it was donated that if it were not donated would be included in your beginning inventory for the contribution year. You must remove your contribution deduction from your beginning inventory. It is not part of the cost of goods sold. If the cost of donated inventory is not included in your beginning inventory, its basis is zero, and you cannot claim a charitable contribution deduction. Treat the cost of donated inventory as you would under your usual method of accounting. For example, add the cost of donated inventory purchased and donated in the same year to the cost of goods sold for that year. A special rule may apply to some donated inventory activities, such as food. See Publication 526, Charitable Contributions.

If you are a business owner, please use the cost of all goods you have purchased to sell. If you are a business owner or manufacturer, this cost includes the cost of all raw materials or parts purchased to produce a finished product.If you are a business owner, please use the cost of all goods you have purchased to sell. If you are a business owner or manufacturer, this cost includes the cost of all raw materials or parts purchased to produce a finished product.

The difference between the listed price of the items and the actual price you pay for them is called a trade discount. You must use the price you actually pay (not the listed price) to figure your cost of goods sold. Do not report the trade discount separately as a separate line item on your total income. A car dealer must record the cost of a car in inventory after subtracting any manufacturer's rebate that is a trade discount.

Cash discount is the amount that your supplier allows you to deduct from your purchase invoice when you pay early. There are two methods of accounting for cash discounts. You can record them in a separate discount account or deduct them from the total purchase cost in the year. Regardless of which method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change the method of calculating inventory cost, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see Change of method of accounting in Chapter 2. If you record cash discounts in a separate account, you must include the balance in your business income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, please do not deduct cash discounts from your cost of goods sold.

If you withdraw goods for personal or family use, you must deduct the cost from your total cost for the goods you have bought to sell. Do this by recording the cost of the goods you withdraw for personal use in your purchase or sales account. You must also include this amount in your cash-at-hand account. The cash-at-hand account is a separate account that you should keep to record your business income that you withdraw to pay personal and family expenses. As mentioned above, you also use it to record the withdrawal of goods for personal or family use. This account is also known as a cash-at-hand account or personal account.

Labor costs are usually a part of the cost of goods sold, but this is only true for manufacturing or mining enterprises. Retailers (wholesale, retail, etc.) usually do not have labor costs that can be allocated to the cost of goods sold in a reasonable manner. In a manufacturing enterprise, labor costs are allocated in a reasonable manner to the cost of goods sold, including both direct and indirect labor used to transform raw materials into finished goods that can be sold.

Direct labor costs are the wages you pay to full-time employees who work directly on the product being produced. These costs also include a portion of the wages you pay to part-time employees who work directly on the product if you can identify that portion of their wages.

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform a common factory function that has no direct or immediate relationship with the production of a saleable product, but is an essential part of the production process.

Other labor costs not included in the cost of goods sold may be deducted from selling expenses or management expenses. Typically, the only labor costs that can be reasonably included in your cost of goods sold are direct or indirect labor costs and certain other costs that are considered to be general production costs as discussed in Line 39, Other expenses.

Materials and supplies, such as hardware and chemicals, used in the production of goods are included in the cost of goods sold. Things not used in the production process are considered a deferred expense. You deduct them as a business expense when you use them. Business expenses are discussed in Chapter 8.
Below are examples of other expenses incurred in the process of production or mining that you include in your cost of goods sold.

The containers and packaging in which the product is sold are a component of the product sold and are included in your cost of goods sold. If they are not a component of the product sold, then the cost of them is shipping cost or selling cost.

Overhead costs include costs such as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labour and supervision. Overhead costs you must pay are included in the cost of goods sold.

Take the value of your year-end inventory (including any allocable portion of raw material and supplies, direct labor, and overhead if appropriate) and subtract it from line 40. Year-end inventory is also known as year-end inventory. Your year-end inventory will usually become your year-end inventory in the next tax year.

Your gross profit is calculated by first determining your gross revenue. Calculate your gross revenue (line 3) in Schedule C by subtracting any returns and allowances (line 2) from your gross sales (line 1). Returns and allowances include cash refunds or credits that you give to customers, refunds and other allowances that are not part of the actual selling price. Then subtract your cost of goods sold (line 4) from your gross revenue (line 3). The result is your gross profit from your business.

You do not have to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of the merchandise is not a factor in generating income for your business. Your gross profit is equal to your gross revenue (gross revenue minus any refunds, returns or other allowances). Most businesses and trades that sell services rather than products can calculate gross profit directly from gross revenue in this way.

At the end of each business day, please ensure that your books are balanced with your cash receipts and are properly recorded in the day. You may find it helpful to use a cash register to track your receipts. You should also use a proper invoicing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

Check to ensure that your document correctly reports the amount of consumption tax collected. If you are a seller of goods or services to a buyer, and consumption tax of the state and local governments applies to you, you must include the amount collected in your gross income. If you are required to collect consumption tax of the state and local governments from a buyer and remit it to the state or local government, you generally do not include these amounts in your income.

Check to ensure that your inventory count procedures are complete. These procedures must ensure that all items have been counted into inventory and that appropriate valuation techniques have been used. Use the inventory form and roll tape machine sheets as the only evidence for your inventory. The inventory form is available at office supply stores. The forms have columns for recording description, quantity, unit price and value of each inventory item. Each page has space to record who performed the count, who valued the items, who performed the multiplication of quantity and unit price and who checked the calculations. The forms will help you verify that the total cost of inventory has been calculated correctly. They will also provide you with a durable document to support its legal value. Inventory is discussed in Chapter 2.

If you are in the retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your total profit calculation. First, divide your total profit by your gross sales. The percentage yield is a measure of the average spread between your cost of goods sold and your selling price. Next, compare this percentage yield with your policy for the spread between your selling price and your cost of goods sold. A lack of spread or a small spread between the two percentages indicates that your total profit figure is accurate. A large spread between the percentages may indicate that you have not calculated your sales, cost of goods sold, inventory, or other line items accurately. You should determine the reason for the spread.

You run a retail business. On average, you price your goods at a mark-up that results in a net profit of 331/3% of sales. Your gross revenue (total sales minus returns and discounts) as reported on your income statement is $300,000. Your cost of goods sold is $200,000. This results in a total profit of $100,000 ($300,000 − $200,000). To verify the accuracy of your year-end results, you divide the total profit ($100,000) by the gross revenue ($300,000). The result is 331/3%, which confirms that your mark-up percentage of 331/3% is correct.

If your business has income from a source other than its normal business activities, please enter that income in line 6 of Schedule C and add it to your total business income. The result is your total business income. Examples include interest income from a checking account, scrap sales income, income from certain tax credits and fuel refunds, and amounts recovered from bad debts.

You can deduct your business operating expenses. These expenses are called business expenses. These are expenses that you do not capitalize or include in the cost of goods sold but can deduct in the current year. To be deductible, a business expense must be ordinary. An ordinary expense is a common and accepted expense in your business. A necessary expense is an expense that is useful and appropriate to your business. An expense is not necessarily mandatory to be necessary. To learn more about the general rules for deducting business expenses, see Section 162 and the regulations. If you have an expense that is partly for business and partly for personal use, please separate the personal use part from the business part. The personal use part is not deductible.

SEP and SIMPLE programs also provide you and your employees with a tax-advantaged way to save for retirement. You can deduct your own contributions to your employees' plan on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are a sole proprietor, you can deduct your own contributions to your own plan on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). You can also deduct trustee fees if they are not included in the plan contributions. Income from contributions is generally tax-free until you or your employees receive distributions from the plan. You can also claim a credit if you start a qualified defined benefit or defined contribution plan (including a 401(k) plan), a SIMPLE or SEP plan. To learn more about this credit and the automatic enrollment and spouse-in-the-military credits, see Form 8881 and its instructions. Under certain plans, employees may ask you to contribute a limited amount that is part of their untaxed compensation paid to a plan. These amounts (and income from them) are generally tax-free until the employee receives a distribution from the plan. For more information about small business retirement plans, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs), discusses other tax-advantaged ways to save for retirement.

Rent is any amount of money you pay for the use of a property that you do not own. Generally, you can only deduct rent as a business expense if the rent is for a property you use in your business. If you own the property or will receive equity or ownership interest in the property, you cannot deduct rent.

You cannot deduct rental expenses for unreasonable rental amounts. Generally, the issue of reasonableness arises only when you and the landlord have a relationship. Rental payments to a related party are reasonable if they are equal to the amount you would pay to a stranger to use the same property. Rental payments are not considered unreasonable just because they are calculated as a percentage of gross income. Related parties include immediate family members, including siblings (whether or not they share the same parents), your spouse, your parents, grandparents, and your immediate descendants. For a list of other related parties, see Section 267 of the Tax Code.

Generally, rental payments made in your business are deducted in the year that the payment is made or accumulated. If you pay ahead on your rental payments, you can only deduct the amount that applies to your use of the leased property in the tax year. You can only deduct the remaining amount of the payment in the period of time that it applies to.

You can deduct in Schedule C a state income tax for total income (as opposed to net income) that is directly attributable to your business. You can deduct state and local income taxes in Schedule A (Form 1040) if you list your deductions. Do not deduct federal income taxes.

You can deduct Social Security, Medicare, and FUTA taxes that you paid out of your own pocket as an employer. The payroll tax is discussed briefly in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments that you made as an employer into the state's unemployment compensation fund or into the state's disability benefits fund. Please deduct these payments as taxes.
You may deduct in Schedule C any taxes imposed by a state or local government on property used in your business. You may also deduct fees for registering the use of property in a state or local area.

You can deduct from Schedule C the real estate taxes you pay for your business property. Deductionable real estate taxes are any state, local, or foreign income taxes imposed on income from sources outside the United States that are levied on real property used for public purposes in general. The tax authority must assess these types of taxes at the same rate for all real property within its jurisdiction and the proceeds must be used for general community or governmental purposes.

Please treat any consumption tax that you must pay for a service or for the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service or cost or use of the property is a business expense that can be deducted, you may deduct the tax as part of the service or cost. If the property is merchandise that you buy to sell again, the consumption tax is part of the cost of the merchandise. If the property can be depreciated, add the consumption tax to the basis to compute depreciation. To get information about the basis of the property, see Publication 551. Do not deduct the state and local consumption tax that you collect and remit to the state or local government. Do not include these taxes in gross income or total sales revenue.

Taxes on gasoline, diesel, and other fuels that you use in your business are usually included as part of your fuel cost. Do not deduct these taxes separately. You may be able to get a credit or refund for the federal excise tax you paid on fuel used for certain purposes. For more information, see Publication 510.

Generally, the place where you file your tax return is the location of your business, regardless of where your family lives. The place where you file your tax return includes the entire city or area where your business is located. See Publication 463 for more information. Below is a brief discussion of the expenses you may deduct.
You can deduct tickets for these types of vehicles as well as other types of vehicles when traveling between the airport or station and the hotel, or between the hotel and your home office.
You can deduct the cost of shipping your luggage and samples or display materials between your regular and temporary work locations.
You can deduct the tip you paid yourself from any of the expenses on this list.

To qualify under the exclusive use standard, you must use a specific area of your home that is dedicated to your business. The area used for business purposes can be a room or a distinct area that is clearly separated. The area does not have to be always separated by a wall. You do not meet the requirements of the exclusive use standard if you use an area that is unclear for both business and personal purposes.

To qualify under the use test standard, you must use a specific area of the home for business purposes on a regular basis. You do not meet this use test standard if the business use of the area is only occasional or random, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose.

Generally, you must capitalize your costs to acquire or produce tangible personal property or real property used in your business or trade, such as buildings, equipment, or furniture. However, if you elect to use the minimum safe harbor election for tangible personal property, you may deduct the minimum safe harbor amount paid to acquire or produce tangible personal property if those amounts are deducted for financial accounting purposes or to maintain books and records. If you have a proper financial statement, you may use the minimum safe harbor election to deduct the amount paid for tangible personal property up to $5,000 per item or invoice. If you do not have a proper financial statement, you may use the minimum safe harbor election to deduct the amount paid for tangible personal property up to $2,500 per item or invoice. The amounts eligible under the minimum safe harbor election should be included as other expenses in Schedule C, Part V.
To learn more about making this choice and the requirements for using the minimum safe harbor rule for tangible property, see Tangible Property (English).

You may also deduct the following expenses. Advertising. Bank fees. Contributions to business organizations. Educational expenses. Expenses related to damage. Interview allowance. License and regulatory fees. Relocation of machinery. Support services for finding new employment for employees. Fines and penalties you must pay for late or non-performance of contracts. Repairs and maintenance of real or personal property. Reimbursement of income. Supplies and materials. Public utilities.

You can't deduct the following as business expenses. Bribery and kickbacks. Charitable contributions. Cost or loss from demolition. Dues of business, social, athletic, lunch, sports, air, and hotel clubs. Entertainment expenses. Improvement expenses of real or personal property. Improvement expenses are the amounts paid for improvements to property, restoration of property, or alteration of property to fit a new or different use. Lobbying expenses. Fines and penalties you must pay to a government or other authority because of your own violation of the law. Personal, living, and family expenses. Political contributions. Payments or settlements related to harassment or sexual abuse if the payment or settlement is made under a nondisclosure agreement. You also can't deduct lawyer fees related to such payments or settlements.

If you have a bad debt, you have a bad debt. There are two types of bad debts — business bad debts and nonbusiness bad debts. Business bad debts are generally debts from your business or commercial activities. You can deduct business bad debts as a business expense on your business tax return.

A business-related debt is a debt whose primary reason for being incurred is a business motive. Business bad debts are mainly the result of trade credit sales to customers. Business bad debts may also be the result of loans to suppliers, customers, employees, or distributors. Goods and services that customers have not paid for are presented in your books as accounts receivable or trade receivables. If you are unable to collect any part of these accounts receivable or trade receivables, the uncollectible part is business bad debts. You can deduct business bad debts for these accounts receivable and trade receivables only when the debt is included in your gross income for the tax year for which you are deducting the bad debts or for a prior year.

If you claim a deduction for a bad debt on your income tax return and later recover (collect) all or part of the debt, you may have to include all or part of the recovery as income. The amount you include is limited to the amount you actually claimed as a deduction. However, you can exclude the amount claimed without reducing your tax. Report the recovery as “Other income” on your return or the appropriate business schedule. See Recoveries in Publication 525 for more information.

All other nonbusiness bad debts are nonbusiness bad debts and are deducted as short-term capital losses on Form 8949 and Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information about nonbusiness bad debts, see section 166 and its regulations.

If you use the accrual method of accounting, you generally report income when you earn it. You can deduct bad debts for a receivable that you can't collect if you've included the uncollectible amount in income.
If you use the cash method, you generally report income when you receive a payment. You can't deduct bad debts for unpaid debts and can't recover if you never included those amounts in income.

If a political party (or other organization that accepts contributions or spends money to influence elections) owes you money and the debt becomes worthless, you can only claim a bad debt deduction if all of the following requirements are met. 1. You use an accrual method of accounting. 2. The debt arose from the sale of goods or services in the ordinary course of your business. 3. More than 30% of your receivables accumulated during the year of sale are from sales to political parties. 4. You have made a good faith effort to collect the debt.
You cannot claim a bad debt deduction for a loan you have made to a company if, on the facts and circumstances, the loan is actually a contribution to capital.

If you guarantee a debt that subsequently becomes worthless, the debt may qualify as business bad debt if all of the following requirements are met. You guaranteed in the course of your business transaction or business. You have a legal obligation to pay the debt. You made the guarantee before the debt became worthless. You meet this requirement if you reasonably expect that you will not have to pay the debt without receiving full repayment from the borrower. You received reasonable consideration for making the guarantee. You meet this requirement if you make the guarantee in the course of business or for business-related purposes.

When you pay off the loan that you are guaranteeing, you may have the right to step in for the lender. The amount owed thereafter is yours. If you have this right, or some other right to demand payment from the borrower, you cannot claim bad debt deduction until these rights become partially or completely worthless.
If two or more debtors owe you money together, your inability to collect money from one debtor does not allow you to deduct an equivalent amount as a bad debt.
If a secured or collateralized asset is sold for less than the debt, the outstanding balance, which cannot be recovered from the debt, is a bad debt.

If you receive property to settle part of a debt, reduce the debt by the FMV of the property, it becomes the cost basis of the property. You can deduct the remaining debt as a bad debt if and when it becomes worthless. If you later sell the property for a price higher than its original cost, any profit from the sale is due to the property's appreciation. It is not the recovery of a bad debt. For information about selling property, see Publication 544.

Local business transportation expenses do not include expenses incurred when traveling away from home overnight for business. These expenses are deducted as travel expenses and discussed in the Travel and Meals section below. However, if you use your car when traveling away from home overnight, please use the rules in this section to calculate your car expense deduction. Typically, the location you choose to file your taxes is your regular business location, regardless of where your family lives. The location you choose to file your taxes includes the entire city or area in general where your business or agency is headquartered.

In addition to using the standard mileage rate for each mile driven, you can deduct any parking fees and tolls related to your business. (The fees you pay to park at your workplace are not deductible as business travel expenses.)

If the property you buy to use in your business is expected to last more than 1 year, you usually can't deduct the full cost as a business expense in the year you buy the property. You must spread the cost over more than 1 tax year and deduct a part of the cost each year on Schedule C. This method of deducting the cost of business property is called depreciation. Here is a brief overview. You will find more information about depreciation in Publication 946.

You can depreciate property if it meets all of the following requirements. The property must be owned by you. The property must be used in your business or held for the production of income. You can never depreciate inventory (explained in Chapter 2) because it is not held for use in your business. The property must have a significant remaining useful life after the year it is placed in service. The property must be of a determinable useful life, meaning the property is subject to wear and tear, obsolescence, exhaustion, or loss of value due to natural causes. You can never depreciate land because land is not subject to wear and tear, obsolescence, or exhaustion. The property must not be excluded property. This includes property placed in service and disposed of in the same year.

Generally, you don't deduct repair or maintenance expenses if those expenses don't improve your property. Instead, you deduct those amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvement expenses are amounts paid for improvements to your property, restoration of your property, or work that makes your property suitable for a new or different use.

You may elect to treat certain repairs or replacements in your business or trade as improvements that must be depreciated. This election may be made if you treat the amount as a long-term investment expense on your books and records that you regularly use to compute your income and expenses.

The method of depreciation for most investment and business property placed in service after 1986 is called the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS). MACRS is discussed in detail in Publication 946.

You can elect to deduct a limited amount for the cost of a property placed in service during the tax year you place the property in service. This deduction is called the Section 179 deduction. The maximum amount you can elect to deduct in 2024 is generally $1.220.000 (higher limits apply to certain assets). This limit is generally reduced by the amount by which the cost of the property placed in service in the tax year exceeds $3.050.000. The total amount of depreciation (including the Section 179 deduction) that you can take for a passenger automobile used in your business placed in service for the first time in 2024 is $12.400 ($20.400 if you take the special depreciation allowance for eligible passenger automobiles placed in service in 2024). Special rules apply to trucks and vans. For more information, see Publication 946. This publication explains which assets are eligible for the deduction, what limits apply to the deduction, and when and how to claim the deduction. Your election under Section 179 for the cost of an SUV and certain other vehicles is limited to $30.500. For more information, see Publication 530 or Publication 946.

Use Form 4562, Depreciation of Property, Plant and Equipment, and Depreciation of Intangible Property, if you claim any of the following. Depreciation of property placed in service during the tax year. A deduction under section 179. Depreciation of any listed property (whether or not placed in service during the tax year).
You cannot deduct your own salary or any withdrawal from your business for personal purposes. As a sole proprietorship, you are not an employee of your business.

There are a number of ways you can compensate your employees listed below. Bonuses. Commissions. Educational expenses. Fringe benefits (discussed in the next section). Loans or advances that you do not expect your employees to repay if they are for personal services that have actually been performed. Property you transfer to an employee as a compensation for services. Reimbursements for employee business expenses. Sick pay. Vacation pay.

Generally, you can deduct the cost of any fringe benefits you provide to employees on Form 1040, Schedule C, regardless of whether the cost is of a personal nature. For example, if you allow employees to use a car or other property that you rent, deduct the rental cost as a rental expense. If you own property, deduct the depreciation of the property as a section 179 deduction or as a deduction for depreciation. You can deduct all or part of the fringe benefits you provide to employees. For more information about fringe benefits and deductions for fringe benefits, see Publication 15-B.

Generally, you can deduct the cost of insurance you pay for the following types of business-related insurance. 1. Fire, theft, flood, or similar insurance. 2. Credit insurance including losses from bad business debt. 3. Health and medical insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Occupational risk insurance including your personal liability for workplace accidents resulting in injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. Workers' compensation insurance for any claims for bodily injury or disease related to the work that your employees in your business must bear, regardless of the mistake that led to the accident. 7. Contributions to state unemployment insurance funds are deductible as a tax if they are considered a tax by state law. 8. Comprehensive insurance pays for general business expenses that you incur during a long period of disability due to injury or illness. 9. Automobile and other vehicle insurance for vehicles used in your business before liability, damage, and other losses. If you use a vehicle partly for personal use, please deduct only the corresponding portion of the cost of insurance for the use of the vehicle for business purposes. If you use a standard mileage rate to calculate your automobile expenses, you cannot deduct any automobile insurance cost. 10. Life insurance for employees if you are not directly or indirectly the beneficiary under the contract. 11. Business interruption insurance pays for lost profits if your business must stop operating due to fire or other cause.

You cannot deduct insurance premiums for the following types of insurance. 1. Self-insurance reserve. You cannot deduct the amount credited to a reserve established for self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain business insurance for some business risks. However, your actual losses may be deducted. For more information, see Publication 547. 2. Income loss. You cannot deduct insurance premiums for a contract to pay for income lost by you due to sickness or injury. However, see section 8 in the list above. 3. Certain life and annuity insurance. 1. For contracts issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct insurance premiums on a life insurance contract on your own life or on the life of an employee or any person having a financial interest in your business if you are directly or indirectly the beneficiary of the contract. You may be a beneficiary of the contract if the owner of the contract has a liability to repay a loan to you from the proceeds of the contract. A person having a financial interest in your business is one who is the owner or co-owner of the business or has loaned the business money. 2. For contracts issued after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct insurance premiums on any life insurance, life and annuity, or annuity insurance contract if you are directly or indirectly the beneficiary. The denial applies regardless of the beneficiary of the contract. 4. Loan guarantee insurance. If you sign a life insurance contract on your own life or on the life of another person having a financial interest in your business to receive or guarantee a business loan, you cannot deduct the insurance premiums as a business expense. You also cannot deduct the insurance premiums as interest on business loans or as costs of business loans. In the event of death, the proceeds from the contract are not taxed as income even if they are used to pay off a debt.
You can deduct the amount you paid for health and dental insurance, as well as long-term care insurance that meets the requirements for yourself and your family.

View Form 8962 and the instructions for the form and use Publication 974 if the health insurance program that is established, or is considered to be established, in your business is received through the Health Insurance Marketplace, and you are requesting a tax credit for premiums.

You cannot deduct in advance any expenses paid in advance, even if paid in advance. This rule applies to any expense that is paid in advance sufficiently early to, in substance, create an asset with a substantially longer useful life than the current tax year.

Some taxpayers are required to limit their business interest deduction. See the Instructions for Form 8990 to determine if you are required to limit your business interest deduction, who must file Form 8990, and how some businesses may elect not to limit their business interest deduction. You cannot deduct on Schedule C the interest you paid on personal loans. If the loan is partly for business and partly for personal use, you must apportion the interest between the two parts.

Additional items to consider are displayed below. How to allocate interest between personal and business purposes. Business interest limits. Timing of interest deduction. Rules for loans with lower interest rates than market rates. (This is usually a non-interest bearing loan or a loan with a lower interest rate than the current federal rate.)

Legal and professional service expenses, such as fees paid to an accountant, are necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business that are deducted on Schedule C. However, you generally cannot deduct legal expenses for the purchase of business assets. Add these expenses to the original cost of the asset. If the expense includes payments for personal work (such as a will), you can only deduct the portion of the expense that is related to your business.

For tax purposes, a non-U.S. citizen is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen. Non-U.S. citizens are classified as non-resident aliens and resident aliens. This publication will help you determine your status and provide the necessary information for you to file a U.S. tax return. Non-resident aliens generally are taxed on worldwide income, just like U.S. citizens. Resident aliens generally are taxed on worldwide income, but they may be exempt from U.S. income tax on some income, such as income from U.S. sources, if they meet certain requirements.

Foreign nationals who are temporary residents (and some foreign nationals who are permanent residents) from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require that a foreign national be a resident of the treaty country for the year in which the benefits are claimed. However, in the case of some students, interns, teachers, or researchers, some treaties only require that a foreign national be a resident of the treaty country immediately prior to coming to the United States.

You can access the tax treaty tables by visiting IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English). You can access the text of the U.S. income tax treaties, Tax and Information Exchange Agreements (TIEAs) recently signed, and technical explanations of the Treasury Department's tax conventions also available when widely circulated and in the United States. The typical Tax Treaty Conference is at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax (English). Note that treaty and TIEA documents are posted on this website after they are signed and before they are ratified and effective. The full text of the personal income tax conventions is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z (English). For more information about tax treaties, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties (English). Typically, you can arrange to have your withholding tax on salary and other qualified income reduced or eliminated under a tax treaty. See Income Tax Treaty Benefits in Chapter 8.

Foreign tax credit is the total foreign tax paid on income that is subject to the treaty tax. Foreign tax credit includes dividends from sources in the United States that are taxed at the treaty rate of no more than 15%. Foreign tax credit is the total foreign tax paid on income that is not subject to the treaty tax. To determine tax on income that is taxed at a lower treaty rate, calculate tax on each income separately at the reduced treaty rate applicable to that income. To determine tax on income that is not subject to the treaty tax, calculate tax at a fixed rate of 30% or a progressive rate, depending on whether the income is actually related to a trade or business in the United States. Tax liability is the total of treaty tax and non-treaty tax, not to exceed the tax liability as if the treaty tax were not in effect.

The following sections briefly explain the treaty-based exemptions available for personal service income, remittances, scholarships, fellowship income, and capital gains income. The requirements for exemption vary by treaty. To learn more about the treaty-specific requirements, download the full text of most U.S. tax treaties at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z (English). Technical explanations of many of these treaties are also available at that website. See also Publication 901 (English). Treaty-based benefits also include income such as dividends, interest, rents, royalties, pensions, and annuities. These types of income may be exempt from U.S. income tax or may be taxed at a lower rate. To learn more, see Publication 901 (English) or the current tax treaty.

According to most income tax treaties, non-resident aliens from treaty countries and dual-status aliens who are resident in the treaty country (see Chapter 1) are temporarily present in the United States to perform services may be eligible for a tax exemption on some or all of their personal services income if they meet the requirements of the applicable treaty provision.
Some tax treaties have other requirements, such as a maximum period of residence. For more information, see Publication 901 (English).

Some tax treaties on personal income have a 'independent contractor' provision that allows residents of the treaty country to be exempt from U.S. income tax on income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed if they spend a certain number of days in the U.S. and do not have a permanent base of operations in the U.S.

According to many tax treaties, a foreign teacher or professor who is temporarily resident in the United States for the primary purpose of teaching at a college or other educational institution recognized by the United States is not subject to United States income tax on teaching income for the first 2 or 3 years after he or she arrives in the United States. Many treaties also allow tax exemption for research participation. In general, a teacher or professor must be in the United States for the primary purpose of teaching, lecturing, advising, or participating in research. A significant portion of the person's time must be devoted to these duties. The ordinary duties of a teacher or professor include not only the regular classroom work related to the teaching schedule, examinations, and other activities involving students, but also the presentation of ideas in informal workshops or other groups and in joint efforts in the laboratory. If you entered the United States as a temporary resident alien but are now a permanent resident alien, treaty-based tax exemption may still apply. See Foreign Students, Trainees, Interns, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers Becoming Permanent Residents in Foreign Students, Trainees, Interns, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers Becoming Permanent Residents.

All treaties provide for tax-free treatment of a certain class of foreign government employees. However, there are differences among the treaties as to who is eligible for this benefit. Under many treaties, foreign nationals who are U.S. residents are not eligible. Under most treaties, foreign nationals who are not nationals or subjects of a foreign country are not eligible. Foreign government employees should carefully read the treaty applicable to them to determine whether they are eligible for the benefit. Chapter 10 of this publication contains information on foreign government employees.

Under certain tax treaties, students, apprentices, and interns are exempt from tax on income received from abroad for study and maintenance of a standard of living. In addition, under certain treaties, scholarships and research grants and certain limited compensation received by students, apprentices, and interns may be exempt from tax. If you entered the United States as a nonresident alien but are now a resident alien, treaty-based exemption may still apply. See Nonresident Aliens becoming Resident Aliens in the Nonresident Aliens section.
Most treaties allow for the exemption of capital gains from the sale or exchange of personal property. Capital gains from the sale or exchange of real property in the United States may be taxable.

Under the Canada-Germany Social Security Treaty, if a U.S. resident receives social security benefits from Canada or Germany, those benefits will be treated for U.S. income tax purposes as if they were received under the U.S. Social Security Act. If you receive social security benefits from Canada or Germany, including in line 1 of the Social Security Benefits Schedule in the Social Security Instructions for Form 1040 to determine the amount of income subject to tax on line 6b of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, line 1. You do not need to file Form 8833 for these benefits.

Generally, you must be a foreign student, trainee, intern, teacher, professor, or researcher to claim treaty exemption for foreign-source income for study and maintenance of living in the United States, scholarships, fellowship grants, and research and other personal service income. After you become a U.S. resident for tax purposes, you may no longer claim this treaty exemption. However, if you entered the United States as a temporary resident but are now a U.S. resident for tax purposes, treaty exemption may continue to apply if the treaty exemption provision (explained above) is an exception and you do not meet the treaty exemption requirements (including any treaty exemption time limits, explained below). This is true even if you were a temporary resident who elected to file a U.S. tax return as explained in Chapter 1. If you qualify under the treaty exemption exception provision, you can avoid withholding on this income by providing the payor with a Form W-9 along with the required Form W-9 instructions.

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because the income will be exempt from U.S. income tax under a treaty. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other information return, you should report the income on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, the amount reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount that the treaty-based foreign income exemption is required on Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter “Exempt income (Thu nhập được miễn thuế),” the name of the treaty country, and the treaty provision that allows the income to be exempt.

If you claim treaty benefits that override or modify any provision of the Internal Revenue Code and by claiming these benefits, your tax will be or may be reduced, you must attach Form 8833, fully completed, to your tax return. See the Exceptions below to determine when you do not have to file Form 8833.

You do not need to file Form 8833 to report any of the following situations. 1. You claim a treaty reduction on interest, dividends, rents, royalties, or other FDAP income, which is generally taxed at a 30% rate. 2. You claim a treaty reduction or adjustment on income from personal services performed for others, pensions, annuities, social security, or other public retirement income, or on income of artists, athletes, students, interns, or teachers. This includes scholarships and research grants that are taxable. 3. You claim a treaty reduction or adjustment on social security income, or on income from a foreign trust or estate. 4. You are a partner in a partnership, or a beneficiary of a foreign trust or estate, and the partnership, trust, or estate files the necessary information on the tax return. 5. The total amount of required disclosure payments or income is less than $10,000. 6. You are claiming treaty benefits for payments or income: 1. That have been reported to you on Form 1042-S; and 2. That have been received by you: 1. As a related person of a U.S. company that has filed within the meaning of Section 6038A (related to the information reporting on Form 5472 filed by the U.S. company that is at least 25% owned by a foreign person), or 2. As a beneficiary of a U.S. financial institution or qualified intermediary or a direct partner, beneficiary, or owner of a foreign partnership or foreign trust that is a withholding agent, from the U.S. financial institution, qualified intermediary, or foreign partnership or foreign trust. The exception described in (6) above does not apply to any payments or income that are required to be disclosed on the tax return based on a treaty, as directed by Form 8833.

International organization employees may be exempt from U.S. income tax under a provision (if any) in the international organization's establishing treaty or by satisfying the requirements to be exempt from that income tax under U.S. tax law. An “international organization” is an organization designated by the President of the United States by Executive Order as eligible for the privileges, immunities, and exemptions provided in the Internal Revenue Code. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to income from official services performed for a foreign government or international organization. Other income from U.S. sources of qualified individuals may be subject to full U.S. income tax or may be eligible for the tax treaty benefits under the current tax treaty. The treatment of this type of income (interest, dividends, etc.) is discussed in the preceding section of this publication.

Foreign government employees are not eligible for tax exemption under the terms of a Vienna Convention, a bilateral consular agreement, or a tax treaty if they meet the requirements to be exempt from U.S. income tax on foreign government salary. Exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current foreign government employees and does not apply to former employees. Pension income that former foreign government employees receive while living in the United States is not exempt from U.S. income tax as discussed here. See Publication 1779 (English) and Publication 15-A (English). Salary that is not exempt from U.S. income tax under tax law if you are hired by a “controlled commercial organization” or your services are primarily related to the commercial activities of the foreign government (within or outside the United States). A Foreign Service Certificate (if any) is the easiest way to confirm that you perform services similar to those performed by Foreign Service employees and are eligible for the same tax-free treatment but is not required to qualify for tax-free treatment under US tax law. There are many international organization agreements that have a provision for U.S. income tax exemption for your salary. If you are working for an international organization in the U.S., first determine whether the agreement establishing the international organization where you are working has such a provision and whether you meet the requirements of that provision. These provisions usually will not exempt from U.S. income tax the salary of U.S. citizens and residents who are foreign nationals.

Before leaving the United States, all non-U.S. citizens (except those non-U.S. citizens listed in Non-U.S. Citizens Not Required to File a Return or Report on Form 1040-C or 2063) must file a Certificate of Compliance. This document is also commonly referred to as a Form 1040-C or 2063 Return of Income as part of the tax return you must file before leaving. You will receive a Form 1040-C or 2063 Return of Income after filing Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are discussed in this chapter. To determine whether you need a Form 1040-C or 2063 Return of Income, first read Non-U.S. Citizens Not Required to File a Return or Report on Form 1040-C or 2063, in the next section. If you do not fall into one of the categories discussed there, you must file a Form 1040-C or 2063 Return of Income.
