If you are a non-U.S. citizen of type (1) or (2) above, you must have a departure or exit permit. This is still true even if your income is exempt from U.S. income tax under a tax treaty, consular agreement, or international agreement.

Foreign students, trainees in the industrial sector and exchange visitors, including spouses and children, who enter the United States on F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, or Q visas and who do not receive any income from sources in the United States while in the United States under those visas other than: Allowances to cover expenses related to the study or training in the United States, such as travel, maintenance, and tuition; Value of any services or food and lodging related to the study or training; Income from authorized employment by USCIS; or Income from interest on actual non-commercial deposits in the United States. See Interest Income in Chapter 3.

Foreign students, including spouses and children, who are admitted under the M-1 or M-2 visa categories and who do not receive any income from sources in the United States while in the United States under these visa categories other than income from authorized employment by USCIS, or income from actual interest on non-communicated funds not related to any commercial or business activity in the United States. See Interest Income in Chapter 3.

Some other non-U.S. persons who are temporarily present in the United States do not receive taxable income in the tax year for which the return is being filed until the day and including the day of departure or in the tax year before. If the IRS has reason to believe that the non-U.S. person has received taxable income and the income tax liability may be affected when they leave, the IRS may require the non-U.S. person to apply for a departure or departure permission. Non-U.S. persons in this category: 1. Military trainees who are non-U.S. persons who enter the United States for training under the sponsorship of the Department of Defense and who depart the United States under official military orders; 2. Business visitors who are non-U.S. persons who enter the United States under a B-1 visa or both B-1 and B-2 visas and who do not stay in the United States or its territories more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. Business visitors who are non-U.S. persons who enter the United States under a B-2 visa; 4. Non-U.S. persons who transit through the United States or any of its territories under a C-1 visa or under a contract, such as a bond, between a carrier and the Attorney General; and 5. Non-U.S. persons who enter the United States by means of a border crossing card or who are not required to present a passport, visa, and border crossing card, if they are: 1. Visitors for pleasure, 2. Business visitors who do not stay in the United States or its territories more than 90 days in the tax year or 3. Non-U.S. persons who transit through the United States or any of its territories.
A Canadian or Mexican resident alien is a non-U.S. citizen who regularly travels between that country and the United States to seek employment and whose earnings are subject to U.S. withholding tax.

If you are not in one of the categories listed in Foreign Nationals Not Required to Obtain a Landing or Exit Permit, you must obtain a Landing or Exit Permit. To obtain a permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (as applicable) with the TAC office where you reside before you leave the United States. See Forms to File in the following section. You must also file all taxes due on Form 1040-C and any taxes due in prior years. See Pay Taxes and File Returns in the following section.

To obtain a compliance certificate, you must visit the TAC office at least 2 weeks before you leave the United States and file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C and any other required tax returns. The certificate is issued no more than 30 days before you leave. If you and your spouse are both foreign nationals and both leaving the United States, both of you must visit the TAC office. Please note that all TAC offices operate on an appointment basis. You can call 844-545-5640 between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. local time to schedule an appointment. For more information about your local TAC office, visit IRS.gov/TAC.

The process of applying for a departure or departure permit will be faster if you bring to the IRS office the documents and papers related to income and time of residence in the United States. Bring the following documents if applicable. 1. Passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your federal income tax returns filed in the 2 years prior to your departure. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring copies of your federal income tax returns for that period. 3. Receipts for taxes paid on these returns. 4. Bank statements, canceled checks and other documents that show deductions, business expenses and dependents claimed on your returns. 5. W-2 forms from each employer showing wages earned and taxes withheld from January 1 of the current year through the date of departure if you are an employee. If you are self-employed, you must bring copies of your income and expense statements through the date you plan to depart. 6. Evidence of any estimated tax payments made in the previous year and this year. 7. Documents showing any capital gains or losses from the sale of personal and/or real property, including capital assets and merchandise. 8. Documents relating to any scholarships or fellowship grants, including the following: 1. Verification of the grantor, source and purpose of the grant. 2. Copies of the application and approval of the grant. 3. Statement of amounts paid and your obligations in connection with the grant. 4. List of any previous grants. 9. Documents showing that you are eligible for any treaty-based special tax benefits. 10. Evidence of the date you are leaving the United States, such as a plane ticket. 11. Evidence of your ITIN, such as a Social Security card or a CP 565 notice from the IRS showing your ITIN.

If you must apply for a departure permit or exit permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a “certificate of compliance” section. When the certificate of compliance is signed by the Field Assistance Area Director, the certificate confirms that your U.S. tax obligations have been met as reported on the information available. A copy of Form 1040-C of the signed certificate or a separate copy of Form 2063 is the departure or exit permit.

Foreign nationals who are either in one of the two categories above and have not filed a tax return or have paid tax on their income in any tax year are required to file and pay tax on their income before they are granted a departure or exit permit on Form 2063. A departure or exit permit separate from Form 2063 may be used for all exits in the current year. However, IRS may revoke the departure or exit permit for any subsequent exit if they determine that the tax on income is affected by the subsequent exit.

If you must apply for a departure or departure permit and are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or reasonably expected to be received in the tax year up to and including the day of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and the tax must be paid. When you file any tax due by the due date shown on Form 1040-C and you file all returns and pay all taxes for prior years, you will be issued a departure or departure permit. However, IRS may permit you to pay the tax by a bond in certain years. See Bonded payment in the following section. The departure or departure permit granted under the conditions in this section is only for the specific departure for which the permit is issued.

If you give the IRS information showing that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure does not interfere with the collection of your income tax, you may be able to get a departure or departure permit by filing Form 1040-C without paying the tax shown on it. However, you must file all the income tax returns and pay all the tax shown on the return due on or before the date of your departure. Form 1040-C must include all income received and reasonably expected to be received during the year of departure. A departure or departure permit is issued and Form 1040 may be used for all future departures during the current year. However, the IRS may revoke the departure or departure permit for any subsequent departure if it appears that the collection of your income tax is being impeded.

You must pay the entire tax shown as due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, except when the bond is provided or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not affect tax collection. You also must pay taxes due in prior years. If the tax on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, you are not required to pay the tax at the time of filing. However, the IRS cannot refund the tax at the time of departure. If you are due a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR by the end of the tax year.

You usually have to pay the tax due on Form 1040-C when you file this form. However, if you have paid all of your tax due in previous years, you may give a bond in lieu of paying the tax due on Form 1040-C or on your return for the previous year if the filing deadline for that return has not yet passed. The bond must be in the amount of the tax due plus interest to the date of payment as required by IRS. You can get information about the bond and the security from the TAC office.

The 1040-C is not a U.S. income tax return. If a tax return is not required by law, then the return must be filed even if the 1040-C has been filed. Chapter 5 and Chapter 7 discuss filing a U.S. income tax return. Any taxes paid with the 1040-C must be considered a credit against your annual U.S. income tax liability on your annual U.S. income tax return.
Tax support services for non-resident taxpayers are available in the U.S. and some overseas locations.

After you receive all your wage and income statements (W-2s, W-2Gs, 1099-Rs, 1099-Ms, 1099-NEs, etc.); unemployment compensation statements (paper or electronic format) or other government payment statements (1099-Gs); and interest, dividend, and pension statements from banks and investment companies (1099s), you have several options to prepare and file your taxes. You can prepare your own tax return. see if you qualify for free tax preparation or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return for you.

You will need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete forms that are mobile-friendly and require a signature. You will have the option to submit the form online or download a copy to mail in. You will need scanned copies of your documents to support your filing. Visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms (English) for more information.

Access IRS.gov/Account to securely access your federal tax account information. View the amount you owe and analyze by tax year. See details of your payment plan or enroll in a new payment plan. Make payments, view a 5-year payment history, and all pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax records, including important data from your most recent tax return, your payment impact amount, and your transcript. View electronic copies of selected IRS notices. Approve or reject tax preparer authorization requests. Update your address or manage your preferred ways of communication.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can get your records, review your most recently filed tax return, and get your adjusted gross income. Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/Account.

The safest and easiest way to receive your tax refund is to e-file and choose direct deposit, which will electronically deposit your refund directly into your financial account. Direct deposit also helps prevent lost, stolen, destroyed, or failed to be returned checks to the IRS. Of the 10 taxpayers who file, 8 choose direct deposit to receive their refunds. If you don't have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out where to find a bank or credit union that can help you open an account online.

The IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers by email, phone, text message (including short codes) or social media to request personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center web page, to learn about identity theft and protecting taxpayer data for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If you are a victim of identity theft, you can learn what steps you should take. Get an IP PIN. An IP PIN is a six-digit number that is issued to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of their Social Security number in tax fraud. When you have an IP PIN, it will prevent someone else from filing a tax return with your SSN. To learn more, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Electronic assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about how to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or estimated tax bill directly from your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card, or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at a participating retail location. Same-day wire transfer: You can make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about availability, cost, and timing.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. File an Online Payment Agreement Application (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill in monthly installments if you currently can't pay your tax bill in full. After you complete the online process, you will be notified immediately to let you know whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Offer in Compromise (OIC) Tool (English) to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the total amount you owe. For more information about the OIC program, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.
Access IRS.gov/Notices to find more information about responding to an IRS notice or letter.

You can use the Document Upload Tool to electronically respond to certain IRS notices and letters by securely uploading the required documents online through IRS.gov. To learn more, visit IRS.gov/DUT (English).

You can use the LEP Table (Form 1040), Change of Language Preferences Request, to state your preference for receiving notifications, letters, or other written communications from IRS in a language other than English. You may not immediately receive written communications in the requested language. IRS's commitment to LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year schedule that is expected to begin providing translations in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including notices and letters, in English until they are translated into your preferred language.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, provides administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are Your Voice at the IRS.

Before you start, you should determine whether, for tax purposes, you are a non-resident temporary visitor or a non-resident permanent resident. If you are both a temporary visitor and a permanent resident in the same year, you are a dual resident. See Non-resident dual residents in the section later. See also Non-resident spouse/partner considered a permanent resident and other special situations explained in the section later in this chapter.
If you are a non-U.S. citizen, you will be considered a non-resident alien, unless you meet one of the two tests described in the Non-Resident Aliens section below.

You are a non-U.S. resident for U.S. tax purposes if you meet the green card test or the substantial presence test for 2024 (from January 1 to December 31). Even if you do not meet either of these tests, you may still be considered a U.S. resident for part of the year. See Part-year resident in the Foreign dual-status individuals section, later.

You are a resident alien for tax purposes if you are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time during 2023. (However, see Foreign persons with dual status in the section below.) This is called the green card test. You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time if you are granted, under immigration law, the right to permanently reside in the United States as an immigrant. You will generally have this status if the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) (or a predecessor organization of the agency) has issued you Form I-551, Permanent Resident Card, also known as a green card. You will continue to have this status, unless it is revoked or is determined administratively or judicially to have been abandoned.

Residency status is considered to have been revoked if the US government issues a final administrative or judicial order requiring exclusion or deportation. A final judicial order is an order that you cannot appeal to a higher court.

When filing by mail, you must send by registered mail, request a return receipt (or equivalent document outside the US) and keep a copy and proof that the document has been sent and received. Until you have proof that the letter has been received, you are still a foreign resident for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of the green card as it is over 10 years old or you have not been present in the US for a period of time. If USCIS or a US consular officer makes this determination, your residency status will be considered to have been abandoned when the final administrative order requiring abandonment is issued. If you have the right to appeal to a federal court of competent jurisdiction, you are required to have a final judicial order. Under US immigration law, a legal permanent resident must file tax returns as a resident and failure to do so may be considered as having abandoned the status and may result in loss of legal permanent resident status. Long-term residents (LTR) who are no longer legal permanent residents may be subject to special reporting and tax requirements. SeeTax abandonment of citizenship in Chapter 4.

You will be a resident for tax purposes if you meet the substantial presence test for 2023. To meet this test, you must be present in the United States for at least: 1. 31 days during 2024; and 2. 183 days during the 3-year period 2024, 2023, and 2022, which includes: 1. All of the days you are present during 2024, and 2. 1/3 of the days you are present during 2023, and 3. 1/6 of the days you are present during 2022.

Do not count the days you work in the United States from your residence in Canada or Mexico if you work regularly from Canada or Mexico. You are considered to work regularly if you work in the United States on 75% (0.75) or more of the working days in the work year. For this purpose, “work” means going to work and returning to your residence within a 24-hour period. “Working day” is the days you work in the United States or Canada or Mexico. “Work year” means the period beginning on the first day of the current year that you are present in the United States to work and ending on the last day of the current year that you are present in the United States to work. If your work requires you to be present in the United States only seasonally or on a cycle, your work year will begin on the first day of the season or cycle that you are present in the United States to work and end on the last day of the season or cycle that you are present in the United States to work. You may have more than one work year in a year and your work year may begin in one year and end in the following year.

When determining the number of days you were present in the United States, you can only exclude days you competed in a sporting event. You cannot exclude days you were present in the United States to train for the event, perform promotional activities or other activities related to the event or travel between events. If you qualify for the exclusion of days present as a professional athlete, you must file Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 in the next section.
Tax and finance

Not counting days you spend in the U.S. for less than 24 hours and layovers between two places outside the U.S. You are considered a layover if you engage in activities related to completing your move to the foreign destination. For example, if you move between airports in the U.S. to change planes on your way to the foreign destination, you are considered a layover. However, you will not be considered a layover if you attend a business meeting while in the U.S. This still applies even if the meeting is held at the airport.

Not counting the days you are temporarily present in the United States as a regular crew member of a foreign ship (vessel or vessel) engaged in the carriage of cargo between the United States and foreign countries or territories. However, this exception does not apply if you engage in any business or commercial activity in the United States during those days.

Not counting the days you intend to leave but cannot leave the United States because of health conditions or a problem that arises while you are in the United States. Whether you intend to leave the United States on a specific day or not is determined by the facts and circumstances. For example, you may intend to leave if the purpose of your visit to the United States can be completed within a period of time that is too short to meet the requirement of substantial presence test. However, if you need a long period of time to complete your purpose of visit and that period of time will meet the requirement of substantial presence test, you will not be able to establish an intention to leave the United States before the end of that long period. In the case of an individual who is determined to be mentally incapacitated, evidence of an intention to leave the United States may be established by analyzing the individual's behavior before the individual is determined to be mentally incapacitated. If you are eligible for exclusion of days present in the United States due to health conditions, you must file Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 in the back of this publication. You cannot exclude any days present in the United States in the following cases. Initially you are prevented from leaving, but you can leave later. However, you remain in the United States after a reasonable period of time to arrange for your departure. You return to the United States to receive treatment for a health condition that arose during your previous stay. The condition existed before you entered the United States and you knew about the problem. Whether you need to receive treatment for the problem when you enter the United States is not important.

A person who is related to a foreign government is a person (or a close family member of the person) who is temporarily present in the United States: As a full-time employee of an international organization, For diplomatic or consular reasons (not a visa that permits lawful permanent residence) that the Secretary of the Treasury determines to be full-time diplomatic or consular representation.

If you are present in the United States as an A-3 or G-5 visa holder as a personal employee, servant, or domestic help for a foreign government or an employee of an international organization, you will not be considered a foreign government employee and must count all days you are present in the United States for the purpose of the substantial presence test.

Even if you meet the substantial presence test, you may be considered a nonresident alien if you: Are present in the United States for 183 days or less during the tax year, Maintain a foreign country as your tax home for the tax year, and Have a closer connection to a foreign country than to the United States during the tax year (except if you have a closer connection to two foreign countries, discussed in the next section).

You can show that you have a closer connection to two foreign countries (but not more than two) if you satisfy all of the following conditions. You have maintained a place to file your tax return beginning on the first day of the year in a foreign country. You have changed your place to file your tax return in the year to a second foreign country. You continue to maintain a place to file your tax return in the second foreign country for the remainder of the year. You have a closer connection to each foreign country than to the United States during the time you maintain a place to file your tax return in that foreign country. You must be taxed as a resident under the tax laws of each foreign country for the entire year or as a resident in both foreign countries during the time you maintain a place to file your tax return in each foreign country.

Where you choose to file is the area of your principal place of business, where you work or where you maintain your office, regardless of where you maintain your family home. Where you choose to file is the place where you work long-term or indefinitely as an employee or as a self-employed individual. If you do not have a principal place of business or you are frequently away from home by the nature of your work, then your place of filing is the place where you usually live. If your case does not fall into one of these categories, you are considered a mobile worker and your place of filing is wherever you work. To determine whether you have a more substantial connection to a foreign country, your place of filing also must exist for the entire current year and be located in the same foreign country that you claim to have a more substantial connection to.

To determine whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country, the term “foreign country” means: Any territory under the sovereignty of the United Nations or a non-U.S. government, Foreign territorial waters (as defined by U.S. law), The seabed and subsoil of the seabed of the maritime areas adjacent to the territorial waters of a foreign country and in which the foreign country has exclusive rights to explore and exploit natural resources under international law, and U.S. territories.

A resident alien has dual status. The rules discussed here to determine whether you are a U.S. resident alien will not render the tax treaty resident definitions ineffective. If you are a dual-status taxpayer, you still may claim treaty benefits for income. A dual-status taxpayer is a resident of both the United States and another country under the tax laws of each country. The tax treaty between the two countries must have a provision that resolves conflicting residency definitions (exception rule). If you are considered a resident under the tax treaty, you will be considered a nonresident alien for U.S. income tax purposes. For other purposes besides income tax, you will be considered a U.S. resident. For example, the rules discussed here do not affect the time you reside, as discussed in Dual-Status Foreigners later in this section.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer and claim treaty benefits, you must file Form 1040NR with Form 8833 and pay tax as a nonresident alien. A dual-status taxpayer may also be eligible for assistance from the U.S. government. See Revenue Procedure 2015-40, 2015-35 I.R.B. 236, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40 (English) or subsequent issue. See Treaty-Based Filing Status in Chapter 9 for more information about filing treaty benefits.

Nonresidents have two tax statuses, so see Chapter 6 for information about filing a tax return in the tax year you are a nonresident alien.

If you meet the green card test at any time during the year but do not meet the substantial presence test for that year, your date of residence will be the first day of the year that you are present in the United States as a legal permanent resident. If you meet both the substantial presence test and the green card test, your date of residence will be before the first day of the year that you are present in the United States under the substantial presence test or as a legal permanent resident.

When calculating the number of days absent in items (1) and (2) above, do not count the days you are in the United States under any of the exceptions discussed in the preceding section on Days Present in the United States. If you choose the first year, your first day of residence in 2024 will be the first day of the earliest 31-day period (shown in item (1) above) that you use to meet the requirements of this election. You are considered a U.S. resident for the remainder of the year. If you are present for more than 31 days and meet the requirements of item (2) above in each of those periods, your first day of residence will be the first day of the first 31-day period. If you are present for more than 31 days but only meet the requirements of item (2) above in the 31-day period after that, your first day of residence will be the first day of that 31-day period.

You cannot file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR or the return until you meet the substantial presence test for 2025. If you do not meet this test for 2024 by April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of time to file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR for 2021 until a reasonable time after you meet that test. To request an extension of time to file until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You can file the paper form or use one of the electronic filing options described in the instructions for Form 4868. When you extend, you must pay the estimated tax for 2024, as if you were a nonresident alien for the entire year. You can use Form 1040-NR to figure your tax. Enter the tax on Form 4868. If you do not pay the tax by the due date, you will be charged interest on any tax not paid by the due date for the regular tax return and you may be subject to a penalty for late filing. After making the first year election, you cannot withdraw the election without the consent of the IRS. If you do not follow the procedure discussed here to make the first year election, you will be treated as a nonresident alien for the entire year 2024. However, this does not apply if you can show by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable actions to know the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

You usually make this choice when filing a joint return. However, you can also make this choice by filing Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter “Amended (Adjusted)” at the top of the adjusted return. If you make this choice with the adjusted return, you and your spouse also must adjust any returns you may have filed after the year you made the election. You usually must file the adjusted joint return within 3 years from the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return or 2 years from the date you paid tax for that year, whichever is later.

If you are a U.S. resident for the substantial presence test and you qualify to apply for an earlier ending date, you can exclude up to 10 days of presence in the U.S. to determine the date you end your residency. To determine if you can exclude up to 10 days, the following rules will be applied. You can exclude days from multiple periods of presence, as long as the total number of days in all periods does not exceed 10. You cannot exclude any days in a continuous period of presence if you cannot exclude all days in that period. Although you can exclude up to 10 days of presence when determining the date you end your residency, you must include those days when determining if you meet the substantial presence test.

If you are a resident of the United States at any time during 2025 and a resident at any time during 2024, you will be considered a resident through 2024. This applies whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country than to the United States during 2024 and whether you are a resident by the significant presence test or the green card test.

Attach the required form to your tax return. If you are not required to file a tax return, send the form to the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the form by the due date or before the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date is discussed in Chapter 7. If you do not file the required form as explained above, you cannot claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or to more than one foreign country. This does not apply if you can show by clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to know the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

If at the end of the tax year you are married and your spouse is a U.S. citizen or a nonresident alien who is a U.S. resident alien and your spouse is a nonresident alien who is a nonresident alien for the tax year, you may elect to treat your nonresident alien spouse as a U.S. resident alien. This includes situations where your nonresident alien spouse is a nonresident alien at the beginning of the tax year, but a U.S. resident alien at the end of the tax year and your spouse is a nonresident alien at the end of the tax year. If you make this election, you and your spouse will be treated as U.S. residents for the entire tax year. You and your spouse both cannot file under any tax treaty and also cannot be treated as U.S. residents. You and your spouse both will be taxed on income from all sources throughout the world. You must file a joint income tax return for the tax year you elect, but you and your spouse may file a joint return or separate returns in subsequent years. If you file a joint return under this provision, the special rules and restrictions for dual-status taxpayers in section 6 are not applicable to you.
Also check the box and enter their name if you and your spouse/partner were considered residents for a year prior to the filing date and the election is still valid.

You usually make this choice when filing a joint return. However, you can also make this choice by filing an amended return on Form 1040. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter “Amended (Amended)” at the top of the amended return. If you make this choice with the amended return, you and your spouse also must amend any returns you may have filed after the year you made the election. You usually must file an amended joint return within 3 years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return or 2 years from the date you paid tax for that year, whichever is later.

The status of being considered a nonresident alien will be suspended for any tax year (after the tax year in which the election is made) if both spouses are not U.S. citizens or nonresident aliens at any time during the tax year. This means that each spouse must file a separate tax return as a nonresident alien for that year if either spouse meets the requirements for filing a tax return for a nonresident alien discussed in Chapter 7.

If you are a non-resident alien temporarily present in the United States and a true resident alien of the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico who is actually a resident alien of the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you will be taxed, with certain exceptions, under the rules for nonresident aliens who are U.S. residents. For more information, see True Resident Aliens of the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico in Chapter 5. If you are a non-resident alien from the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico who is not eligible to be a true resident alien of the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you will be taxed as a non-resident alien. A non-resident alien who was a true resident alien of the United States of Samoa or Puerto Rico will be taxed under the rules for nonresident aliens.
After you have determined the status of the non-resident, you must determine the source of income. This chapter will help you identify many sources of income that you may receive in the tax year.

Foreign residents' income is generally taxed in a similar way to US citizens. If you are a foreign resident, you must report all interest, dividends, salary or other service income, rental income or royalties, and other types of income on your US tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in and outside the United States.

Foreign residents are taxed only on income from sources in the United States and some income related to the conduct of business or trade in the United States (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from sources in the United States apply to most foreign residents. These rules are summarized in Table 2-1. The discussion below includes the general rules as well as the exceptions to these rules. Not all items of income from sources in the United States are taxable. See Chapter 3 ..

Real estate is land, buildings, and anything built on or attached to land. Total U.S. income from sources in the U.S. includes interest, dividends, and income from the sale or other disposition of U.S. real property.

Income from the sale of products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other mineral well or wood in the United States and sold abroad or placed abroad and sold in the United States, which is a part of the United States. To determine the part, see §1.863-1(b).

Personal property is property such as machinery, equipment, or furniture, not real estate. Gain or loss from the sale or exchange of personal property is generally sourced to the U.S. if you have a principal place of employment in the U.S. If you do not have a principal place of employment in the U.S., the gain or loss is generally treated as coming from outside the U.S.

Where you choose to file your tax return is the area of your principal place of business, your place of work, or your place of residence, wherever you may maintain a family home. Where you choose to file your tax return is the place where you work long-term or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed individual. If you do not have a principal place of business or are frequently away from home by virtue of the nature of your work, then your place of choice to file your tax return is where you usually live. If your case does not fall into either of these categories, you are considered a mobile worker and your place of choice to file your tax return is wherever you work.

Inventory assets are personal assets held for sale in the ordinary course of business or for the production of goods for sale. Income from inventory sales that you buy has its source in the place where you sell the property. That is usually the place where the buyer gains ownership of the property. For example, income from inventory sales in the United States is income having its source in the United States, even if you buy the inventory in the United States or abroad. Income from inventory sales that you produce in the United States and sell outside the United States (or vice versa) has its source in the place where the property is produced. This rule applies even if the place you choose to file your tax return is not in the United States.

"English": "To determine the source of any interest earned from the sale of personal property subject to depreciation, first you must calculate the portion of the interest that does not exceed the total depreciation adjustments of the property. You allocate this portion of the interest to sources in the United States based on the depreciation adjustment in the United States relative to the total depreciation adjustment. The remaining portion of the interest is considered to be from sources outside the United States. For this purpose, “U.S. depreciation adjustments” is the depreciation adjustment allowed on the basis of the property when computing taxable income from sources in the United States. However, if the property is used primarily in the United States during the tax year, the entire depreciation allowance allowed in that year is considered to be a U.S. depreciation adjustment. However, there are certain exceptions for transportation, communications, and other property used internationally. Interest from the sale of depreciable property in excess of the total depreciation adjustment on the property is treated as being from sources other than the United States. The loss from the sale of depreciable property is treated in the same manner as the depreciation allowance. However, if the property is used primarily in the United States, the entire loss is treated as being from sources in the United States. The original cost of the property is generally the cost (the amount paid plus the reasonable market value of the property or other service received) of the property that you acquired. Depreciation is the amount you deduct to recover the original cost or other basis of the property used in a trade or business. The amount you can deduct depends on the original cost of the property, the time you begin to use the property, the period of time over which you recover your cost, and the depreciation method you use. The deduction for depreciation is any depreciation deduction or other allowable deduction that treats capital expenditures as a deduction.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, trade secrets, trade names, trademarks, or other similar property. Profits from the sale of intangible property may be allocated or depreciated, up to the allowed depreciation deduction previously taken, having the same source as the original deduction. This is similar to the rule for income from the sale of depreciable property. See Depreciable Property in the previous section for details on how to apply this rule. Profits in excess of depreciation deductions having the same source as the depreciation deduction taken in the country where the property is used if the income from the sale of the property depends on the productivity, use, or transfer of the property. If the income does not depend on the productivity, use, or transfer of the property, the income will have the same source as the place you choose to file your tax return (discussed in the previous section). If payments for trade secrets do not depend on the productivity, use, or transfer of the property, the source of the payments is from the country where the trade secret is created.

Regardless of any prior rules, if you do not have a U.S. tax filing location but you still maintain a fixed business office or other fixed place of business in the U.S., you may consider income from any personal property sales (including inventory) to be assigned to that office or place of business. However, this rule does not apply to inventory sales for use, transfer, or consumption outside the U.S. if the foreign office or other fixed place of business outside the U.S. was more actively involved in the inventory sales. If you have a U.S. tax filing location but you still maintain a fixed business office or other fixed place of business outside the U.S., income from the sale of personal property, other than inventory, depreciable property, or intangible property, may be considered income from the U.S. income from the sale of inventory for use, transfer, or consumption outside the U.S. may be considered income from the U.S. if the foreign office or other fixed place of business outside the U.S. was more actively involved in the inventory sales. Income is considered income from the U.S. if the foreign country taxes income from the sale of inventory at a rate of less than 10 percent of the income from the sale of inventory. This rule also applies to losses if the foreign country taxes income from the sale of inventory at a rate of less than 10 percent.

Payment location or method is not important in determining the source of income. Interest payments in lieu of the transferor of securities in a securities lending or repurchase transaction are made in a manner similar to interest from the securities transferred.

Income from interest earned from sources outside the United States does not include the following. 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or domestic corporation on obligations issued before August 10, 2010, if during the 3-year period ending in the tax year of the taxpayer before the interest is paid, at least 80% (0.80) of the taxpayer's total income is from sources outside the United States and 2. Allowed to be engaged in a trade or business of the individual or the corporation in a foreign country or U.S. territory. However, interest will be treated as income from interest earned from sources outside the United States if either of the following is true. 1. The interest is received by a foreign resident or domestic corporation. See section 954(d)(3) for the definition of “related person.” 2. The terms of the obligation are substantially modified after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the obligation is considered a substantial modification. 2. Interest paid by a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership on a deposit account or withdrawable account in a domestic savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, building and loan association, or other savings organization subject to Federal or State supervision and examination as a savings account or loan or credit union or similar organization under Federal or State law. 3. Interest on deposits at a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership, but only if the branch is engaged in the business of a commercial bank.

In most cases, dividends received from domestic companies are U.S. source income. Dividend income from foreign companies is generally foreign source income. An exception to the second rule discussed below is the case of a U.S. company that is a foreign corporation for U.S. tax purposes but is a domestic corporation for tax purposes in the foreign country. In this case, the dividends are treated as foreign source income.

The equivalent dividend payment amount includes any amount that is referred to as a US-source dividend and used to calculate any actual amount that is transferred to or from a taxpayer under a contract, if the taxpayer is the buyer under the contract. Thus, the taxpayer may be considered to have received an equivalent dividend payment even if they pay net or no amount, as the amount is effectively zero. In 2024, an NPC or ELI will generally be a specific NPC or ELI if the contract is a non-options derivative product contract with a delta of one. Generally, delta is the ratio of the change in the fair market value of the NPC or ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares referenced under the contract. Generally, the equivalent dividend amount of a specific NPC or ELI is the dividend per share multiplied by the number of shares referenced under the contract multiplied by the contract's delta. Special rules apply to complex contracts. See section 1.871-15 of the regulations and Notice 2024–44 (or its successor), for more information.

All compensation and any other allowances from services performed in the United States are considered to be of United States origin. The only exception to this rule is discussed in Foreign Employees, Organizations, or Offices in the Foreign Personnel section in the Front Matter. If you are an employee and receive employment or personal service allowances performed both in and outside the United States, special rules will apply when determining the origin of the allowances. Allowances (other than a few supplements) are considered to be of origin based on time. Some supplements (such as housing and education) are considered to be of origin based on location. You may also be used a substitute basis to determine the origin of the allowances. See Substitute Basis in the Foreign Personnel section in the Front Matter.

Some companies sell products through multi-level marketing, such as an upper distributor who is sponsored by an upper distributor, will be paid by the company based on a number of activities of the lower distributor that. Generally, depending on the fact, the payment of the multi-level marketing company for the independent distributor (not an employee) (upper distributor) based on sales or purchases of those whom they sponsor (lower distributor) will be income from the performance of personal services when recruiting, training and supporting lower distributors. That source of income is usually based on the place of performance of the upper distributor and depending on the fact, can be considered as multi-year subsidies, in which the source of income is determined in the period that the subsidy is allocated.

If you are a self-employed person, you will determine the source of your remuneration from labour or personal services from self-employment based on the most accurate reflection of that appropriate source of income in your particular circumstances. In many cases, the reality and circumstances will require an allocation on the basis of time, which is explained in the following section.

The multiyear source of compensation is generally determined based on the time period in which the compensation is allocated. Multiyear source of compensation is compensation that is included in your taxable income for 1 tax year but may be allocated over 2 or more tax years. You determine the period of time that the compensation is allocated based on the facts and circumstances in your case. For example, compensation related to a period of several years may be allocated over the entire multiyear period. Compensation that is considered to have a U.S. source is treated by multiplying the total multiyear compensation by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or a less than a day unit of time, if appropriate) that you worked or performed personal services in the United States related to the project. The denominator of the fraction is the number of days (or a less than a day unit of time, if appropriate) that you worked or performed personal services in the United States related to the project.

The secondary education allowance for your dependent is based on your main place of work. Secondary education allowance includes only the following payments for primary or secondary school. Tuition, fees, tutoring, special needs student services, books, supplies, and other equipment. Room, board, and uniforms required by or provided by the school in connection with enrollment or attendance.

Local travel allowance is determined based on your main place of work. Local travel allowance is the amount you receive as local travel allowance for you or your spouse or dependent at your main place of work. The amount is considered to be local travel allowance if it is limited to the actual local travel expenses incurred and the reasonable rental value of any vehicle provided by the employer that is used primarily by you, your spouse or dependent for local travel. Actual expenses do not include expenses (including interest) of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf.

The source of the relocation allowance is usually based on your new principal place of work. However, the source is determined based on your former principal place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that the determination of the source is more appropriate in reality and circumstances in your case. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer or a statement of company policy, which is reduced to writing before the move and signed or established to make you or another employee move to another country. The statement or agreement must clearly state that the employer will reimburse you for your relocation expenses to return to your former principal place of work, regardless of whether you continue to work for the employer after returning to that location. This may include certain conditions under which the reimbursement is determined, provided that the conditions are determinable and only implementable before or after you return to your former principal place of work.

If you are an employee, you can use alternative basis to determine your compensation source if you certify in a manner that satisfies the IRS that, in your case, the alternative basis is a more reasonable determination of compensation source than the time or location basis. If you use alternative basis, you must keep (and be able to examine) records to show why the alternative basis is a more reasonable determination of compensation source. Also, if your total compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, check the box “Yes” in both boxes on line K of Form OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach a statement with your return that includes all of the following. 1. Your name and SSN (as shown at the top of the statement). 2. The specific compensation or allowance from which you are using alternative basis. 3. For each item in (2), the alternative basis used to allocate the income. 4. For each item in (2), the calculation showing how the alternative basis was determined. 5. Compare U.S. compensation and foreign compensation based on both the alternative basis and the time or location basis discussed above.

Transportation income is income from the operation of a vessel or aircraft or the performance of services directly related to the use of any vessel or aircraft. This is true whether the vessel or aircraft is owned or leased. The term “vessel or aircraft” includes any container used in connection with a vessel or aircraft. All transportation income that begins and ends in the United States will be considered to be from the United States. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50 percent of the transportation income will be considered to be from the United States. For transportation income from personal services, 50 percent of the income is from the United States if the transportation is between the United States and the territory of the United States. For foreign residents temporarily present, this applies only to income from or related to aircraft.

Generally, grants, research fellowships, prizes and awards are the residence of the taxpayer, regardless of who is actually the funder. However, see Out of Country Activities in the following section. For example, payments for research or study activities in the United States are made by the United States, U.S. residents are not domestic businesses or corporations having their origin in the United States. Similar payments from a foreign government or foreign corporation are foreign source payments, even though the money may be paid through an agent in the United States. Payments made by an organization designated as a foreign public organization under the Foreign Organizations Exemption Act are foreign source payments.

Scholarships, research grants, targeted grants, and achievement awards received by non-U.S. residents for activities conducted or to be conducted outside the United States that are not from U.S. sources. This rule does not apply to payments in the form of salary or other compensation for services. SeePersonal services in the previous section for the rules on income sources applicable to this type of income.

If you receive pension payments from a domestic trust fund for services performed in the U.S. and abroad, part of the pension payment is from U.S. sources. That part is the amount allocated to the program income and the employer’s contributions for services performed in the U.S. This applies whether the distribution is made under a qualified stock bonus, pension, profit-sharing, or other qualified plan (whether or not it is funded). If you perform services as a U.S. employee, you may be eligible to receive payments from the U.S. government under a program such as the Civil Service Retirement System, which is considered a qualified pension plan. Income from U.S. sources is the amount of the distribution that is taxable other than the amount that is exempt from tax for services performed outside the U.S.

If you are required to file a U.S. federal income tax return, you may be able to take advantage of special rules related to natural disasters for using your retirement funds. To learn more, see Publication 590-B (English). Also, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules provide for tax-favored withdrawals and rollovers from certain retirement plans (including IRAs) for taxpayers who suffer economic losses from a major disaster. To learn about reporting qualified disaster distributions and rollovers, see Form 8915-F, Distributions and Rollovers from Qualified Disaster Retirement Plans (English), and instructions.

Income from U.S. sources includes rental income and royalties received during the tax year from U.S. property or from any interest in such property. Income from U.S. sources also includes rental income or royalties from U.S. property or from any interest in such property, intangible property such as patents, copyrights, trade and business secrets, trade names, franchises and similar property.
In these cases, you and your spouse must report joint income, explained in the following section.

Income earned by the spouse, other than income from business or trade and income from the distribution of profits in a partnership of the partner, will be considered as income of the spouse performing services that generate income. The spouse in question must declare all of this on their own tax return.

Income from business activities, other than income from the distribution of profits in a partnership of spouses, will be considered as income of the spouse who performs commercial or business activities. That spouse must declare all of this on their own tax return.

Income (or loss) from the share of the profits distributed in the partnership of the partner will be considered as income (or loss) of the partner. The partner must declare all of this on their own tax return.

Income from the spouse's separate property (not income earned, income from business or trade, or income from the share of profits in a partnership) shall be regarded as income of the spouse. The spouse shall declare all of this on their own tax return. Use the appropriate community property law to determine what is separate property.
All other joint income is deemed to have been provided under the current joint property law.

Foreign residents and temporary residents are generally eligible for certain types of deductions from gross income if they meet certain requirements. A deduction from gross income is generally income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. tax. This chapter covers some of the more common deductions that apply to foreign residents and temporary residents.
Non-resident aliens may exclude the following from their total income.

If you are present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 days in any 12-month period, you may be eligible to exclude income earned abroad. The exclusion amount for 2024 is $126,500. In addition, you may be able to exclude or deduct certain foreign housing expenses. You may also be eligible if you are a true resident of a foreign country and you are a citizen or national of a country with which the United States has a tax treaty. For more information, see Publication 54 (English).

A foreign country is any territory under the sovereignty of a government other than the United States Government. The term “foreign country” includes the land and airspace of that country, but does not include international waters and airspace above. A foreign country also includes the seabed and subsoil of the sea areas adjacent to the territorial waters of that country and in which they have exclusive rights to explore and exploit natural resources under international law. The term “foreign country” does not include the territory of the United States. A foreign country does not include the Antarctic region.
Foreign residents may be exempt from the following amounts from total income.

Income from interest not related to trade or business in the United States will be exempt from income if the income is from: Money on deposit (including certificates of deposit) with persons in the banking business; Money on deposit or accounts that are withdrawable at a savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, building and loan association, or other savings organization that is supervised and insured as a savings and loan association or credit union under federal or state law (if the association is so insured); and Money that a company of insurance holds under an agreement to pay interest accruing from such money.

Interest on the debt obligations of a state or political subdivision, the District of Columbia or a U.S. territory is generally not included in income. However, interest on certain private activity bonds, zero-coupon bonds and some unregistered bonds will be included in income.

Interest and OID that is qualified investment income is not subject to withholding tax under Chapter 3 (of the Internal Revenue Code) in sections 1441-1443. However, that interest may be withheld if it is a withholding-tax-subject payment and does not qualify for the withholding-tax exemption under Chapter 4 (of the Internal Revenue Code) in sections 1471-1474. For more information, see the discussion of qualified investment income in Withholding on Specific Income (in Publication 515 (PDF)) (English). To qualify as qualified investment income, interest must be paid on a bond issued after July 18, 1984. If not, interest will be withheld. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, qualified investment income does not include interest paid on an unregistered loan. Before March 19, 2012, qualified investment income includes interest on certain registered and unregistered (unregistered) bonds if the bond meets the requirements set out below.

A registered security is not considered to be registered at a specific time if the security can be converted at any time in the future to an unregistered security. For more information on whether a security is considered to be registered, see the discussion of investment income in Withholding on Specific Income in Publication 515 (PDF).

You are not required to provide documentation of interest income on a non-taxable account to qualify as investment income. However, in some cases, you may need to provide documentation for reporting purposes on Form 1099 and the withheld amount on your payroll to pay taxes annually.

Payment to certain persons and payment of interest on reserve accounts is non-taxable interest. You must deduct the appropriate rate of tax from these payments, except where an exception applies, such as a treaty provision.

Interest on investment categories does not include reserve interest. Reserve interest is one of the following. 1. Interest is determined by reference to: Any income, sales proceeds, or other cash flow of the debtor or related party; Income or profits of the debtor or related party; Any change in the value of any asset of the debtor or related party; or Any dividends, contributions of capital, or similar payments of the debtor or related party. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other reserve interest is determined by the Secretary of the Treasury in regulations.

The relevant persons include the following. Members of a family, including only siblings, half-siblings, step-siblings, step-parents, grandparents, and descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.). Anyone who is a party to any arrangement entered into for the purpose of avoiding the rules on unexpected interest. Certain corporations, partnerships, and other entities. For details, see Nondeductible Loss in Chapter 2 of Publication 544 (English).

The reserve interest is not included in the interest paid or accrued on any fixed-term debt issued: On or before April 7, 1993; or After April 7, 1993, by a binding written contract effective on that day and at all times thereafter before the debt is issued.
The following dividend income is exempt from the 30% tax rate.

Do not apply a 30% tax rate to U.S. source dividends you receive from a foreign corporation. See Exception in Chapter 2, Dividends, for how to calculate U.S. source dividends. This exemption does not apply to equivalent dividend payments.

No 30% tax on dividends related to U.S. interest income you receive from a mutual fund or regulated investment company (RIC). A mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are related to interest income.

No 30% tax rate on a portion of short-term capital gains from U.S. sources you receive from a mutual fund or RIC. A mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains. This tax break won't apply if you are present in the U.S. for 183 days or more in the tax year.

If you do not meet all three conditions, income from personal services performed in the United States is U.S. source income and is taxed under the rules in Chapter 4. If you are paid more than $3,000 for these services, the entire amount is U.S. business or trade income. To determine whether you are paid more than $3,000, do not include any amount you receive from your employer to advance or reimburse your business or trade expenses, if you are required to and have accounted to your employer for those expenses. If your advances or reimbursements exceed your business or trade expenses, include the excess in your income from services. A “day” means a calendar day during which you are physically present in the United States.

Compensation for services performed by a non-resident individual while temporarily present in the United States as a seaman on a foreign ship (e.g., a boat or a vessel) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or U.S. territory is not U.S. source income and is exempt from U.S. taxation. This exemption does not apply to compensation for services performed on a foreign aircraft.

Students or exchange visitors in the United States on an F, J, M, or Q visa may exclude wages from total income received from an employer who is a non-U.S. person. This group includes students, fellows, interns, teachers, professors, research assistants, specialists, or leaders in a field of knowledge or skill, or persons with similar descriptions. This group also includes the spouse and children under the age of 21 of a non-U.S. person if they are accompanying or joining the non-U.S. person in the United States. Exchange visitors on a J visa include foreign nationals admitted to the United States as exchange visitors under the U.S. Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961.
Foreign labor is not a foreign government. Foreign government payments are discussed in Chapter 10.

Any kind of income exempt from U.S. tax under a treaty to which the United States is a party will be excluded from gross income. However, income that is only subject to tax by treaty, will be included in gross income. See chapter 9.
You can exclude from total income winnings from legal betting on horse or dog racing held outside the United States in a pool of betting on such racing held in the United States.

If you have sold your principal residence, you may exclude up to $250,000 of gain from the sale. If you are married and file a joint return, you may exclude up to $500,000. For information about this exclusion, see Publication 523 (PDF). This exclusion does not apply if you are subject to the rules on tax abandonment of citizenship discussed in chapter 4.

If you are a candidate for a degree program, you can exclude part or all of the amount received as a qualified scholarship from income. The rules discussed here apply to both resident and nonresident aliens. If a nonresident alien receives a grant that is not from the United States, the alien is not subject to United States tax. SeeScholarships, grants, awards, and prizes in chapter 2 to determine whether your grant is from the United States. A graduate student scholarship or grant is only excluded from income if: 1. You are a candidate for a degree program at a qualified educational institution and 2. You use the scholarship or grant to pay qualified educational expenses.

This still applies even if you have to pay a fee to an educational institution as a condition of enrollment or attendance. Any scholarship or research grant used to pay these fees is taxable.

You cannot exclude a scholarship, research fellowship, or tuition reduction that represents a payment for teaching, research, or other services in the past, present, or future from income. This is true even if all applicants to a degree program must perform services as a condition of receiving a degree.

Foreign residents and non-resident aliens are taxed in different ways. Foreign residents are generally taxed in a way similar to U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed based on their sources of income and whether the income is actually related to their business or trade in the United States. The discussion below will help you determine whether the income you received in the tax year is actually related to your business or trade in the United States and how that income is taxed.

Foreign residents are generally taxed in a manner similar to US citizens. This means that their income from other parts of the world is subject to US taxation and must be reported on a US tax return. Foreign resident income is taxed at the progressive tax rates applied to US citizens. Foreign residents use the Tax Table or Tax Calculator in the Guide for Form 1040 for US citizens.

The difference between the two is that the actual taxable income, after permitted deductions, is taxed at a progressive rate. This is the same rate applied to US citizens and residents. The actual non-taxable income is taxed at a flat 30% (or lower under a treaty). If you were ever a US citizen or foreign resident then these rules may not apply. SeeTaxes on Renunciation in the later section of this chapter.

Generally, you must be engaged in a trade or business during the tax year to have income received during that year considered to be derived from that trade or business. Whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. The discussion below will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you perform personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States. Wages from foreign employers are not included in your total income. For more information, seeServices performed for a foreign employer in chapter 3.
Below is another example of engaging in a commercial or business activity in the United States.

If you are temporarily present in the United States as a nonimmigrant under a visa classification of F, J, M, or Q and are not engaged in a commercial or business enterprise, you will be considered to be engaged in a commercial or business enterprise in the United States if you have income from a fellowship or research grant described in section 1441(b). Any income from a fellowship or research grant that is from sources in the United States will be considered to be related to your commercial or business enterprise in the United States.

If you are a member of a partnership that at any time during the tax year you engage in a trade or business in the United States, you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States.
If you are a beneficiary of real property or a trust that is engaged in a U.S. trade or business, you are considered to be engaged in the same trade or business.

If your only U.S. business activity is trading securities, commodities, or insurance risk through a U.S. resident broker or other agent, you are not engaged in U.S. trade or business. For securities trading, this applies to any nonresident temporary resident, including a securities trader or broker. For commodities trading, this applies to commodities that are commonly traded on an organized exchange and traded on that exchange. This discussion does not apply if you have a fixed place of business or other fixed place of business in the U.S. at any time during the tax year in which you trade securities, commodities, or insurance risk.

You are not engaged in a trade or business in the United States if your trading in stocks, securities, or commodities in your own account is your sole business activity in the United States. This applies even if the trading occurs when you are in the United States or is carried out by your agent, broker, or other representative. This does not apply to trading in your own account if you are a trader in stocks, securities, or commodities. However, this does not necessarily mean that as a trader, you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States. Determine that based on the facts and circumstances in each case or according to the rules set forth in Trading in Stocks, Securities, and Commodities.

If you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States, all income, gain, or loss from sources within the United States (other than investment income) is treated as effectively connected income. This applies whether or not there is any connection between the income and the trade or business being conducted in the United States during the tax year. Two tests, discussed in Investment Income in the following section, determine whether certain types of investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) are treated as effectively connected to the trade or business. In certain limited circumstances, certain types of foreign income may be treated as effectively connected to trade or business in the United States. For a discussion of these rules, see Foreign Income in the following section.

Use the two challenges discussed in the section below to determine whether a particular income is from the U.S. and is one of the three types discussed above and received in the tax year of actual U.S. business or trade activity. If the challenges indicate that the income is actually U.S. income, you must include it in the other actual U.S. income. If the income is not actually U.S. income, you must include it in all other income discussed in the 30% rate in the section below in this chapter.
Generally, the stock of a company is not considered to be property used in or held for use in or for the purpose of commerce or business in the United States.
According to this challenge, if commercial or business activity in the United States is a significant factor in generating income, then that income is considered to be a real connection.

If you have performed personal services in the United States after 1986 and in the tax year following the year in which you were a nonresident alien temporarily present in the United States, distributions from your retirement or pension plan that are attributable to such services are treated as effectively connected income to the extent they are attributable to contributions made by you while you were a nonresident alien temporarily present in the United States. This is true whether or not you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States in the year you received the distributions.

A “fixed place of business” is usually a place, location, structure, or other similar place where you conduct business or commercial activity. A “regularly scheduled transportation” means a ship or aircraft that operates under a published schedule with recurring trips or flights between the same points, beginning or ending in the United States. This definition applies to both scheduled air transportation and charter flights. If you do not meet both of these requirements, your income will not be considered to be in the U.S. trade or business and will be taxed at the 4% rate. See Transportation Income in the later part of this chapter.

All income or loss arising from U.S. sources from the business of a U.S. person is effectively connected income from a U.S. trade or business. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the U.S. acquired in the U.S. or abroad is effectively connected income from a U.S. trade or business. A portion of income or loss arising from U.S. sources from the business of a partnership engaged in a U.S. trade or business is also effectively connected income from a U.S. trade or business.

Interest and losses from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property interests (whether they are capital assets or not) are taxed as if you were engaged in a U.S. trade or business. You must treat interest or losses as being related to that trade or business.

That is any interest in U.S. real property or U.S. Virgin Islands real property or any interest (other than as a creditor) in a domestic corporation that is a U.S. real property owner. Real property includes the following. 1. Land and unimproved natural products of land such as crops and timber, mines, wells, and other natural deposits. 2. Improvements on land such as buildings, other structures, and structural components attached to the land. 3. Tangible personal property used in the operation of the real property such as farm, mining, forest, or construction equipment or property used in a lodging or office rental business, except tangible personal property: 1. That is transferred more than 1 year before or after the transfer of the real property, or 2. That is sold separately to persons unrelated to the seller or purchaser of the real property.
