Stocks in any domestic company will be considered as stocks in a U.S. real estate holding company, unless you determine that the company is not a U.S. real estate holding company.

Benefits from U.S. real property do not include a class of stock of a company that is regularly traded on a stock exchange, unless you own more than 5% of the fair market value of that class of stock (or more than 10% of that stock in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT)). Benefits in a foreign company that owns U.S. real property are generally not interest from U.S. real property, unless the company elects to be treated as a domestic corporation.

Special rules apply to QIE. A QIE is any REIT or any RIC that is treated as a U.S. real property holding company (after applying certain rules in section 897(h)(4)(A)(ii)). See U.S. Real Property Interest in Publication 515 (English) for more information.

In most cases, any distribution from a QIE to a nonresident alien, a foreign corporation, or another QIE will be treated as income to the nonresident alien, foreign corporation, or other QIE from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property. Certain exceptions apply to the rule of attributing income to a separate class of QIE distributions. Distributions of QIE related to publicly traded stock held by a U.S. person are not treated as income from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property if the U.S. person held at least 5% of the stock (or 10% of the stock in the case of a REIT) at any time during the 1-year period ending on the distribution date. Distributions made by a REIT are generally not treated as income from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property if the shareholder is a qualified shareholder (as described in section 897(k)(3)). Distributions that you do not treat as income from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property may be included in your total income as ordinary dividends.

The holding of stock in a REIT by a qualified holder (whether directly or indirectly through one or more partnerships) will not be treated as an interest in U.S. real property. See sections 897(k)(2)-(4) for more information.

To determine whether a QIE is controlled in the U.S., the following rules will be applied. 1. A person holding less than 5% of any QIE's stock, traded regularly on a U.S. stock exchange at any time during the test period, will be considered a U.S. person, unless the QIE knows that the person is not a U.S. person. 2. Any stock in a QIE held by another QIE will be considered held by a foreign person if: 1. Any other class of QIE stock is traded regularly on a U.S. stock exchange, or 2. The other QIE is a RIC issuing a class of redeemable securities. Notwithstanding the above, stock in a QIE will be considered held by a U.S. person if the other QIE is controlled in the U.S. 3. Stock in a QIE held by any other QIE not described above will be considered held by a U.S. person, in proportion to the stock of the other QIE held (or considered held) by a U.S. person.

If this situation occurs, you will be treated as having realized gain from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property interests for a distribution that is treated as gain. This also applies to any alternative minimum tax distributions. A transaction will not be treated as a short sale of a current QIE if: You actually receive a distribution from a domestic QIE related to the interests treated or repurchased in the transaction or You hold any type of stock in a QIE that is traded regularly on a U.S. stock exchange but only if you do not own more than 5% of that type of stock at any time during the 1-year period ending on the distribution date.
There may be a minimum tax on net income from the processing of benefits from U.S. real property. Pay this tax (if any) on Form 6251.

Any income from abroad equivalent to any income presented above is considered to be actually related to commercial or business activity in the United States. For example, interest from abroad and equivalent dividends are considered to be actually related income in the United States if the income is from the banking, financial, or similar business activity of a foreign person in the United States.

Your income from the year of the tax year in which you are actually engaged in business or trade in the United States, after any allowed deductions, will be taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. Generally, you can only receive income from business or trade in the United States if you are a nonresident alien temporarily present in the United States during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the performance of services, or any other transaction during the tax year that you are not engaged in business or trade in the United States, but the payments are considered income from business or trade in the year of the transaction or you performed the services, they are considered income from business or trade in the tax year in which you received the payments.
You can choose to treat all income from real property as a single economic unit. See Income from real property in the section later in this chapter.
Tax rates of 30% (or lower under a treaty) apply only to a limited number of income or interest from the U.S. when the income or interest is not related to a U.S. trade or business.

Tax rate of 30% (or lower under treaty) applies to total fixed, determinable, annual, or periodic (FDAP) income from U.S. sources. Income is fixed when it is paid by way of advance payments. Income is determinable whenever there is a basis for determining the amount to be paid. Income is periodic if it is occasionally paid. Income is not paid annually or periodically. Income may be determinable or periodic even if the payment period increases or decreases. The amounts are treated as fixed or determinable income if they are interest (other than OID), dividends, equivalent dividend payments (as defined in chapter 2), rents, premiums, annuities, wages, and other compensation. Dividend or interest substitute payments received in a securities lending or repurchase transaction are treated as income received on the securities transferred. Other income such as royalties may also be subject to a 30% tax rate. Certain fixed or determinable income may be exempt from U.S. tax. See chapter 3 If you are not sure whether income is taxable,.

Generally, nonresident aliens are taxed at a 30% rate on total gambling winnings in the United States if the income is not effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business and is not exempt from tax under a treaty. However, no tax is levied on nonbusiness gambling income that a nonresident alien wins while playing blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette, or big 6 wheel in the United States. Nonresident aliens are taxed at a graduated rate on net gambling income in the United States that is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business. This income is exempt under certain tax treaties. See Treaty Tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English) for a list of tax treaties that exempt gambling income from U.S. tax. For more information, see Publication 915 (English).

Foreign residents are subject to 85% of the U.S. Social Security benefits (and the equivalent Social Security of the Railroad Retirement benefit Tier 1) on FDAP income from the U.S. Social Security benefits include retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is exempt under certain tax treaties. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English) for a list of tax treaties that exempt Social Security benefits from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Publication 915 (English).

Income from (1) is not subject to the 30% (or lower under a treaty) rate if you choose to treat the income as being derived from a U.S. trade or business. See Income from real property in the next section.

Reporting Capital Gains and Losses from the Sale or Exchange of a Capital Asset That Is Not Related to a Trade or Business in the U.S. Report capital gains and losses from the sale or exchange of a capital asset (including real estate) that is not related to a trade or business in the U.S. on Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797 or both. File with Form 1040-NR.

If you have income from U.S. real property in which you have an interest or a right to use and hold for the production of income, you may elect to treat all of the income from that property as income from a U.S. trade or business. This election applies to all income from U.S. real property held for the production of income and also applies to all income from any interest in that property. Profits include income from rents, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells, or other natural resources. Profits from the sale or exchange of wood, coal, or iron ore in the U.S. that yield economic benefits are also treated as profits. You may make this election only for income from real property that is not effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business. If you make this election, you may deduct expenses incurred in earning the income from the real property and only the net income from the real property is taxable. This election does not treat a nonresident alien who is not engaged in a U.S. trade or business as being engaged in a U.S. trade or business during the year.
This option remains in effect for all subsequent tax years, unless you revoke it.

You can withdraw your election without IRS approval by filing Form 1040-X for the year you made the election and for the tax years after that. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years from the date you filed your return or 2 years from the due date, whichever is later. If this period expires in the year of the election, you cannot withdraw the election for that year. However, you can only withdraw the election for subsequent tax years if you have IRS approval. To learn more about how to get IRS approval, see Section 1.871-10(a)(2) of the Regulations.

Tax rate of 4% applies to total transportation income from the United States. This includes only transportation income considered to arise from the United States if the transportation activity begins or ends in the United States. For personal service transportation income, the transportation activity must occur between the United States and the territory of the United States. For personal service income provided by non-U.S. residents, this applies only to income arising from or related to aircraft.

Under this special rule, you must pay tax on all income from sources in the United States and on your actual income at the progressive rate applicable to individuals (with allowed deductions) during the time you are a nonresident alien, unless you are subject to a higher rate under section 871 (the rules generally applicable to the taxation of nonresident alien individuals, discussed in the preceding section) after taking into account any current treaty benefits. For more information on the calculation of the special rule, see Tax from Renunciation in the following section.

If you must pay this tax for any year during which you are a nonresident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The return will be due not later than the due date (including any extension) for filing your U.S. income tax return for the year you become a U.S. resident. If you have already filed a return for that period, you must file an amended return. You must attach a statement with your return identifying the source of all your U.S. and foreign income and any income subject to this special rule.

Tax provisions for renunciation of citizenship apply to U.S. citizens who have renounced citizenship and LTR has terminated residency. The following describes the rules for renunciation of citizenship under Section 877A, which apply to individuals who renounced citizenship on or after June 17, 2008. See Renunciation of Citizenship after June 16, 2008 in the next section. If you renounced citizenship before June 17, 2008, refer to Renunciation of Citizenship after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008 in Chapter 4 of Publication 519, 2018, and the Instructions for Form 519, 2018. If you renounced citizenship or terminated long-term residency after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (if applicable) of your renunciation of citizenship and file Form 8854 with the IRS.

You are a LTR if you are a U.S. legal resident for at least 8 of the 15 tax years ending in the year your residency status ends. To determine if you meet the 8-year test, please do not count any years you are considered a resident of a foreign country for tax purposes and do not waive treaty benefits.
The day you give up your citizenship is the day you give up your U.S. citizenship (in the case of former citizens) or end your long-term residency (in the case of former U.S. residents).

You must file Form 8854 original in the year you renounce U.S. citizenship or end long-term resident status, even if you are not a renouncing citizen who must pay departure tax on all assets in the last year. In addition, you also must file Form 8854 annually after you renounce citizenship if you are a renouncing citizen who must pay departure tax on all assets in the last year and you: 1. Pay the tax adjustment after (see Postponement of Tax Adjustment , in the back), 2. Have qualified deferred compensation, or 3. Have interest in a non-grantor trust.

You are considered to have renounced your U.S. citizenship as early as the days following. 1. The day you renounced your U.S. citizenship before a U.S. consular or diplomatic officer (provided that the voluntary renunciation has been confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 2. The day you provided the Department of State with a signed statement of voluntary renunciation of U.S. citizenship (provided that the voluntary renunciation has been confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 3. The day the Department of State issues a certificate of loss of citizenship. 4. The day a U.S. court cancels your certificate of naturalization.

You are considered to have terminated your long-term residence status no later than the days following. 1. The day you voluntarily renounce your lawful permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 of the Department of Homeland Security to a U.S. consular officer or immigration officer. 2. The day you must comply with the final administrative order in which you renounce your lawful permanent resident status (or if the order has been appealed, the day of the final judicial order relating to the administrative order). 3. The day you must comply with the final administrative order to be deported from the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act. 4. If you are a U.S. permanent resident and a country that the United States has signed a tax treaty, the day you begin to be considered a resident of that country under the terms of the treaty and notify the IRS of that treatment on Form 8833 and Form 8854. See Tax Treaty Impact in Chapter 1 for more information about dual status individuals.

If you abandon your citizenship after June 16, 2008, you are considered to have abandoned your citizenship and the rules of abandonment of citizenship under Section 877A will apply if you meet any of the following conditions. 1. Your average annual net income for the 5 years ending before the date of abandonment of citizenship or ending of residence is more than $201,000 if you abandon citizenship or terminate residence in 2024. 2. Your net worth is $2 million or more on the date of abandonment of citizenship or ending of residence. 3. You do not certify on Form 8854 that you have complied with all United States federal tax obligations in the 5 years before the date of abandonment of citizenship or ending of residence.

If you are a U.S. citizen who renounced citizenship after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for certain relief procedures as an alternative to meeting the tax compliance requirements. For more information, see Relief Procedures for Certain Former Citizens, available at IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Relief-Procedures-for-Certain-Former-Citizens (English).

You may be eligible for the above-described exception if you meet both of the following requirements. At birth, you were a U.S. citizen and a citizen of a foreign country and, since the date you renounced your citizenship, you continue to be a citizen of that foreign country and are taxed as a resident of that foreign country. You are a U.S. resident for less than 10 years during the 15-year period that ends with the tax year in which the renunciation of citizenship occurred. To determine your U.S. residency status, use the significant presence test described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for the exception discussed in the preceding section if you meet both of the following requirements. You renounced citizenship before age 18½. You were a U.S. resident for more than 10 years of tax years before renouncing citizenship. To determine your U.S. residency status, use the significant presence test discussed in chapter 1.

In the year you give up your citizenship, you must report income on net gains (or losses) realized on assets as if the assets were sold at fair market value on the day before you give up citizenship (“market-based adjustment”). This applies to most types of property interests you hold on the day you give up citizenship or end your residency. However, see the Exception below. Capital gains realized on sales of property are taxable in the tax year of the sale that is not related to other U.S. tax laws. Capital losses realized on sales of property are taxable within the limits prescribed by U.S. tax law. However, Section 1091 (relating to the non-allowance of short-term capital losses on stock and securities) does not apply.

Instead, items (1) and (3) may be withheld at source. In the case of item (2), you are treated as receiving the present value of accumulated earnings from this date until the date you abandon your citizenship. In the case of item (4), you are treated as distributing the entire amount of interest in the account on this date until the date you abandon your citizenship. See Notice 2009-85 and the Instructions for Form 8854 for more information.

If you are both a non-resident alien and a non-resident alien for the same tax year, see chapter 6 to see the discussion of dual nationals.

You can deduct a number of individual deductions if you have actual trade or business income in the United States. Generally, you can only deduct and claim losses that are properly allocated to your actual trade or business income in the United States. You cannot deduct deductions and losses related to income that is exempt from tax or income that is not actually earned in the United States. However, you can deduct some charitable contributions and losses from theft and damage even if they are not related to your actual trade or business income. Use Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) to claim individual deductions. See Form 1040-NR Instructions (English) for more information.

View the 4684 Form (English) Guide for more information on disaster losses that qualify. To determine if you were affected by a major disaster declared by the federal government, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.
These losses are not subject to the limits applicable to personal-use property. Use Schedule B of Form 4684 to figure the deduction for these losses.

Special rules apply to eligible students and business trainees under Section 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty. You can claim the standard deduction, provided you do not claim individual deductions. Use Schedule 5-1 to figure the standard deduction for 2023. If you are married and your spouse files a separate return and claims individual deductions, you cannot claim the standard deduction.

If you are a qualified student or business professional who is affected by a major disaster declared by the federal government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters (English)), you may choose to increase your standard deduction by the amount of your qualified disaster-related personal loss on your 2023 return. Use Schedule 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. See Form 4684 (English) 2024 and the instructions for more information about the disaster-related personal loss deduction.

You can deduct state and local income taxes paid on income that is not included in your gross income from business or trade in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 ($5,000 if you are married and filing separately). If you received a refund or had a tax reduction in the year 2024 that you filed in a prior year, do not reduce your deduction by that amount. Instead, you must add the refund or the amount of the reduction to your income if you took a deduction in the prior year and the deduction reduced your tax. See Recoveries (Refunds) in Publication 525 (English) for details on how to figure the amount to add to your income.

Direct contributions to a foreign organization are not deductible. However, you may be able to deduct contributions to a U.S. organization that transfers money to a foreign charity if the U.S. organization manages the use of the funds or the foreign organization is merely a branch of the U.S. organization. Under the limited income tax treaty, you may be eligible to deduct contributions to a foreign charity. See Publication 526 (English) for details.

You can deduct losses from damage and theft on your tax return. You can only deduct losses from casualty or theft that are not related to a business or trade if the loss is attributable to a federal declared disaster. If the loss from casualty or theft is attributable to a federal declared disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to a business or trade in the United States. The property can be personal use property or property that produces income not related to a business or trade in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the casualty or theft. You can deduct a loss from theft in the year you discover the theft. Use Form 4684 and the instructions to figure the loss from damage and theft that you must deduct. For more information, see Publication 547.

You can claim foreign tax credits for a limited amount of foreign income tax paid or accrued for a foreign country on foreign-source income. You cannot claim foreign tax credits for foreign-source income earned in a foreign country that is excluded. To claim foreign tax credits for foreign income tax paid or accrued for a foreign country, you usually must file Form 1116 with Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514 (PDF).

You may be able to claim this tax credit if you pay someone to care for a qualifying dependent under age 13 or a disabled spouse or dependent so you can work or look for work. For more information, see Form 2441 (English) and Publication 503 (English).

You may be eligible for these education credits if you paid qualified education expenses for yourself, your spouse or your dependent. There are two types of education credits: the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit. You cannot claim these credits if you are married and filing separately. Use Form 8863 to figure the credits. For more information, see Publication 970 (PDF). Foreign residents, see Education Credits for Foreign Residents in Foreign Residents later in this section.

You may be eligible for this credit (called the savings credit) if you made eligible contributions to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or IRA in 2023. Use Form 8880 and the instructions to figure the credit. For more information about the eligibility requirements for the credit, see Publication 590-A (English).

A child is always considered to be your own child. A child is a child for whom you are entitled to claim a child tax credit. If you do not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extensions) then you cannot claim the child tax credit on the original or amended 2024 return. If the child does not have a valid SSN to work issued before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extensions) then you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child but you can claim the credit for another dependent for this child. See Dependent credit below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and instructions to figure the credit.

Dependents other than children are eligible for the child tax credit. A qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or foreign national who is a U.S. resident alien and must have a SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including any filing extensions). See Form 8812 (Form 1040) and instructions for more information.

You may be eligible for a credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be taken into account when adopting a child with special needs, regardless of whether you have any qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

EIC or earned income tax credit (EITC) is a benefit for people who work and have low to moderate income. To qualify for EIC, you must earn earned income while working for someone or operating or owning a business or farm and meet basic rules. Also, you must meet other rules for workers who don't have qualifying children or have children who meet all the rules about qualifying children. EIC reduces the amount of tax you owe and may give you a refund. To learn more, go to IRS.gov/EIC. If you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) don't have a Social Security number (SSN) issued by the date you're required to file your 2024 tax return (including extensions) then you can't claim EIC on your original or amended 2024 tax return. Also, if a child doesn't have an SSN issued by the date you're required to file your 2024 tax return (including extensions) then you can't claim that child as a qualifying child when you claim EIC on your original or amended 2024 tax return. If your Social Security card has a notation that says “Not Valid for Employment (Not Valid for Employment)” and the number was issued to you (or your spouse or qualifying child) so you can receive federal assistance, then you can't claim EIC. A federal assistance program is Medicaid. If your card has this notation and your immigration status has changed so that you now are a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, ask SSA to issue you a new Social Security card without the notation.
You can request a number of tax credits similar to those available to non-resident foreigners. You can also claim a number of taxes paid, considered paid, or withheld from income.
Only allow the tax credit if you actually receive income from multiple sources. You may be able to claim some tax credits after you file.

If you receive income from a foreign country that is related to your business or trade in the United States, you may be able to claim a credit for any foreign income taxes paid or withheld on that income. If you do not receive income from a foreign country that is related to your business or trade in the United States, you cannot claim a U.S. credit for any foreign income taxes paid or withheld on that income. You cannot claim a credit for any foreign income taxes paid or withheld on income from the United States if the foreign country or territory imposed those taxes only because you are a citizen or resident of that foreign country or territory. If you claim a credit for foreign income taxes paid on income from a foreign country, you usually must file Form 1116 with your return. See Publication 514 (English) for more information.

You may claim this credit if you pay someone to care for a qualifying dependent under age 13 or a disabled dependent or spouse to enable you to work or to look for work. To see the definitions of these terms, see Publication 503 (English). Foreign residents who are married may claim the credit if they file a joint return with a U.S. citizen spouse or a U.S. resident spouse as discussed in Chapter 1, How to Make an Election, or if they are eligible as a married person living apart (see Joint Return Test in Publication 503 (English)). Expenses for child care and qualifying dependents may be claimed as a credit in any tax year only if they are less than your earned income from the United States in that tax year. Wages are usually earned income. For more information, see Publication 503 (English).

A child is always considered to be your own child. A child is a child for whom you are entitled to claim a child tax credit. If you do not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued by the date or before the due date of your 2024 return (including extensions) then you cannot claim the child tax credit on the original or amended return. If the child does not have a valid SSN to work by the due date of your 2024 return (including extensions) then you cannot claim the child tax credit for that child but you can claim the credit for another dependent for that child. See Dependent credit below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and instructions to figure the credit.

A non-resident alien who is a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or foreign resident alien is eligible to claim the child tax credit. This is a non-refundable credit of $500 per qualifying child. A qualifying child is a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or foreign resident alien. See Form 1040-NR Instructions. To claim the child tax credit for another qualifying child, the qualifying child must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including any filing extensions). Only foreign nationals who are U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or foreign resident aliens; Canadian, Mexican, or South Korean citizens who are U.S. residents; or Indian students and business trainees are eligible to receive the benefits under Section 21(2) of the Income Tax Treaty with India.

You may be eligible for a credit of up to $16,810 when you have paid qualifying expenses to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed to adopt a child with special needs, regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. A nonresident alien who is married may claim the credit only if he or she elects to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident, discussed in Chapter 1, Married Nonresident Aliens Considered as U.S. Residents. A married nonresident alien who is not eligible to file a joint return may claim the credit if he or she is a married individual who lives apart from his or her spouse, see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly (Married Nonresident Aliens Who Are Not Filing Jointly) in the instructions for Form 8839.

If you are a non-resident alien at any time during the tax year, you generally cannot claim EIC. However, if you are married and you and your spouse are both U.S. citizens or legal permanent residents discussed in Spouse is a non-resident alien considered a resident alien under Chapter 1, you may be eligible to claim this credit. If you and your spouse do not have SSNs issued by the date you file your 2024 return or by the due date (including any extensions) for filing your 2024 return, you cannot claim EIC on your original or amended 2024 return. Also, if your child does not have an SSN issued by the date you file your 2024 return or by the due date (including any extensions) for filing your 2024 return, you cannot claim your child as a qualifying child when claiming EIC on your original or amended 2024 return. If your SSN has an endorsement stating “Not Valid for Employment (Not Valid for Employment)” and the number has been issued to you (or your qualifying spouse or qualifying child) to receive a federal benefit, you cannot claim EIC. A federal benefit is Medicaid. If your SSN has this endorsement and your immigration status has changed to become a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, request SSA to issue a new SSN without the endorsement. See Publication 596 for more information about this credit.
You can claim tax withheld on Form 1040-NR, lines 25a-25g. Withholding tax will reduce the amount of tax you owe on Form 1040-NR.

Any federal income tax withheld from your salary in the tax year in which you are a nonresident alien is treated as a U.S. income tax payment for that year. You can report the withheld tax even if you were not engaged in U.S. trade or business during the tax year and even if the salary (or other income) related to the trade or business was not received in the United States.

If you have two or more employers, you may be able to deduct Social Security and Medicare taxes withheld from your income from your U.S. income tax return. See Social Security and Medicare taxes in chapter 8 for more information.

Employers are required to withhold 0.9% (0.009) of Medicare tax on Medicare wages or compensation paid to you that exceeds $200,000 in 2024. If you do not owe Medicare tax, you can request a refund of any withheld Medicare tax by filing Form 8959.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT, you may be able to claim a deduction for the tax paid by the company on your long-term capital gains. You will receive information on Form 2439, which you must attach to your tax return.

You may claim as a deduction any withholding tax on your investment income and FDIAP income paid to you. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rents and royalties that you do not report as actual income. Wages or salaries may be fixed or determinable income but usually depend on the withholding discussed above. Tax on fixed or determinable income will be withheld at 30% or less under the treaty.

If you are a foreign member of a partnership, the partnership will withhold ECTI from the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a Form 8805 reporting the withheld tax. A publicly traded partnership may withhold on the actual distribution of the actual taxable income. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a Form 1042-S. Withholding tax reported is a payment on line 25e or line 25g of Form 1040-NR if deemed appropriate.

You can report as a withheld tax payment related to the transfer of a U.S. real property interest (or income treated as derived from the transfer of a U.S. real property interest). See Real property gains or losses in Chapter 4. The buyer will provide you with a Form 8288-A. Report withheld tax as line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a nonresident alien who is a U.S. resident alien of American Samoa or a resident alien of Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you generally are taxed as a nonresident alien. You must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and report all income from sources in and outside the United States. However, you may exclude income discussed in the following sections. For tax purposes, however, you are considered a nonresident alien. For example, you are not allowed the standard deduction, you cannot file joint returns, and you cannot claim a dependent unless the dependent is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limits on the deductions and credits you can claim.

If you are a Puerto Rico resident for the entire year, you can exclude all income from sources within Puerto Rico (except amounts paid for services performed as an employee of the United States or any United States agency) from your total income. If you file your income tax return on a calendar year basis and have no withheld income in 2024, you must file your return and pay your tax by June 16, 2025. You must also make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by June 16, 2025. You cannot file a joint return or make joint estimated tax payments. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident alien, see Spouse as a Nonresident Alien Considered a Resident Alien for Chapter 1. If the income you earn is subject to withholding, your U.S. income tax return will be due by April 15, 2025. You must also make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by April 15, 2025. For information about withholding and estimated tax payments, see Chapter 8.

If you are a bona fide resident of American Samoa for the entire year, you may exclude all income from sources within the American Samoa (except amounts paid for services performed as an employee of the U.S. Government or any agency of the U.S. Government). Employees of the Government of American Samoa are not considered employees of the U.S. Government or any agency of the U.S. Government for purposes of this exemption. For more information about this exemption, see Form 4563 and Publication 570 (English).

You must calculate your income and file a tax return on the basis of the fiscal year, which is the 12-month period ending on December 31. If you have not established a fiscal year, your tax year will be the calendar year. The calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have established a fiscal year that is 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a year that has 52 or 53 weeks and you are considered a U.S. resident in any year of that fiscal year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at any time during that fiscal year.

Tax identification number (TIN) is provided on tax returns, reports, and other tax documents. For individuals, this is the social security number (SSN). If you do not have and are not eligible for an SSN, you must apply for an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN). An employer identification number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietor and have employees or a qualified retirement plan. You must provide a TIN if you are: A nonresident alien having effective U.S. source income at any time during the tax year; A nonresident alien having a U.S. office or place of business at any time during the tax year; A nonresident alien spouse who is considered a resident alien, as discussed in Chapter 1; or Any other nonresident alien filing a tax return, an amended tax return, or a claim for refund (but not a statement).

Generally, you can obtain a SSN if you have been legally admitted to the United States as a permanent resident or under other immigration status that allows you to work in the United States. If you do not have a SSN, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to determine if you are eligible for a SSN. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 800-772-1213 (for the deaf or hard of hearing, call TTY 800-325-0778).

If you have an F-1, M-1, or J-1 visa, see SSA Publication 05-10181, available at SSA.gov/Pubs/10181.html (English) for more information about the documents you must provide to prove your immigration status.

If you have an ITIN, enter your ITIN in any place that requires you to provide a SSN on your tax return. If you do not have a TIN and are not eligible for a SSN, you must file an application for an ITIN. To learn more about how to do this, see Form W-7 (English) and instructions. If you are eligible for an ITIN and your application is complete, you will usually receive a letter from the IRS with your ITIN within 7 weeks. If you have not received an ITIN or other letter within 7 weeks after filing your application, call the IRS toll-free number at 800-829-1040 to request the status of your application if you are in the United States. If you are outside the United States, call 267-941-1000 (not a toll-free number). An ITIN is only for tax purposes. It does not give you the right to receive Social Security benefits or change your employment or immigration status under U.S. law. In addition to the requirement that a non-U.S. person must provide an ITIN and is not eligible for a SSN, you must file a Form W-7 for a non-U.S. spouse or dependent who is eligible for tax benefits and is not eligible for a SSN. More information about obtaining an ITIN is available in the Form W-7 Instructions and at IRS.gov/ITIN.
Foreign residents may file tax returns in the same way as U.S. citizens. See our forms instructions or Publication 501 (English) for more information on filing status.

You may be eligible to be a head of household if you are not married or considered to be unmarried at the end of the tax year and you must pay more than half of the cost of maintaining your home for you and a qualifying person. You must be a resident alien for the entire tax year. For this purpose, you will be considered unmarried if your spouse is a nonresident alien at any time during the year and your spouse does not elect to be treated as a resident alien, as discussed in Chapter 1 under Nonresident alien spouse treated as a resident alien.

Foreign nationals who are married to a non-U.S. citizen or non-U.S. resident usually must use the Foreign Income or Business Income Schedule to report their income from U.S. sources separately when determining the tax on their actual income from business or trade in the U.S.

Foreign nationals who are married and living apart from their spouse for the last 6 months of the year may be able to file as single. See Form 1040-NR instructions to see if you qualify. A U.S. citizen is defined in the section below in this topic. Foreign nationals who are married and living in the U.S. may not be able to file married and joint. However, a foreign national who is married to a U.S. citizen or a U.S. resident alien may be able to be treated as a resident alien and file married and joint on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For information on these options, see Chapter 1. If you do not elect to file married and joint, file Form 1040-NR and use the married and joint tax tables or the married and joint tax calculator.

Individuals, although not U.S. citizens, are considered U.S. citizens for purposes of U.S. government. In addition, U.S. nationals also include U.S. Samoans and residents of the Northern Mariana Islands who choose to become U.S. nationals instead of U.S. citizens.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you haven't remarried by the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a surviving spouse and use the joint tax rate. To learn more about surviving spouse filing status, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse in the Filing Status section of the 2024 Form 1040–NR instructions.

You cannot file as head of household if you are a nonresident alien at any time during the tax year. However, if you are married, your spouse may be eligible to file as head of household if: Your spouse is a nonresident alien or U.S. citizen for the entire tax year; You elect not to be treated as a nonresident alien; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this filing status, as discussed earlier in Nonresident alien.
Foreign real property or trust holdings using Form 1040-NR must use Schedule W in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to determine tax on actual income from U.S. business or trade.

You must report each item of income subject to tax in accordance with the rules in chapters 2, 3, and 4. For a nonresident alien, this includes income from sources within and without the United States. For a nonresident alien who is a U.S. citizen or resident alien, this includes income that is effectively connected with the conduct of a trade or business in the United States (subject to graduated rates) and income that is not effectively connected with the conduct of a trade or business in the United States (subject to a flat 30% or lower rate under a treaty).

Foreign residents and temporary residents may claim similar deductions on their US tax returns. However, temporary residents usually can only claim deductions related to actual income from business or trade in the US.

You may claim deductions for actual combined taxable income (ECTI). Generally, you cannot claim deductions related to non-combined taxable income with business activity in the United States. Except for a few per-item deductions discussed in the following section, you can only claim deductions within the scope related to actual combined taxable income.

You may deduct all necessary expenses incurred in the course of business or trade in the United States that are related to the income from the business or trade. For more information about other business expenses, see Business Expenses (English).

If you paid interest in 2024 on a qualified student loan, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. Generally, you can claim the deduction if you meet all the requirements. This deduction is taken on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To figure the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). For more information, see Publication 970 (English).

If you have actual trade or business income from U.S. sources, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualified trade or business income, plus 20% of your qualified REIT dividends and qualified public partnership income (PTP). For more information, see Line 13a in the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). For more information about deducting qualified trade or business income, see Form 8995 (English), Form 8995-A and the forms and instructions related to them.

You may deduct losses incurred from trades you enter into to make money and are not insured against, etc. in relation to income that is commingled with your business or commercial activity in the U.S.

If you are a qualified educator in 2024, you can deduct up to $300 as a qualified education expenses adjustment on your 2024 tax return for expenses you paid or incurred during 2024 for professional development courses, books, supplies (not supplies for health or physical education classes), computers (including software and related services), and other supplementary materials you use in your classroom. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040. Allowable expenses include payments or expenses during 2024 for protective equipment, disinfectants, and other supplies used to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

If you made traditional IRA contributions in 2024, you may be able to deduct your IRA contributions. However, to do so, you must have compensable income from a U.S. trade or business. Form 5498 will be sent to you by June 2, 2025, reporting all your traditional IRA contributions for 2024. If you are covered by a qualified retirement plan (pension, 401(k), 403(b), SIMPLE, SEP, etc.) at work or through self-employment, your IRA deduction may be reduced or eliminated. However, you can still make traditional IRA contributions even if you can't deduct them. If you make non-deductible IRA contributions in 2024, you can report them on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication 590-A (English).

You must include all interest income you received or credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce this amount by any penalty you must pay when you withdraw money from your savings account before maturity. However, if you had interest income from business or trade in the United States during the year, you may deduct the penalty charged by the bank on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

You must give the SSN (or ITIN) of any dependents you list on Form 1040-NR. If you don't give an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents (Dependents) section of your return, or if you give an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be allowed. SeeNumber identification in the introduction.

If you are a non-resident alien, your eligible dependents include your eligible child or eligible spouse. A child must meet five tests to be an eligible child. A spouse must meet five tests to be an eligible spouse. For more information, see Form 1040 instructions. If you don't provide an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents section of your return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be allowed. See Identification numbers in the previous section.

If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada or a U.S. citizen, you can claim each dependent who meets certain requirements. Residents of Mexico or Canada or U.S. citizens must use the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent. See Publication 501 (English) for these rules.

Foreign nationals who are permanent residents of South Korea (not government employees of South Korea) may claim their children as dependents. In addition to using the same rules as US citizens to determine who is a dependent, under the tax treaty on income tax signed with South Korea, children must live with the foreign national resident in the US at some point during the tax year.
Students and apprentices in eligible trades who are entitled to benefits under Article 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty may claim a dependent if they meet the same requirements as US citizens.

You have a dual-status year of taxation when you are both a resident alien and a nonresident alien in the same year. Dual status does not refer to your nationality; dual status only refers to your tax residency in the United States. When determining your U.S. income tax liability for a dual-status year, many different rules will apply at different times during the year you are a U.S. resident and at different times during the year you are a nonresident. The most common dual-status years are the year of entry and the year of departure. See Foreign persons with dual status in Chapter 1. If you are married and you elect to be treated as a nonresident spouse of a resident alien as explained in Chapter 1, then the rules in this chapter do not apply to you for that year.

If you are a nonresident alien on the last day of the tax year and file a return on a calendar year basis, you must file your return no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year (but see MOTHER , in the back of this publication). If you file a return on a noncalendar year basis, or file a return no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. In either case, file your return to this address for nonresident aliens who are dual citizens of the United States and another country shown on the back of the instructions for Form 1040. If you are a nonresident alien who is a resident alien on the last day of the tax year and file a return on a calendar year basis, you must file your return no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year if you received earned income. If you file a return on a noncalendar year basis, file your return no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. If you did not receive earned income and file a return on a calendar year basis, you must file your return no later than June 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. If you file a return on a noncalendar year basis, file your return no later than June 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. In all cases, mail your return by mail to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you are sending a payment with your return, mail your return by mail to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the regular due date for filing your return falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the due date will be the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday.

You must file a tax return for each tax year, which is the 12-month period ending on December 31. If you have not established a tax year, your tax year will be the calendar year. The calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have established a regular tax year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a year with 52 or 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any year of that tax year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at any time during that tax year.

In a year in which you are a nonresident alien, you must pay tax on all income. Income from sources outside the United States is taxable if you receive it as a nonresident alien. Income is taxable even if you earn it as a nonresident temporary resident or if you become a nonresident temporary resident after receiving and before the end of the year. In a year in which you are a nonresident temporary resident, you pay U.S. income tax on income from sources in the United States and income from certain foreign sources is considered effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business. The rules for considering income from foreign sources as effectively connected are discussed in Chapter 4, Foreign Income. Income from sources outside the United States that is not effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business will not be taxable if you receive it as a nonresident temporary resident. This income is not taxable even if you earned it as a nonresident alien or if you became a nonresident alien or a U.S. citizen after receiving and before the end of the year. Income from sources in the United States is taxable whether you receive it as a nonresident temporary resident or a nonresident alien, unless it is exempt from U.S. taxation by the Internal Revenue Code or a tax treaty provision. Generally, treaty provisions apply only to a portion of a year in which you are not a U.S. resident. However, in certain cases, treaty provisions may apply when you are a nonresident alien. See Chapter 9 for more information. When determining which income is taxable to the United States, you must consider U.S. tax exemptions, as well as reduced rates and exemptions under a tax treaty between the United States and a foreign country. For more discussion of tax treaties, see Chapter 9.

View the 1040NR Guide to see if you qualify. U.S. citizens are individuals, even though they are not U.S. citizens. U.S. citizens include U.S. Samoans and residents of the Northern Mariana Islands who choose to become U.S. citizens instead of U.S. citizens.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you may claim a dependent on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. You may be eligible for additional deductions and credits if you have a qualifying dependent. See the instructions for Form 1040 or the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English) for more information. If you are a U.S. citizen or Canada or Mexico resident, you may claim a dependent under the same rules as U.S. citizens. If you are a U.S. resident alien or Indian citizen, see Chapter 5.

All income during the time you are a resident and all income that is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business during the time you are not a resident, after allowed deductions, will be combined and taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. Non-effectively connected income from a U.S. trade or business during the time you are not a resident is taxed at a flat rate of 30% or less under the treaty. You do not receive any deductions for this income.

In a year when you are a nonresident alien, 85% of your Social Security benefits (and the equivalent of your railroad retirement benefit) are taxable at a 30% rate, unless you are exempt from tax or subject to a lower rate under a treaty. See Tax Rate 30% in Chapter 4). In a year when you are a resident alien, a portion of your Social Security and an equivalent portion of your railroad retirement benefit are taxable at a graduated rate if your adjusted gross income plus one-half of this benefit exceeds a certain base amount. Use the Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Guide for Form 1040 to help you determine the taxable portion of your Social Security and railroad retirement benefit in a year when you are a resident alien. If you receive Social Security benefits while you are a nonresident alien, SSA will send you a Form SSA-1042S showing your combined benefits for the year and the tax withheld. You will not receive a separate report of the benefits received during the time you are a nonresident and a resident in the United States. Therefore, it is important that you keep careful records of these amounts. You need this information to complete your return correctly and calculate your tax liability. If you receive a railroad retirement benefit while you are a nonresident alien, the Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) will send you a Form RRB-1042S, Statement of Nonresident Alien Income and Taxes Withheld and/or a Form RRB-1099-R, Railroad Retirement or Pension Income. If your legal residence or tax status changes during the tax year, you may receive more than one form.

As a dual-status nonresident, you can generally claim the same tax benefits as a resident alien. There are some restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are discussed here, along with a brief explanation of the tax benefits that individuals generally claim. You cannot claim education credits, EIC, or the credit for the elderly or disabled, unless you are married and you choose to be treated as a resident alien for the entire 2024 tax year by filing a joint return with your spouse, who is a U.S. citizen or resident alien, discussed in Chapter 1.

If you have paid or are liable to pay income tax to a foreign country on income from foreign sources, you may be able to claim a foreign tax credit. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you generally must file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, see Form 1116 Instructions and Publication 514 (PDF).

You may be eligible for this credit if you pay someone to care for a qualifying child under age 13 or a qualifying dependent who is disabled or your spouse who is disabled, so you can work or look for work. Foreign citizens with dual status and who are married only may claim this credit if they file a joint return discussed in Chapter 1 or if they are a married person living apart. Child care and dependent care expenses that qualify for the credit in any tax year may not be more than the earned income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication 503 (English) and Form 2441.

A child is always considered to be your own child. A child is a child for whom you are entitled to claim a child tax credit. If you do not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or amended 2024 tax return. If the child does not have a valid SSN to work issued before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for the child but you can claim the credit for another dependent for the child. See Dependent credit below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and instructions to figure the credit.

Dependents other than children are eligible for the child tax credit. A qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or foreign national who is a U.S. resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extensions).

You may be eligible for a credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a special needs child, regardless of whether you have any qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return. Foreigners with dual citizenship and who are married may claim the credit only if they elect to treat their spouse as a resident alien for purposes of the credit as discussed in Chapter 1 or if they are married and living apart (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the instructions for Form 8839).

You can also report as tax payments made on US income taxes paid, considered paid or withheld from your income. These options include: Withheld taxes from US-source wages, Withheld taxes from other US-source income other than wages, Estimated tax payments made with Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and Tax payments made with Form 1040-C at the time of departure from the US.
The U.S. tax return that you must file as a dual citizen depends on whether you are a resident alien or a nonresident alien at the end of the tax year.

You must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR if you are a dual-status taxpayer who becomes a U.S. resident during the year and are a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year. Write “Dual-Status Return” on the top of your tax return. Attach a statement with your tax return to report income for a period of the year when you were not a U.S. resident. You can use Form 1040-NR as a statement. However, make sure you write “Dual-Status Statement” on the top of the statement.

You must file Form 1040-NR if you are a dual-status taxpayer who renounced your U.S. citizenship during the tax year and are not a U.S. resident for the last day of the tax year. Enter “Dual-Status Return (Return for a Dual-Status Taxpayer)” above the top of the return. Attach a statement with your return to report income in a year when you were a U.S. resident. You can use Form 1040 or Form 1040-NR as the statement. However, make sure you check the box for “Dual-Status Statement (Statement for a Dual-Status Taxpayer)” above the top of the return. If you renounced citizenship or terminated residency during the 2024 tax year, you may need to file a statement of renounced citizenship (Form 8854) with your return. For more information, see Renounced Citizenship in Chapter 4.

Any report must have the name, address, and tax identification number on it. You do not need to sign a separate report or the accompanying list of items. Your signature on the tax return applies to the report and the accompanying list of items.

Foreign residents must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR at the address shown in the instructions for Form 1040. The deadline for filing a tax return and paying all taxes due is April 15 of the following year that you will file a return (but see the PREVIEW above). Under U.S. immigration law, legal permanent residents must file a tax return as a resident. If they do not, they may be considered to have renounced their status and may lose their permanent resident status.

You must also file a return if you want: Request a refund of withheld tax or overpayment or Request a deduction or credit. For example, if you have no business activity in the United States but have income from real property that you choose to treat as actual income (discussed in Chapter 4) you must file a return on time to claim any allowable deductions for that income. To learn about which categories are due, see When to file to claim deductions and credits in the Filing time section below.

Even if you have left the United States and filed Form 1040-C upon departure, you must still file a U.S. income tax return annually. If you are married and both you and your spouse must file a return, each of you must file a separate return.

If a foreign person owns all DE domestic then the domestic DE will be considered a separate domestic company from the owner (foreign person) when considering the purposes of this provision under §6038A applicable to 25% domestic DE owned by a foreign person. Domestic DE owned by a foreign person must file Form 1120 with the Form 5472 attached by the due date (including any extensions) to file. The only information to be filed on Form 1120 is the name and address of the domestic DE owned by a foreign person and the items B and E in the first part. A domestic DE owned by a foreign person may have had reporting requirements prior to 2017 if this entity has conducted business or other activities in the United States that require reporting. See the Instructions for Form 5472 for more information and combine with the Form 5472 filed by the domestic DE. Also note that since the domestic DE is usually a transparent entity, the foreign person will file (or continue to calculate) any tax reporting of the domestic DE on Form 1040-NR. The DE (foreign or domestic) may also have separate reporting requirements related to employment or special tax. See §301.7701-2(c)(2)(iv) and (v).

If you are an employee and receive US income tax withheld pay, you usually will file your tax return by April 15 of the year following the tax year of your income. In 2024, file your tax return by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee receiving US income tax withheld pay, you must file your tax return by June 15 of the year following the tax year of your income. In 2024, file your tax return by June 16, 2025.

If you can't file your return by the due date, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the Instructions for Form 4868. In 2024, this time will be extended to October 15, 2025. If your normal due date is June 16, 2025, this date will be extended to December 15, 2025. You must request an extension before your normal due date. The automatic 6-month extension will not extend the time to pay your tax. If you don't pay your tax by the original due date of your return, you will owe interest on the unpaid tax and may be subject to penalties. See Form 4868.

Tax credits for the following items are not subject to this time limit. Tax credits already withdrawn. Special consumption tax credits on certain uses of gasoline and special fuels. Tax credits paid by a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT on long-term capital gains not distributed.

If your activity in the United States is restricted and you do not believe that you have actual income from business or trade in the United States in the year, you may file a protective return (Form 1040-NR) by the due date explained above. By filing a protective return, you will preserve your right to claim deductions and credits in the event that it is later determined that some or all of your income is actually income from business or trade in the United States. You do not have to report any actual income or deductions on the protective return, but you must state the reason for filing the protective return. If you believe that some of your activity results in actual income, file a return reporting that income and the related deductions before the regular due date. To preserve your right to claim deductions or credits from other activities, attach a statement to the return, explaining that you want to preserve your right to claim deductions and credits if it is later determined that the other activities result in actual income. You may follow the same procedure if you believe that you are not liable for United States taxes under a United States tax treaty. Make sure that you also complete Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) to report the income and deductions on the return.

The IRS may waive the filing requirement if you determine that based on the facts and circumstances, you have acted reasonably and in good faith in failing to file a U.S. income tax return (including a protected return) and you cooperate with the IRS in determining the amount of U.S. income tax liability for the tax year for which you did not file a return.

If you do not submit a payment, file Form 1040-NR at the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 . If you submit a payment, file your tax return by mail to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303

Report all income from sources in the United States, as well as income from other sources, on your tax return. To learn about filing a U.S. Virgin Islands tax return, contact the U.S. Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue. If you are a U.S. Virgin Islands resident who is actually a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entire tax year and work temporarily in the United States, you must pay U.S. Virgin Islands income tax and file a U.S. Virgin Islands income tax return at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802 . If you find a change in your income, deductions, or credits after you file your return by mail, file Form 1040-X. Also use Form 1040-X if you should have filed Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR or vice versa. If you correct Form 1040-NR or file a corrected return, enter “Amended (Adjusted)” above and attach the corrected return (Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, or Form 1040-NR) to Form 1040-X. Generally, an amended return requesting a refund must be filed within 3 years from the date you filed your return or within 2 years from the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. A return filed before the due date is considered filed on the due date.
You may need to file a form to report certain foreign income or assets or currency transactions.

Civil and criminal penalties will be imposed if not reporting, reporting with incomplete or significant errors or reporting falsehoods or fraud. Moreover, all money or monetary instruments may be seized and confiscated.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of those assets exceeds the filing threshold (the “reporting threshold”). The reporting threshold is different depending on whether you live in the United States, are married, or file a joint return with your spouse. Foreign financial assets are any financial accounts maintained by a foreign financial institution and within the scope of being held to invest any stock, securities, or other interests in a foreign corporation and any financial instrument or contract with a foreign issuer or partner that is not a U.S. person. You may be subject to a penalty if you are required to file Form 8938 but do not file or if you report less than the tax benefit from any transaction related to a foreign financial asset that is not reported. You can learn more about filing Form 8938 in the Instructions for Form 8938 (English).

If you don't file your tax return and pay your tax before the due date, you may have to pay a penalty. You may also have to pay a penalty if you report a significant amount of tax underpayment, file a fraudulent return, or fail to provide your TIN. If you provide false information on your tax return, you may have to pay a civil penalty for fraud.

The existence of significant authority to handle taxes on a subject depends on the facts and circumstances. Court decisions, Treasury regulations, tax court decisions, tax procedure, notices and declarations issued by the IRS and published in the Tax Court Bulletin relating to similar or like cases to yours will be considered.

To fully disclose the treatment of a position, use Form 8275, Disclosure Statement. You must also have a reasonable basis for treating the position as you have treated it. In the case of a significant reduction in tax, only positions that meet the requirements of Revenue Procedure 2024-44, available at IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (English) (or the next version) are considered to be fully disclosed on your return. Revenue Procedure 2024-44 does not consider the effect of changes in the tax law effective in tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a reference to a line in this revenue procedure is affected by such a change and requires additional disclosure, the taxpayer may be required to file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, Disclosure Statement under the Rules, until such time as a subsequent revenue procedure or guidance is issued to comply with the rules. A complete and accurate disclosure of the tax position on Form 1120, U.S. Corporate Income Tax Return, or Form 1120-S, U.S. Income Tax Return for an S Corporation, will be considered to be the filing of Form 8275 or Form 8275-R with respect to the tax position. However, the filing of Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be considered to be the filing of Form 1120 or Form 1120-S. Use Form 8275-R to disclose positions or tax positions that are contrary to the rules.

You will not be liable for a penalty if you give a good (reasonable) reason for your handling of an item. You must also show that you acted in good faith. This does not apply to a transaction that is not economic.

You may be liable for penalties if you file a tax refund or credit claim with errors. The penalty is equal to 20% of the amount not allowed in the claim, unless you can show that you have a reasonable cause for filing the claim. However, any amount not allowed due to a transaction that lacks economic substance will not be considered a reasonable cause. The penalty will not be imposed on any part of the claim that is not allowed due to accuracy or fraud.

You may be subject to a penalty of $5,000 if you file a false return or other false information return. A false return is a return that does not contain enough information to determine the correct amount of tax or contains information that clearly indicates that the amount of tax you reported is not correct. To learn more about false returns and false information returns and the list of positions that are determined to be false, visit IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (tiếng Anh) (or subsequent versions). You will be subject to a penalty if you file this type of return based on a false position or seeking to delay or interfere with the administration of the federal tax laws. This includes changing or highlighting the preprinted language above the space provided for you to sign your name. This penalty is in addition to any other penalty provided by law.
If there is any tax underpaid on the return due to fraud, the penalty equal to 75% of the underpaid tax due to fraud will be added to your tax.
