If you file a false tax return, you will be subject to a penalty of 15% for each month or part of a month you file late, up to 75%.
If you file a return more than 60 days after the due date or the due date has been extended then the minimum penalty will be the lesser of $510 or 100% of the tax not paid.

You will be subject to a penalty of ½ of 1% (0.005) of the amount of the unpaid tax for each month or part of a month after the due date for filing the return. This penalty does not apply during the automatic six-month extension period of the filing deadline if you have paid at least 90% of your actual tax liability by the due date for filing and pay the balance when you file. The monthly penalty for non-payment of tax is one-half of the normal penalty of ¼% (0.0025 instead of ½%) if a payment arrangement is in effect for that month. You must file your return by the due date (including the extension) to qualify for this reduced penalty. If a notice of intent to levy is issued, the penalty will increase to 1% at the beginning of the first month that is at least 10 days after the date of the notice. If a notice and demand for immediate payment is issued, the penalty will increase to 1% at the beginning of the first month after the date of the notice and demand. This penalty may not exceed 25% of the amount of the tax you have not paid. You will not be subject to a penalty if you can show that you have a reasonable cause for not filing your return on time.

If both the penalty for not filing and the penalty for not paying (discussed in the previous section) apply in any month, the penalty for not filing of 5% (or 15%) will be reduced to the penalty for not paying. However, if you file more than 60 days after the due date or the due date has been extended, the minimum penalty will be less than $510 or 100% of the unpaid tax.

The penalty is equal to 20% of the amount of the underpayment. The penalty is equal to 40% of any part of the underpayment related to a non-economic transaction that is not disclosed or a foreign financial asset transaction that is not reported. The penalty will not be imposed on any part of the underpayment that is penalized for fraud, discussed in the next section.

The term “negligence” includes failure to make a reasonable effort to comply with the tax law or lack of reasonable care in preparing a tax return. Negligence also includes failure to keep complete books and records. You will not be subject to a penalty for negligence if you have a reasonable basis for your position or if you can show a reasonable basis and act in good faith.

You can avoid penalties for failing to comply with rules or regulations if you disclose on your return a view that has at least a reasonable basis. See Disclosure of view in the back of this report. This exception will not apply to a position that can be attributed to tax evasion. Also, this exception will not apply if you do not keep full records or provide evidence for the items in a reasonable manner.
You may be criminally prosecuted for acts such as: 1. Evasion; 2. Willful failure to file, pay, or report any tax due; 3. Fraud or false statement; or 4. Filing or preparing fraudulent returns.

This chapter discusses how to pay U.S. income taxes when you earn or receive income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is due immediately. There are two ways to pay immediately. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer can withhold income tax from your wages. Tax may also be withheld from some other income — including pensions, bonuses, commissions, and gambling winnings. In each case, the amount withheld will be paid to the Internal Revenue Service on your behalf. 2. Estimated tax. If you don't pay taxes through withholding or don't pay enough taxes that way, you may have to pay estimated tax. Business owners usually pay taxes this way. You may have to pay estimated tax if you receive income such as dividends, interest, rent, and royalties. Estimated tax is used to pay income tax, self-employment tax, and alternative minimum tax.

You must notify your employer that you are a resident alien or nonresident alien so that they can withhold the correct amount of tax from your wages. If you are a nonresident alien under the rules discussed in Chapter 1, you must file Form W-9 or a similar form with your employer. If you are a nonresident alien under those rules, you must provide your employer with Form 8233 or Form W-8BEN, which confirms that you are a nonresident alien, or Form W-4, which confirms that your wages are subject to withholding at the same rate as a nonresident alien or U.S. citizen. If you are a nonresident alien and receive income other than wages (such as dividends and royalties) from sources in the United States, file Form W-9 or a similar form with the withholding agent (usually the person who pays the income) so that they do not withhold tax on the income at a 30% rate (or lower under a treaty). If you receive this type of income as a nonresident alien, file Form W-8BEN with the withholding agent so that they withhold tax at a 30% rate (or lower under a treaty). However, if the income is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business, file Form W-8ECI.

The following discussion is generally only applicable to non-resident aliens. Tax withheld on non-resident aliens is generally similar to that on U.S. citizens. Wages and other compensation paid to non-resident aliens for services performed as an employee must be withheld at the same rate as for U.S. citizens and non-resident aliens. Thus, your compensation, unless excluded from the term “wages” by law or exempt from tax by treaty, must be withheld at the progressive rate.

If you are an employee and receive progressive deferred compensation, you must file Form W-4. Also, file Form W-4 to receive a fellowship or research grant in the amount of the payments for past, present, or future services and you are not claiming exemption from withholding on Form 8233 (discussed later in Tax-Benefit Income from a Treaty). These are services that you perform as an employee and are a condition for receiving a fellowship or research grant (or reduced tuition). Foreign residents must follow special instructions in Notice 1392 (English) when completing Form W-4 for compensation received as a personal service performer of a dependent in the United States. Compensation from personal services performed on behalf of others includes wages, fees, bonuses, commissions, scholarships, research grants, and similar amounts paid to an employee. To determine whether you need to increase or decrease withholding, use the IRS Withholding Estimator. See Withholding from Scholarships and Research Grants in the later section to learn how to complete Form W-4 if you receive a U.S. source fellowship or research grant that is not a payment for services.
If you are eligible for the benefits under Section 21(2) of the Tax Treaty between the United States and India, you may claim additional withholding on the standard deduction.

If you are a home-based employee, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, you may agree to voluntarily withhold income tax by completing a W-4 form for your employer. This agreement becomes effective when the employer accepts the agreement by beginning to withhold. You or your employer can terminate the agreement by giving the other party written notice.

If you are an agricultural worker on an H-2A visa, your employer does not have to withhold income tax. However, your employer will withhold income tax if you and your employer agree to do so. In that case, you must give your employer a completed W-4 form. You can find more information about non-withholding at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers (English).

Income from employment is generally exempt from US income tax under the income tax treaty. To learn about how to claim treaty income tax exemption, see Treaty Income in the following section. Wages paid to a US resident alien of Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or the US Virgin Islands may be exempt from withholding tax. The following sections will explain this exemption.

If you are a non-U.S. citizen resident alien and a U.S. or Puerto Rico resident alien of Samoa, your earnings from services performed in Samoa are generally not withheld, unless you are an employee of the U.S. or any U.S. agency in the U.S. at Samoa or Puerto Rico.

Non-U.S. residents who are U.S. Virgin Islands residents are actually not subject to U.S. income tax on income earned while working temporarily in the U.S. This is because the individual pays income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid being subject to U.S. withholding tax on income earned in the U.S., U.S. Virgin Islands residents should write a letter to their employer, in which they state that they are a U.S. Virgin Islands resident and that they expect to pay tax on all income to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive pension payments from the United States, the payments are generally subject to a 30% withholding tax rate (or lower under a treaty). However, you may be subject to a progressive tax rate on the pension income arising from services performed in the United States after 1986. You must file Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and then file with the withholding agent or payer before the income is paid to you or credited to your account.

Tip income you receive in the year for services performed in the United States is subject to United States income tax. Include it in your taxable income. In addition, tip income received while working for an employer, up to $20 or more per month, is subject to withholding tax at the progressive rate.

If you do not have an employer-employee relationship with the person for whom you perform services, your earnings from that service are subject to a 30% (or lower, if applicable, under a treaty) withholding tax rate. However, if you are engaged in business or trade in the United States during the tax year, your earnings from personal services as an independent contractor may be exempt from withholding tax in whole or in part if you enter into an agreement with the IRS regarding the required withholding amount. The agreement you enter into with the IRS regarding withholding on personal services as an independent contractor applies to payments made under the agreement after all parties agree to it. You must agree to file a tax return for the current tax year.

If you are an entertainer or athlete performing or participating in sporting events in the United States as a nonresident alien then you may file a CWA and then submit it to the IRS to get a withholding tax credit, as long as you meet certain requirements. In all cases, that credit will not reduce your withholding tax to a lower amount than your expected income tax liability. Use Form 13930 to file for a CWA for nonresident alien entertainers or athletes with total annual income in the United States of at least $10,000. Form 13930 can be faxed at 866–715–1507 or mailed to the following address. Central Withholding Agreement Program Internal Revenue Service 25520 Commercentre Dr. Lake Forest, CA 92630–8884 We have temporarily waived the income requirement for the form used when filing for a CWA. Form 13930-A is no longer available. When the exemption is effective, individuals with income under $10,000 may file for a CWA using Form 13930, How to File for a Central Withholding Agreement. For more information about how to file for a CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements (English). CWA requirements must be received by the IRS at least 45 days before the agreement is effective to ensure that it is in place before the trip begins or the first event occurs and must contain all the documentation specified in the instructions. If not, you will not be considered for a CWA. Exceptions will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

If IRS is satisfied with the information, IRS will determine your estimated tax on income for the tax year on your total net income from your business or trade in the United States. Business expenses necessary under the circumstances may be allowed if they are shown to be reasonable and necessary in the conduct of your business or trade. The Commissioner or his representative will send you a letter directly to your withholding agent, stating that the final amount of the compensation is exempt from withholding tax and the amount that may be paid to you without withholding tax. You must give two copies of the letter to your withholding agent and also attach a copy of the letter to your income tax return for the tax year in which the exemption is effective. For more information, see Publication 515 (English).

If you are a distributor of a tax-misclassified direct-selling company, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F) or if you have filed a tax return, file a claim for refund (Form 1040-X or Form 1120-F amended) to recover the tax misclassified amount. You must also attach to your U.S. income tax return or refund claim information supporting the refund claim, including but not limited to the following. A copy of Form W-2, Form 1042-S, or Form 1099 to show the tax misclassified amount. An explanation report showing the reason why the income reported on your Form W-2, Form 1042-S, or Form 1099 is not subject to U.S. income tax. A report listing all the dates you entered and left the United States during the tax year. If the compensation is compensation for more than one year, the report must list all the dates you entered and left the United States during each tax year the compensation is allocated. A copy of any document or record showing the number of days you were present in the United States during the years referred to. A report providing (a) the number of days (or less than a day if appropriate) that the personal services were performed in the United States in connection with the hiring, training, and support of lower-level distributors; and (b) the total number of days (or less than a day if appropriate) that the personal services were performed worldwide in connection with the hiring, training, and support of lower-level distributors. Any other relevant documents or records supporting the claim in which the tax misclassified amount is claimed.

Other income subject to withholding tax at 30% (or lower under a treaty) typically includes fixed or determinable income, such as interest (other than investment income), dividends, pensions, annuities, and gains from sales and exchanges, discussed in Chapter 4. This income also includes 85% of social security benefits paid to non-resident aliens.
Special rules for the deferral of income in partnerships, scholarships and research grants will be explained in the following section.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership, the partnership will retain tax on the actual distributive share of the partnership's ECTI from the partnership. The partnership may reduce the tax retention on your ECTI by considering certain deductions at the partner level. Generally, you must file Form 8804-C for this purpose. For more information, see the instructions for Form 8804-C. The rate of retention on the actual distributive share is usually the highest rate prescribed in section 1 (37%). However, the partnership may retain at the highest rate applicable to a specific type of income that may be allocated to you if you have provided the partnership with appropriate documentation. Long-term capital gains is an example of a specific type of income that is subject to the highest rate. Claim the tax deduction as a credit on your 2024 Form 1040-NR. The partnership will provide you with a report on Form 8805 showing the tax retention. A publicly traded partnership will retain distributions of actual distributive share of income. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a report on Form 1042-S.

No deductions are taken from qualified scholarships received by a degree candidate. See Chapter 3. If you are a foreign student or beneficiary who is a nonimmigrant in F, J, M, or Q status and you receive a grant or scholarship that is not fully exempt from U.S. tax, the withholding agent (usually the grantor) withholds at the 14% (or lower under a treaty) rate on the taxable portion of the grant or scholarship that is not a payment for services. However, if you are not a degree candidate and the grant does not meet certain requirements, the tax is withheld at the 30% (or lower under a treaty) rate. Any portion of a graduate student grant or scholarship that is a payment for services is subject to progressive withholding as discussed in the previous section on Withholding from Wages.
This includes expenses that will be claimed on your tax return. This includes IRA deductions discussed in Deductions in Chapter 5.

If you are a qualified student under Section 21(2) of the Income Tax Treaty between the United States and India, you may be eligible for a standard deduction. The standard deduction for 2023 is $14,600.

Complete the appropriate lines on Form W-4. Sign and date the form and then file it with the withholding agent. If you file Form W-4 to reduce or eliminate withholding on scholarships or fellowship income, you must file a U.S. income tax return to claim any deductions you claim on that form. If you are in the United States for more than 1 year in a tax year, you must attach a copy of your annual report with Form W-4 to show that you have filed a U.S. income tax return for the previous year. If you have not been in the United States long enough to be required to file a tax return, you must attach a copy of your report with Form W-4 to show that you will file a U.S. income tax return when required. After the withholding agent accepts Form W-4, withholding will be taken from your scholarship or fellowship income at the progressive rate applicable to your salary. Total income is reduced by the amounts claimed on Form W-4 and withholding is calculated on the remainder. You will receive a Form 1042-S from the withholding agent (usually the person who pays you the fellowship) showing the total amount of scholarship or fellowship income subject to withholding, less any withholding, tax rate, and withholding tax. Use this form to prepare your U.S. income tax return. For more information, see IRS.gov/FormW4.

If the tax treaty between the United States and your country of residence has a provision for exemption, or a reduced rate of tax, on certain types of income, you should inform the withholding agent of your foreign status to request treaty exemption or reduced rate of withholding. Generally, you do this by filing Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 with the withholding agent. File Form W-8BEN for income that is not income from personal services. File Form 8233 for income from personal services, which will be discussed next. If you are eligible for treaty exemption but do not file Form 8233 with your withholding agent to request treaty exemption, you still may be able to receive the benefit of the exemption by filing Form 1040-NR. Follow the instructions for line 1a of Form 1040-NR...

If you perform personal services as an employee or independent contractor and you request exemption from withholding on your personal service income under a tax treaty, provide Form 8233 to each withholding agent from which the amount will be withheld. Even if you file Form 8233, withholding agents may still withhold tax from your income. This is because the treaty-based exemption factors may not be determinable until after the tax year ends. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to recover any over withheld tax and provide IRS with evidence you are entitled to the treaty exemption.

Students, teachers, and researchers must attach the appropriate report shown in Appendix A (for students) or Appendix B (for teachers and researchers) at the end of this publication to Form 8233 and submit it to the withholding agent. For treaties not listed in the appendices, attach a report in a format similar to other international treaties. If you receive a scholarship or research grant, as well as personal services income, from the same withholding agent, use Form 8233 to request treaty-based withholding exemption for both types of income.

The full 30% withholding is mandatory for payments to a nonresident individual or foreign corporation for income from port (or television or other) receipts from music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment or sports events, unless the withholding agent has been specifically notified by IRS letter that withholding is not required. Depending on the calendar year in which the income is earned from the U.S., Form 13930 may be used to request a withholding reduction. Withholding may still be required even if the income is exempt from tax under the tax treaty. One reason for this is that the exemption from tax may be based on factors that cannot be determined until after the end of the tax year. We have temporarily waived the requirement for income on the form used when filing for CWA. Form 13930-A is no longer available. When the exemption is effective, an individual with income under $10,000 may file for CWA by using Form 13930, How to File for a CWA. For more information about filing for CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, visitIRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements (English). You will be required to pay U.S. tax at the time of departure from the U.S. on any income that you have misstated the treaty exemption for. For more details about the treaty terms applicable to compensation, see Publication 901 (English).

The buyer must file and pay the withholding tax within 20 days after the transfer by using Form 8288. This form is filed with IRS along with a copy A and a copy B of Form 8288-A. Copy B of this report will be stamped after IRS receives and forwards it to you (the seller) if the report is complete and includes TIN. You must file Copy B with your tax return to receive a deduction for the withheld tax. A stamped copy of Form 8288-A will not be provided to you if the TIN is not included on that form. IRS will send you a letter requesting you to provide TIN and instructions on how to obtain TIN. When you provide TIN to IRS, IRS will provide you with a stamped copy of Form 8288-A.
Requesting a refund of withheld tax and reporting on Form 1042-S, Form 8288-A or Form 8805 may require additional time to process. Allow up to 6 months for these refunds to be issued.

If you are a U.S. employee, you must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes in most cases. The tax payment contributes to your Social Security benefits. Social Security provides retirement, survivor, and disability benefits, as well as Medicare insurance for individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. In most cases, $168,600 of first-year earnings for services performed in the United States is subject to Social Security tax. All earnings are subject to Medicare tax. The employer withholds these taxes from each paycheck. The employer must withhold these taxes even if you do not intend to qualify for Social Security or Medicare benefits. You can claim a Social Security tax credit in excess of the amount withheld on your income tax return if you have multiple employers and the total amount withheld from your earnings in 2024 is more than $10,435.20. If any employer withholds more than $10,435.20, you cannot claim a credit for that amount. Request your employer to refund the excess. If your employer does not refund the excess, you can claim a refund by filing Form 843. Generally, Social Security and Medicare taxes of the United States apply to earnings for services performed as an employee in the United States, regardless of the employee's or employer's nationality or residence. In limited circumstances, these taxes apply to earnings from services performed outside the United States. The employer can tell you whether Social Security and Medicare taxes apply to your earnings. You cannot make voluntary payments if no taxes are due.

Generally, services performed by you as a nonimmigrant temporary resident in the United States under the categories (F), (J), (M), or (Q) of Section 101(a)(15) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are not covered by Social Security if the services are performed for the purpose for which you were admitted to the United States. This means that you will not be subject to Social Security and Medicare tax withholding on the money you receive for this service. These types of services are very limited and usually include only school work, training, and work in a financially difficult situation. Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from your wages for this service if you are considered an alien who is a permanent resident under Chapter 1, even if your nonimmigrant classification (“F,” “J,” “M,” or “Q”) remains the same.

If you are a non-immigrant student temporarily present in the United States, you are generally not allowed to work for pay or engage in business while in the United States. In some cases, students admitted to the United States in F-1, M-1, or J-1 status are permitted to work. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not withheld from the wages of employment, unless the student is considered a permanent resident. Any student who is enrolled and regularly attending classes at a school may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes on the wages of service performed for the school. USCIS allows students to work in F-1 status if the employment does not cause a U.S. citizen to be replaced. “Employment in the school” means employment at a location outside the school that is educationally related to the school. Employment in the school under the terms of a scholarship, research assistantship, or teaching assistantship is considered a part of the student’s educational program and is permitted by USCIS. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not withheld from the wages of employment, unless the student is considered a permanent resident. If the service performed by a non-immigrant student is not considered to have been performed for the purpose for which the student was admitted to the United States, Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from the wages of the service, unless the wages are exempt from tax under the Internal Revenue Code.

Foreign agricultural workers are exempt from withholding tax on wages earned while in the U.S. on an H-2A visa. You can find more information about the tax exemption at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers (English).

Self-employment tax is social security and Medicare tax for self-employed individuals. Non-U.S. residents are generally not subject to self-employment tax unless an international social security agreement in effect determines that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, CNMI, or American Samoa residents are considered U.S. residents for this purpose and must pay self-employment tax. You can find information about international social security agreements in the section below. Non-U.S. residents who are U.S. citizens are generally subject to self-employment tax on their self-employment income. However, non-U.S. residents who work for an international organization, foreign government, or instrumentality of a foreign government are generally not subject to self-employment tax on income earned in the United States. Self-employment income that you receive as a non-U.S. resident must be subject to self-employment tax even if the income is paid for services performed as a non-U.S. resident.

If you have both wages and self-employment income, the threshold for the additional Medicare tax on self-employment income will be reduced (but not below $0) by the amount of wages subject to the additional Medicare tax. Do not consider the loss of freelance work for the purpose of this tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay the additional Medicare tax if your total wages and self-employment income is more than $125,000 if married (you checked the box Spouse filed separately on page 1 of Form 1040-NR) or $200,000 if single or surviving spouse eligible (you checked the box Single or Qualifying surviving spouse on page 1 of Form 1040-NR). See Form 8959 and the separate instructions to determine if you must pay the additional Medicare tax. For more information about the additional Medicare tax, visit IRS.gov/ADMTfaqs (English).
If you must pay self-employment tax, you can deduct a portion of the self-employment tax you paid to figure your adjusted gross income. The deduction is figured on Schedule SE (Form 1040).

The United States has signed social security agreements, commonly called “totalization agreements,” with foreign countries to coordinate social security insurance and tax on workers employed in part or all of their working careers in one of these countries. Under these agreements, dual insurance and dual contributions (taxes) for the same work will be eliminated. These agreements usually ensure that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are paid only to one country. To view a list of social security international agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/status.html (English). When agreements with other countries go into effect, this agreement will be posted here. For more information about social security international agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html (English).

Under this agreement, you usually only have to pay social security tax in the country where you are working. However, if you are temporarily sent to work for the same employer in the United States and your regular pay is subject to social security tax in both countries, most agreements provide that you are entitled to social security benefits only in the country from which you were sent to work. To confirm that your pay is subject to foreign social security tax and is exempt from U.S. social security tax (including Medicare tax) under the agreement, you or your employer should request a certification from the foreign agency. This is usually the same agency that you or your employer pay foreign social security tax to. The foreign agency can tell you what information they need to issue the certification. Your employer should keep a copy of the certification because the certification may be needed to show why you are exempt from U.S. social security tax. Only pay that is paid on or after the effective date of the agreement can be exempt from U.S. social security tax.

The majority of the agreements provide that self-employed individuals are insured under the social security system of the country where they reside. However, under some agreements, you may be eligible for U.S. self-employment tax exemption if you temporarily transfer your business to the U.S. or from the U.S. If you believe that your self-employment income is only subject to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from foreign social security taxes, request a Certificate of Coverage from SSA See the link in the Notes above. This certificate will help you be exempt from foreign social security taxes. To prove that your self-employment income is only subject to foreign social security taxes and is exempt from U.S. self-employment taxes, request a Certificate of Coverage from the appropriate foreign agency.

This publication explains how to treat taxes on property damage, theft, and loss of money while in transit. Property damage occurs when your property is damaged by natural disasters such as storms, fires, car accidents, or similar events. Theft occurs when someone takes your property. Loss of money while in transit occurs when your financial institution goes bankrupt or goes out of business. This publication discusses the following topics. Definitions of property damage, theft, and loss of money while in transit. How to calculate your profit or loss. How to deal with insurance and other refunds you receive. Deduction limits. When and how to report property damage or theft. Special rules for damage in disaster areas.
For information about property subject to levy, see Involuntary Conversion (Non-voluntary Conversion) in Chapter 1 of Publication 544, Sales and Other Dispositions of Property.

Publication 584, Handbook on Damage, Disaster, and Theft (Assets Used for Personal Use), is now available to help you make a list of personal-use assets that are stolen or damaged, and to calculate your losses. This publication includes schedules to help you calculate your losses for your home and its contents, and for your motor vehicle. Publication 584-B, Handbook on Damage, Disaster, and Theft for Businesses, is now available to help you make a list of income-producing assets or business assets that are stolen or damaged, and to calculate your losses.

All three types of damage refer to federally declared disasters, but the requirements for each damage are different. A federally declared disaster is a disaster designated by the President of the United States to ensure federal government assistance under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a major disaster declaration, or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Loss of personal property due to a federal disaster is loss of or theft of personal property caused by a natural disaster declared by the federal government. Loss of personal property must occur in a state that has received a federal disaster declaration. If you suffer loss of personal property due to a federal disaster, you may be eligible for a loss of personal property deduction. If you suffer loss of personal property or theft of personal property that is not caused by a natural disaster declared by the federal government, it is not a federal disaster loss and you are not eligible for a loss of personal property deduction unless there is an exception. Theft loss incurred in a business transaction for profit may be eligible for deduction. See Note in the Deduction of Losses section, later.

Loss due to natural disasters is damage caused by natural disasters declared by the federal government and occurring in an eligible area for assistance under the President's declaration. Loss due to natural disasters must occur in a county eligible for assistance under the community or individual (or both). Loss due to natural disasters is not limited to personal use property and may be claimed for personal business or income-producing property and by corporations, S corporations and partnerships. If you suffer a loss due to a natural disaster, you may be eligible to claim a loss deduction and elect to claim a loss in a prior tax year. See Natural Disaster Loss, later.

Loss due to natural disasters includes loss of or damage to personal property caused by: A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Harvey Tropical Storm; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; The California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; and A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act and which occurred in 2018 and before December 21, 2019 and continues through January 19, 2020 (except for the California wildfires in January 2018 which received prior coverage under the policy) and A major disaster declared by the President under a Declaration of Major Disaster in the period from January 1, 2020 to February 10, 2025. At the same time, the disaster must have a period of occurrence beginning on December 28, 2019 and ending no later than January 12, 2024 and must end no later than January 11, 2025.

For tax years 2018 through 2025, if you are an individual, losses from damage to personal property are only deductible if the damage is from a federally declared disaster (loss from federal disaster). Personal property is not business or income-producing property. If the event causing you to suffer personal loss from disaster (not from a federally declared disaster) occurs before January 1, 2018, but the loss from the damage is not maintained until January 1, 2018 or later, the loss from the damage is not deductible. See When to report gains and losses, later, for more information about when a loss from damage is maintained.
Property damage caused by pets in the household is not allowed to be deducted as a loss from damage unless the requirements have been discussed in advance in Damage met.

Loss of property due to deterioration over time is not deductible as for loss due to damage. This is because the damage is caused by regular or normal operation, rather than from a sudden event. Here are some examples of deterioration over time. The gradual deterioration of a building due to normal weather and wind. Deterioration and damage to a hot water tank that exploded. However, carpet and curtains that rust and are damaged by water due to the explosion of the hot water tank are considered a loss. Most damage to property is caused by drought. To be deductible, damage related to drought generally must occur in a business or trade or in a transaction made for profit. Damage from termites. Wood, shrubs, or other plants are damaged or destroyed by fungi, diseases, insects, pests, or other pests. However, a sudden destruction due to the unexpected or unusual invasion of beetles or other insects may result in a loss of damage.

Because the personal losses from the disaster required by this special procedure are not caused by a federal declared natural disaster, they are only deductible up to the extent that the losses do not exceed the personal gain from the damage to you. If your property was damaged by the effects of the imported drywall installed in your home from 2001 to 2009, under a special procedure, you may deduct the amount you paid to repair the damage to your home and household items from the drywall. Under this procedure, you treat the amount you paid for the repair as a loss from damage in the year you made the payment. For example, the amount you paid to repair in 2024 is deductible on your 2024 tax return and the amount you paid to repair in 2023 is deductible on your 2023 tax return.

According to the purpose of this special process, “corroded drywall” is drywall that is identified as drywall with a problem using the two-step identification method issued by the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) and the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the interim guidance dated January 28, 2010 and amended by CPSC and HUD. The amended identification guidance and the repair guidance are available at CPSC.gov/en/Safety-Education/Safety-Education-Centers/Drywall-Information-Center (English).

The way you report your gains and losses depends on whether the asset is a business asset, an income-generating asset, or a personal-use asset.

Individuals report losses from income-producing property on Schedule A (Form 1040). Business and income-producing property losses are combined with business and income-producing property gains on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, please enter only the net gain or loss on your return in the line designated in Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this line will be line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)). In addition to that line, enter “Form 4684.” Partnerships and S corporations should see the instructions for Form 4684 to determine where to report gains and losses.

If your losses from business and income-producing property are more than the gains from these types of property, report the losses from business and income-producing property together with the total gains from business and income-producing property. Report net gain or loss as ordinary income or loss on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, report net gain or loss on your return at the line designated in Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this line will be line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)). Next to that line, report “Form 4684.” For individuals, report any losses from income-producing property on Schedule A (Form 1040). Partnerships and S corporations should refer to Form 4684 to find where to report gains and losses. If your losses from business and income-producing property are less than or equal to the gains from these types of property, report the net amount on Form 4797. You may also have to report gains on Schedule D (Form 1040) depending on whether you have other transactions. Partnerships and S corporations should refer to Form 4684 to find where to report gains and losses.

If property that is held more than 1 year and is damaged or stolen is a depreciable asset, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income in the amount allowed or allowed to be deducted. You must figure the ordinary income part of the gain in Part III of Form 4797. See Depreciation Recapture in Chapter 3 of Publication 544 for more information about the recapture rules.

If you suffer a loss from damage or theft, you must deduct any insurance or other refund received, as well as any loss claimed, from your cost basis in the property. The result is your adjusted basis in the property. If you make one of the adjustments to cost basis described above, the amount you spend to repair the property to restore it to its condition before the damage occurs will increase your adjusted basis. Please do not increase your cost basis in the property by any qualified disaster loss payment (discussed earlier in Loss in a disaster area). See Adjusted Basis in Publication 551 for more information about the adjustments to cost basis.

Please submit your translation here.If you have a loss from damage or theft, you can deduct the loss as a business expense. If the loss is more than your business income for the year, you may have a net operating loss (NOL). You can use an NOL to reduce your tax for the next year. You don't have to be in business to have an NOL from damage or theft. For more information, see the instructions for Form 172.
The taking of money or property by fraud or false representation is theft if the act is illegal under the law of the state or locality.

For tax years 2018 through 2025, if you are an individual, losses from theft and damage to personal property are only deductible if the damage is attributed to a federally declared disaster (loss from federal disaster). An exception to the rule limiting the deduction for personal losses from theft and damage to those losses from federal disaster is applied when you have personal income arising from the damage. In this case, you may deduct personal losses from theft not related to a federally declared disaster within the limits that they do not exceed the personal income arising from your damage.

You cannot deduct as a theft loss the decrease in market value of stock purchased on the open market for investment if the decrease is due to accounting fraud or other illegal misconduct by the company's officers or directors who issued the stock. However, you can deduct it as a capital loss on investment in Schedule D (Form 1040) if the stock is sold or exchanged or becomes totally worthless. For more information about selling stock, worthless stock, and capital losses on investments, see chapter 4 of Publication 550.

Money or property simply disappearing is not theft. However, a random or accidental loss of property may be considered a damage if it is the result of a determinable event that is sudden, unexpected or unusual. Such determinable events have been previously identified in the Damage section.

If you are eligible to use the 2009-20 Tax Procedure, as amended by the 2011-58 Tax Procedure, and choose to follow the procedures in the instructions, first complete Part C of Form 4684 to determine the amount to be entered in line 28, Part B. Skip lines 19 through 27, but you must complete lines 29 through 39 of Part B, if appropriate. Part C of Form 4684 replaces Schedule A in the 2009-20 Tax Procedure. You do not need to complete Schedule A. For more information, see the tax law and tax procedures above, and the instructions for Form 4684. If you choose not to follow the procedures in the 2009-20 Tax Procedure, as amended by the 2011-58 Tax Procedure, you may claim theft loss by completing lines 19 through 39 of Part B, if appropriate. Note that the personal use property limitation for the 2018 through 2025 tax years does not apply to property losses that generate income, such as losses from Ponzi-type investment programs.
You can no longer claim any mixed deductions, including deductions for losses from the deposit of money in bankrupt or insolvent financial institutions.

You can elect to deduct losses from deposits as if they were losses from damage for any year in which you can reasonably estimate the amount of the deposits lost in a bankrupt or insolvent financial institution. The election is generally made on the tax return you file for that year and applies to all your deposit losses in that financial institution for that year. If you treat the loss as a loss from damage, you cannot treat the same loss as a nonbusiness bad debt when it becomes worthless. However, you can deduct a nonbusiness bad debt for any loss in excess of the amount you estimated as a ordinary loss or loss from damage. Once you make the election, you cannot change it without the consent of the IRS.

If you are an individual, loss due to damage to property used for personal purposes is only deductible if the damage was caused by a federal declared natural disaster. An exception to the rule limiting personal loss by disaster and theft to loss by federal disaster applies when you have personal gain from the damage. Since loss of cash on deposit is not caused by a federal declared natural disaster, you can deduct loss of cash on deposit as personal loss by disaster only to the extent that it does not exceed your personal gain from the damage of your own.
For more information, see Deposit in Insolvent or Bankrupt Financial Institution (Ký gửi tại tổ chức tài chánh bị vỡ nợ hoặc phá sản) in Publication 550.

If you recover any amount of the deduction taken as a loss in a prior year, you may have to include the recovered amount in your income for the year of recovery. If any part of the original deduction did not reduce your tax for the prior year, you do not have to include that part of the recovery in your income. For more information, see Recoveries in Publication 525.

For loss of damage, you must be able to present all of the following. That you are the owner of the property, or if you rent the property from someone else, you must be responsible under the contract with the owner for the damage. Type of damage (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and when it occurred. The damage is a direct result of the damage. Is there a claim that can reasonably expect a reasonable recovery.

If you receive insurance or other refund, you must subtract the refund from your calculation of your loss. You will not have a loss from damage or theft for amounts that you are refunded. If in the year there is a refund claim with a reasonable prospect of recovery, the loss will not be carried over until you are certain that you will receive the refund. If you expect to be refunded all or part of the loss, you must subtract the expected refund from your calculation of your loss. You must deduct from your loss even if you have not received the payment until the next tax year. See Refunded amounts after deducting loss, later.

If your property is insured, you should file a timely insurance claim to be reimbursed for your loss. If you do not file a claim, you cannot deduct the entire amount of your unrecovered loss as a loss from theft or damage and you can only deduct the portion of the loss that is not covered by your insurance policy. Typically, non-covered losses (for example, a level of coverage exclusion) do not follow this rule.
The most common form of reimbursement is payment from insurance for stolen or damaged property. Other forms of reimbursement will be discussed in the next section. See more at Form 4684 Instructions.

If you receive money from your employer's emergency relief fund and use that money to repair or replace property that is required to be deducted from your loss, you must include that money in your loss calculation. Only include the amount you use to replace your own property that is destroyed or damaged.

Do not deduct from your loss of property damage your loan proceeds used to repair or replace property that you are claiming a loss for. If you have a federal loan that has been discharged (waived), see Federal Loan Discharged, later, in Disaster Loss in the Area.

This section explains the adjustments you may need to make. See Announcement 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B. 796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5 (English)).

However, if any part of the original loss deduction did not reduce your tax for the year before, do not include that part of the refund in your income. You should not recalculate your tax for the year you requested the deduction. See Recoveries in Publication 525 to figure out how much of the refund you must include in your income.

If your refund is more than the adjusted original cost of the asset, you have a gain. This is true even if the FMV reduction of the asset is less than your adjusted original cost. If you have a gain, you may have to pay tax on that amount, or you may be able to defer reporting the gain. See Calculating gain, later.

There are two ways you can deduct losses from damage or theft of inventory, including items you hold for sale to customers. One way is to deduct damage by increasing the cost of goods sold by properly reporting the beginning and ending inventory. Do not report this loss again as an accident or theft loss. If you suffer damage from increasing the cost of goods sold, include any insurance or other refunds you receive for the damage in your gross income (after deducting expenses and taxes). The other way is to deduct the loss separately. If you deduct separately, reduce the beginning inventory or purchases by the affected inventory items by making a reduction adjustment to beginning inventory or purchases. Deduct the loss by the refund you receive. Do not include the refund in your gross income. If you do not receive the refund by the end of the year, you may not report the loss if you have a reasonable expectation of recovery.
If you are liable for damage to the leased property, your damage is the amount you must pay to repair the property, minus any insurance or reimbursement you receive or expect to receive.
Generally, if a disaster or theft involving more than one asset, you must calculate the damage to each item separately. Then, combine the damages to determine the total loss from the damage or theft.
FMV is the price at which you could sell your asset to a willing buyer when neither you nor the buyer is under any compulsion to sell or buy and both know all relevant facts.
The FMV of the asset immediately after theft is considered to be 0 because you no longer have the asset.

Stolen property that is recovered is the stolen property and then returned to you. If you recover property after having deducted theft loss, you must adjust your loss by using the lower of the adjusted original cost of the property or the FMV reduction from the time just before the property was stolen to the time the property was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate your total loss for the year the loss was deducted. If the loss recalculated is less than the loss you deducted, you generally must report the difference as income in the year of recovery. But report only the difference that exceeds the amount of your theft loss tax benefit.

You can use the valuation you used to obtain a federal loan (or to secure a federal loan) as a result of a declared federal disaster to determine your disaster loss. To learn more about disasters, see Lost in a disaster area, in the back.

Repairs to damaged property are not a part of loss from damage. This is also true for cleanup costs after a disaster. However, you can use cleanup or repair costs after a disaster as a measure of the FMV decrease if you meet all of the following conditions. The repair has actually been made. The repair is necessary to put the property back in its pre-damage condition. The amount spent on the repair is not excessive. The repair is limited to the damage. Because of the repair, the value of the property after the repair is not more than the value of the property before the damage.

Restoration costs to return the property to its original state after damage may indicate a reduction in FMV. You can measure your damage by the amount you spend on the following. Remove destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, minus any remaining value you receive. Prune and other measures to preserve damaged trees and shrubs. You must replant to restore the property to its original value before the damage.

The books published by different car organizations list the manufacturers and models that may be useful in determining the value of your car. You can use the retail value for your car listed in the book and adjust it for factors such as mileage and condition to determine its value. These values are not official, but they can be useful in determining relative value and making suggestions for comparables to buy and sell in your area. If your car is not listed in the book, determine its value from other sources. The dealer's offer for your car when trading in an old car for a new one is usually not a measure of the car's true value.

To calculate the amount of loss due to damage and theft, you usually must determine the FMV reduction of the property lost or damaged by using a professional valuation or the cost of repair that you actually incur. However, the “safe harbor” methods in Revenue Procedure 2018-08, 2018-2 I.R.B. 286 and Revenue Procedure 2018-09, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290 allow you to determine the FMV reduction in other ways. If you are an individual, loss due to damage to property used for personal purposes is only allowed to be deducted if the damage was caused by a federally declared disaster. An exception to the rule limiting the deduction for personal loss due to damage and theft is applicable if you have a personal gain from the damage. In this case, you may deduct personal loss due to non-disaster-related damage in an amount not exceeding the amount of your personal gain from the damage.

The IRS has issued Revenue Procedure 2018-08, 2018-2 I.R.B. 286, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02_IRB#RP-2018-08 (English), which provides safe harbor methods that you can use to calculate the amount of loss from damage and theft of your personal residence and personal property. If you qualify and use the safe harbor method described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08, IRS will not audit you. Using the safe harbor method described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 is not mandatory.

The safe harbor alternative cost method for disaster losses is a federal disaster declaration. You can determine the FMV of your personal property in the disaster area immediately before the disaster occurs to determine the amount of your loss from damage or theft. To use the safe harbor alternative cost method, first you must determine the current cost to replace your personal property with a new asset and then reduce that amount by 10% for each year you own the property. See Personal Property Valuation in IRS Publication 2018-08. If you choose to use the safe harbor alternative cost method, you must use it for all of your personal property, with certain exceptions specified in IRS Publication 2018-08. Each of these safe harbor methods must follow additional rules and exceptions. For more information, see IRS Publication 2018-08.

Loss is determined by subtracting the value of any repairs provided by a third party for free (for example, work done by volunteers or through donations) from the value of the port. In addition, subtract the amount of any insurance, refund or other compensation you have received.

The 'safe harbor' repair cost estimation method allows you to determine the FMV reduction of your personal residential real property by using less than two repair cost estimates provided by independent licensed contractors. The estimates must clearly itemize the costs to restore your property to its pre-loss condition. The 'safe harbor' repair cost estimation method is limited to losses of $20,000 or less.

The least cost repair method allows you to determine the FMV reduction of your residential real property used for personal purposes based on a written estimate of the necessary cost to repair your property to its condition immediately before the damage occurred. You must keep records showing how you determined the damage. The least cost repair method is available for losses of $5,000 or less.

The flood insurance safe harbor method allows you to determine the FMV reduction for residential real estate used for personal purposes based on estimated damage in the flood insurance claim prepared by the landlord or flood insurance company. These claims must state the estimated damage that you must bear due to the property being damaged or destroyed.

If damage occurs in an area declared a federal disaster and is caused by a disaster, you can use the safe harbor method for the contractor or the disaster loan valuation method. Under the safe harbor method for the contractor, you can use the contract price for the repair specified in the contract prepared by an independent licensed appraiser to determine the FMV reduction of the residential real property used for personal purposes. This safe harbor method does not apply unless you must comply with a binding contract you and the contractor execute, which lists the expenditures to restore the residential real property used for personal purposes to its pre-disaster condition.

According to the safe harbor method of valuation for disaster loans, you can prepare a valuation, test to determine your estimated disaster loss, to obtain a federal disaster loan or a federal loan guarantee to determine the FMV reduction of your residential real property.

Personal effects generally include tangible personal property that is owned by an individual and which is subject to loss by damage or theft if it is not used in trade or business. Personal effects do not include a property that may maintain or increase in value over time or other types of property. For more information, see IRS Revenue Procedure 2018-08. The safe harbor method for personal effects is the least cost method and the safe harbor method for replacement cost for natural disasters declared by the federal government.

Under the least cost method, you can accurately estimate the FMV loss of personal property. You must keep records describing the personal property affected and your method of estimating the damage. This method is limited to losses of $5,000 or less.
Generally, you should not consider the following items when trying to set up FMV deductions for your assets.

The cost of protecting your property from damage or theft is not included in the loss from damage or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or storm protection is not included in the damage. If the property is business property, these costs are deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from damage or theft, please add the cost of these improvements to the original cost of the property. An example is the cost of a levee to protect against flooding.

You cannot add to the original cost of the property or deduct as a business expense any expenses incurred in relation to eligible disaster relief payments (discussed in the next section on Disaster losses).

Additional expenses resulting from damage or theft, such as medical treatment for personal injuries, temporary housing or rental car costs, are not considered part of your loss from damage or theft. However, they may be deducted as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is business property.
The replacement cost of stolen or damaged property is not included in the loss from damage or theft.

Please do not consider the sentimental value when determining your loss. If a family portrait, heirloom or memento is damaged, destroyed or stolen, you must base your loss on the FMV of the item, your loss is limited to the original cost adjusted for inflation.

Loss of value of property because the property is located in or near an area of disaster or a place where disaster may recur is not taken into consideration. You have a loss only because of the loss of the property itself. However, if your home is located in an area of disaster declared by the federal government, see Loss in an area of disaster, later in this section.

Photographs taken after the damage occurs will be helpful in determining the condition and value of the property after it has been damaged. Photographs showing the condition of the property after it has been repaired, restored, or replaced may also be helpful. Valuation is used to determine the amount of FMV reduction due to damage or theft. See Valuation in the previous section, in Calculating FMV Reduction — Items to Consider for information on valuation. The cost of taking photographs and appraisals are used as evidence of the value and condition of the damaged property and are not considered part of the damage. They are costs to determine your tax liability. For tax years 2018 through 2025, they can no longer be deducted as other listed deductions.

Your investments in real property that you own are the original cost of that property. For property purchased, the original cost is usually the cost to the purchaser. For property acquired by other means, such as by inheritance, as a gift, or by exchange not subject to tax, you must figure the original cost in a different way, as explained in Publication 551.

If you inherit property from a deceased person in 2010 and the executor of the deceased person's estate made an election under Section 1022 by using Form 8939, Allocation of Increase in Basis of Property Acquired from a Deceased Person, special rules relating to the basis of the property acquired from the deceased person will apply. The executor of the deceased person who died in 2010 may elect to apply the adjusted basis transfer treatment to property acquired from the deceased person. For more information about Section 1022 election, see Notice 2011-66, 2011-35 I.R.B. 184, available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#NOT-2011-66 (English). For guidance on the safe harbor election under Section 1022, see Revenue Procedure 2011-41, 2011-35 I.R.B. 188, available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#RP-2011-41 (English).

During the holding period of an asset, many events may occur that change your cost basis. Some events will increase your cost basis, such as adding or improving the asset permanently. Other events will decrease your cost basis, such as losses from earlier damage and depreciation allowances. After adding the increases and subtracting the decreases from the original cost, you get the adjusted cost basis. See Publication 551 for more information about computing the cost basis of an asset.

After calculating the amount of loss due to damage or theft of your own, you must determine how much of the loss you can deduct. Deduction of personal loss due to damage and theft of property used for personal purposes is limited. For tax years 2018 through 2025, personal loss due to damage and theft is only deductible to the extent it is caused by a federally declared natural disaster. Personal loss due to damage and theft caused by a federally declared natural disaster must follow the $100 per loss and 10% rules discussed below and will be covered in more detail in Section 2. The $100 and 10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. An exception to the rules above is the limitation on the deduction of personal loss due to damage and theft to the extent it is caused by a federally declared natural disaster if you have a personal gain from the loss in that tax year. In this case, you can deduct from your personal gain from the loss any loss due to damage that is not caused by a federally declared natural disaster. Any excess gain is used to reduce the loss due to a federally declared natural disaster. The 10% rule applies to any remaining loss due to a federally declared natural disaster. Business and income-producing property do not follow these rules. However, if the loss due to damage or theft relates to the home you use to conduct or rent a business, your loss deduction may be limited. See the instructions for Form 4684, Part B. If the loss due to damage or theft relates to property used in a passive investment activity, please see Form 8582, Limitations on Loss from Passive Investment Activities and the instructions.

After you have determined your loss from damage or theft of your personal property, as discussed above, you must reduce that loss by $100. This reduction applies to each total loss from damage or theft, including non-disaster losses declared by the federal government that are used to reduce your personal gain from your loss. There is no limit to the number of properties involved in an event. Only one $100 reduction is allowed.

Generally, events that are closely related in origin will cause single loss. Single loss is when loss is caused by two or more causes that are closely related, such as loss caused by wind and flooding caused by the same storm. A single loss can also damage two or more properties, such as a tornado damaging both your house and your car parked on the way.

If you and your spouse file a joint return, both of you are treated as one person for the $100 rule. Whether you jointly or separately own the property does not matter. If you and your spouse both suffer a loss from damage or theft at the same time, each of you must deduct $100 from your loss. This is true even if you jointly own the property. If one spouse owns the property, only that spouse may claim the loss on a separate return. If a loss from damage or theft occurs to property that you jointly own with your spouse, each of you may calculate your deduction only on half the loss on separate returns. Neither of you may calculate your deduction on the entire loss on a separate return. Each of you must deduct $100 from the loss.

If two or more individuals (not married filing jointly) suffer a loss of property held in common, the $100 rule will be applied separately to each individual. For example, if two sisters live together in a house that they jointly own and suffer a loss due to damage in the house, the $100 rule will be applied separately to each sister.

If you and your spouse file a joint tax return, both of you are treated as one person for the 10% rule. It doesn't matter whether you own the property jointly or separately. If you file a separate tax return, the 10% rule will be applied to each return in which the loss is reported.
If two or more individuals (not married filing jointly) suffer a loss of property held in common, the 10% rule will be applied to each individual.

If you have a gain from damage or theft of personal property, you must compare the total gain with your total damage. You must do this after you have subtracted $100 and any refunds from each damage but before you have subtracted 10% of AGI from your damage from federal theft. Gain from damage or theft does not include gain you choose to defer. SeeDefer gain , in the back of this book.

If your loss is greater than your determined gain, please subtract your loss from your gain and subtract 10% of AGI from the result. The remainder, if any, is a loss that is deducted from your personal use property. If your loss is not a federal declared disaster, please see Line 14 in the Instructions for Form 4684. A non-federal declared disaster loss can only be used to offset gain. If you have a qualified disaster loss, please see Line 15 in the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information.

If your profit is more than your losses, subtract your losses from your profit. The difference is considered capital gains and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to your gains. If your losses are not from a federally declared disaster, please see Line 14 in the Instructions for Form 4684.
Generally, you must calculate the loss for each item stolen, damaged, or destroyed. However, a special rule applies to real property used for personal purposes that you own.
To calculate the damage to the real estate used for personal purposes that you own, all activities of upgrading (such as buildings, landscaping and land with improvements) are considered.

Personal property is any property that is not real estate. If personal property is stolen, damaged, or destroyed by a disaster, you must figure your loss separately for each class of property. Then, add the separate losses together to figure your total loss. Subtract $100 plus 10% of AGI from the total loss to figure the loss deduction.

When a loss involves both real and personal property, you must calculate the loss separately for each type of property. However, you only need to apply a $100 deduction for the entire loss. Then, you apply the 10% rule to calculate the loss deduction.

When the property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for business or income-producing purposes, the loss deduction for damage or theft must be calculated separately for the personal use portion and the business or income-producing use portion. You must calculate each loss separately. When calculating each loss, you must allocate the total cost or FMV before and after the loss from damage or theft, as well as any insurance or other refund, between the business use and the personal use. The $100 and 10% rules apply only to the loss from damage or theft of the personal use portion of the property.
Bạn có thể sử dụng một số công cụ trực tuyến để dịch tài liệu của mình. Tuy nhiên, bạn nên biết rằng các dịch vụ này thường không chính xác và không đáng tin cậy.

The amount you receive includes any money plus the value of any property received minus any expenses you must pay to be repaid. This also includes any repayments used to pay off a mortgage on a home or a right to use property to pay off a debt on a property that is damaged, destroyed or stolen.

If you have realized a gain from the sale of your main home, you can generally exclude the gain from your income, treating it as if you had sold or exchanged your home. You may be able to exclude up to $250,000 of gain (up to $500,000 if you are married and file a joint return). To exclude the gain, you generally must have owned and used the property as your main home for at least 2 of the 5 years before it was destroyed. To find out about this exclusion, see Publication 523. If you have more gain than you can exclude but buy a substitute property, you may be able to defer reporting the excess gain. See Deferring gain, later.

Generally, you must report your income as income in the year you receive the refund. However, you do not have to report your gains if you meet certain requirements at the same time you choose to defer reporting your gains under the rules explained in Deferring gains in the next section. To learn about how to report gains, see How to report gains and losses, in the next section. If you have a gain from a loss or theft of personal property that you choose to defer reporting (as explained in the next section) and also have a loss from a different theft or loss of personal property, do not include the deferred gain in your calculation of your theft or loss deduction.

If you receive a refund in the form of a similar asset or related to a service or use of a damaged or stolen asset, you must report any gain on the asset. Your adjusted cost base in the new asset is usually the same as your adjusted cost base in the asset it replaces. You generally must report a gain on a stolen or damaged asset if you receive a refund in the form of a non-similar asset. However, you can choose to defer reporting a gain if you acquire a similar asset or related to a service or use of a stolen or damaged asset during a specific replacement period discussed later. You can also choose to defer reporting a gain if you acquire control (at least 80%) of a corporation that owns a similar asset or related to a service or use of that asset. See Control of a corporation, later. If you receive a gain from a damaged asset, you can choose to defer reporting the gain if you spend the refund on repairing the asset. To defer reporting all gains, the cost of the replacement asset must be at least equal to the refund you receive. If the cost of the replacement asset is less than the refund, you must include the gain in your income as long as it does not exceed the unused refund.

For losses and thefts described in (3) above, profits cannot be offset by any loss when determining whether total profits exceed $100,000. If the property is owned by a partnership, the $100,000 limit will apply to the partnership and each partner. If the property is owned by an S corporation, the $100,000 limit will apply to the S corporation and each shareholder.
This rule does not apply if the related party has received property from the unrelated party within the permitted time period to replace the destroyed or stolen property.

If the tax filer dies after having earned a profit but has not yet purchased a substitute asset, then the profit must be reported for the year in which the deceased earned the profit. The executor of the estate or the heir of the money resulting from damage or theft cannot postpone reporting the profit by purchasing a substitute asset.

You must purchase a substitute asset with a specific purpose of replacing the damaged or stolen asset. Assets you receive from gifts or inheritance are not eligible for this purpose. You do not need to use the refund you receive for your old asset to purchase a substitute asset. If you use the insurance company's refund for other purposes and borrow money to purchase a substitute asset, you can still postpone reporting the gain if you meet the remaining requirements.

If you have a gain from the refund received that is more than the amount you can exclude from your income (see House destroyed in Calculating gain, in the previous section), you can defer reporting the excess gain by purchasing a similar or related substitute property or service. If you want to defer reporting any excess gain, the substitute property must be at least as valuable as the amount you received from the destroyed property minus the amount of gain you can exclude. Also, if you defer reporting any part of your gain under these rules, you are treated as having owned and used the substitute property as your principal residence during the period you owned and used the destroyed property as your principal residence.

You must deduct the deferred tax profits from the original cost of your replacement property (the cost of it). In this way, the tax on the profits will be deferred until you dispose of the replacement property.
The substitute property must be similar or related in service or use to the property it replaces.

The tree (not the land) that you buy with the proceeds from the sale of the tree that was destroyed by a disaster (such as a strong wind, an earthquake, or a volcanic eruption) that meets the criteria for a substitute asset is a substitute asset. If you buy the tree within the substitute asset period that is specified, you can postpone reporting the gain.
Nếu bạn là chủ sở hữu-người sử dụng, “tương tự hoặc có liên quan về dịch vụ hoặc việc sử dụng” nghĩa là tài sản thay thế phải hoạt động giống như tài sản mà nó thay thế.

Special rules apply to replacement property related to your principal residence (or household goods) that is damaged or destroyed in a declared federal disaster area. For more information, see Disaster-related home sale profits, later in this section.

If you are a landlord-investor, “similar or related in service or use” means any substitute property must have a service or use relationship to you that is similar to the property it replaces. You decide this by determining all of the following. Does the property provide the same service to you? What is the nature of the business risk involved in the property? What does the property require of you in the way of management, service and relationship with your tenant/landlord.
