You can substitute property by acquiring control in a company that owns property similar or related to your property in terms of services or use. You can postpone reporting all of your income if the shares giving you control are worth at least as much as the amount received (refund) for your property. You have control if you own shares with at least 80% of the total voting power of all classes of voting shares and at least 80% of the total number of shares of all other classes of shares.

If two or more assets are of the same type, please allocate the deduction to each asset in proportion to the adjusted original cost of all assets in that type. The adjusted original cost of any single asset may not be less than 0.

To postpone declaring profits, you must buy a substitute property for a certain period of time. This is called the substitute period. The substitute period is calculated from the day your property is damaged, destroyed or stolen. The substitute period is usually 2 years after the end of the first tax year in which you earn any profit.

For a principal residence (or personal property) located in a disaster area declared by the federal government, the replacement period usually ends 4 years after the end of the first tax year in which you earn any gain. See Disaster Loss, in the back of this publication.

The extension is usually limited to a period of no more than one year. High market value or scarcity of substitute assets is not sufficient basis for granting an extension. If your substitute assets are under construction and you clearly demonstrate that construction cannot be completed within the substitute period, you may be granted an extension of time.

You may request an extension of time to replace by faxing your written request to 877-477-9193 or mailing your request to Internal Revenue Service, 985 Michigan Ave., Stop 16, Detroit, MI 48226. The return must include a cover sheet with the following information. Date. Your name, title, telephone number, and address. Attention: SB/SE Field Examination Area Director [State of your residence]. Subject: 1033 Extension Request for Replacement Period of Involuntarily Converted Property. Number of pages being faxed (including the cover sheet).

Your request must include all details describing the reason for the extension. Include: 1. Name, address, and tax identification number of the taxpayer, 2. A detailed description of the assets being converted, 3. The date of the conversion of the assets, 4. The adjusted original cost of the assets being converted, 5. The date and amount of any payments received, 6. A copy of the return with the non-voluntary conversion of assets with the related deferred gain, and 7. A description of the actions taken to replace the assets.

You delay reporting income from damage or theft by reporting your election on your tax return for the year in which you receive the income. You have income in the year you receive insurance or other refunds that result in that income. If a partnership or corporation owns property that is stolen or destroyed, only the partnership or corporation can elect to delay reporting income.

You should attach a report to your tax return for the year in which you had a gain. This report should include the following. Date and details of the loss or theft. Any insurance or other refund you received from the loss or theft. How you calculated the gain.

If you acquire alternative assets before filing your tax return for the year in which you realize the gain, your return also should include details of all the following. Alternative assets. Deferral gains. Adjusted basis reflecting the deferral gains. Any gain you are reporting as income.

If you intend to acquire a replacement property after filing your tax return for the year in which you have a gain, your return must also state that you are choosing to replace the property during the mandatory replacement period. You should then attach a separate return with your tax return for the year in which you acquire the replacement property. This return must contain detailed information about the replacement property. If you acquire a portion of the replacement property in one year and a portion in another year, you must file a separate return for each year. This return must contain detailed information about the replacement property acquired in that year.

When you have acquired a substitute asset that meets the requirements you have specified as a substitute asset in a schedule attached to your tax return, you cannot substitute it with another substitute asset that meets the requirements. This is true even if you acquire another asset during the substitute period. However, if it is found that the original substitute asset is not a substitute asset that meets the requirements, you may (during the substitute period) substitute it with a new substitute asset that meets the requirements.

You must file an adjusted return (using Form 1040-X for individuals) for the tax year you received the gain in one of the following situations. You do not have a replacement property in the required replacement period that has been extended. On this adjusted return, you must report the gain and pay any tax due. You have a replacement property in the required replacement period, but at a lower cost than the amount you received for the damage or theft. On this adjusted return, you must report the portion of the gain that cannot be postponed and pay any tax due.

The time period for determining the tax rate for any income that ends after 3 years from the date you notify the local IRS office director of any of the following. You have replaced the property. You do not intend to replace the property. You have not replaced the property during the replacement period.

If you receive an insurance or other refund that is more than the adjusted original cost of a property that is destroyed or stolen, you have a gain from the damage or theft. You must include the gain in your income for the year you receive the refund, unless you choose to defer reporting the gain, as explained earlier.

Generally, you can deduct losses from damage that cannot be recovered only in the tax year the damage occurred. This is true even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until a year later. (However, please see Loss in a Disaster Area in the section later for an exception.) You can deduct losses from theft that cannot be recovered only in the year you discover your property was stolen. If, in the year the damage occurred, there is a reasonable prospect of recovery, the loss will not be carried over until you know relatively certainly that you will not receive the recovery. If you are uncertain whether any part of your loss from damage or theft can be recovered, do not deduct that part until the tax year in which you have a basis for being reasonably certain that part will not be recovered.

If you rent property from someone else, you may deduct a loss for that property in the year that your liability for the loss is determined. This is true even if the loss occurred or your liability for the loss was paid in a different year. You cannot deduct until your liability under the rental agreement can be determined with reasonable certainty. Your liability under the rental agreement can be determined when a claim for refund is settled, a judgment or decision is rendered, or a claim is denied.

This section discusses special rules for losses in areas declared a federal disaster. This section contains information on when you can deduct losses, how to report losses, how to handle a home in a disaster area, and the tax filing deadlines that may be postponed. This section also lists the phone numbers of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (see Contacting the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in the back.) Disaster losses are losses that occur in an area declared a federal disaster. Disaster areas include areas that are eligible for community or individual (or both) assistance. A federal disaster declaration includes a major disaster or an emergency declaration. The list of areas eligible for community or individual (or both) assistance under the Stafford Act is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster (English).

If you are reporting a loss due to damage or theft caused by a federal disaster, check the box and enter the DR or EM disaster designation number provided on line 1 of Form 4684 for 2024. A list of federal disasters and their respective FEMA disaster numbers is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster (English). The FEMA disaster number includes the letters “DR” and four numbers, or the letters “EM” and four numbers. For example, enter “DR-4832” in the appropriate boxes for Tropical Storm Helene (English).

Your home will only be considered unsafe if it meets both of the following conditions. Your home becomes significantly more dangerous after a disaster than before a disaster. The danger comes from the significantly increased risk of future destruction by a disaster.

At the time you elect to deduct your loss in the prior year, unless a loss from a qualified disaster discussed in the preceding section has been discussed, you must calculate the loss under the general rules for loss from damage, as if it occurred in the year before the disaster occurred.

You should adjust your deductions on Form 1040. The instructions for Form 1040 show how to make this adjustment. Explain your adjustments and attach Form 4684 to present your method of computing your loss. See Calculating Loss in the introduction. If the property is damaged or destroyed and is not a business asset and you did not list your deductions on your original return, first determine whether a loss deduction at this time will be more advantageous to you if you list the deductions. It will be more advantageous to list the deductions if the total of the loss deduction and any other deductions listed is more than your standard deduction. If you list the deductions, please attach Schedule A (Form 1040) or Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) and Form 4684 to your adjusted return. File Form 1040-X to compute your tax again to find out how much refund you are entitled to.

You should keep records that prove your loss. You don't need to attach them to your adjusted return. If your records are destroyed or lost, you may have to rebuild them. Information about rebuilding records is available at IRS.gov/Newsroom/Reconstructing-Records-After-a-Natural-Disaster-or-Casualty-Loss (English) or see Publication 3067, IRS Disaster Assistance - Federal Disaster Declaration (English).

Preparing Form 1040-X will be easier if you have a copy of your prior year tax return. If your return was prepared by a tax preparer, that person may be able to provide you with a copy of your return. If not, you can obtain a copy by filing Form 4506 with the IRS. There is a fee for each tax return requested. However, if your principal residence, business headquarters, or tax records are located in a federal disaster area, the fee will be waived. Write the specific disaster on the top of Form 4506 (for example, “Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene (Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene)”).

If your inventory loss is eligible as a loss due to disaster and is attributed to a federal declared disaster in an area designated by FEMA for public or individual (or both) assistance, you may choose to deduct the loss on your return or on an amended return for the prior year. However, reduce your opening inventory for the year of loss to avoid reporting the loss again in inventory.

If a portion of your federal disaster loan is canceled under the Stafford Act, that portion will be treated as a refund for the damage. The cancellation reduces your loss deduction by the amount of your loss.

Please do not include any disaster relief grants received under the Stafford Act in your income if the grant is made to help you meet necessary expenses or pressing needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation, or burial expenses. Do not deduct loss of property damage or medical expenses if they are separately reimbursed by these disaster relief grants. If loss of property damage is separately reimbursed by the grant, and you receive a grant after you take a loss deduction for property damage, see the Grant received after taking a loss deduction in the previous section. Stafford Act unemployment compensation is taxable income.

The grant that a business receives under a state program with the purpose of reimbursing the business for losses incurred by property damaged or destroyed by a natural disaster is not excluded from gross income under the social security benefit exclusion, as a gift, as a disaster relief payment that is qualified (as explained in the following paragraph), or as a contribution. However, the business may elect to defer reporting the income earned from the grant if it purchases eligible replacement property within a certain time period. See Deferring Income, in the preceding section, to understand the rules that apply.

Disaster relief payments are also included in the amount of money paid to individuals affected by a disaster from the federal, state, or local government related to the disaster declared by the federal government. These payments must be drawn from the government fund, based on the need of the individual or family, and not be a payment for services. Payments to businesses are usually not eligible.
You cannot deduct or credit, or increase the basis in your property, related to any expenses that you were reimbursed by a qualified fire-loss payment.

The disaster relief payments eligible under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective April 15, 2005) are not included in income. These are payments you, as the owner of the property, receive to reduce the risk of future property damage. You cannot increase the basis in the property, or deduct or report as a deduction any expenses related to those payments.

Generally, if you sell or transfer property, you must report any gain or loss for tax purposes unless the property is your principal residence. You report the gain or deduct the loss on your tax return for the year you realized the gain. (You cannot deduct a loss for personal-use property unless the loss was caused by a disaster, as discussed in the previous section.) However, if you sell or transfer property to the federal, state, or local government or to a federally recognized Indian tribe under a risk-mitigation program, you may choose to defer reporting the gain if you purchase a qualifying replacement property within a specified time period. See Deferring Gain, in the previous section, to understand the rules that apply.

The IRS can postpone the filing deadline for up to 1 year for taxpayers affected by a federal disaster. The filing deadlines that the IRS can postpone include the deadlines for filing income tax returns, filing sales and use tax returns, and filing employment tax returns; paying income tax, sales and use tax, and employment taxes; and making contributions to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA. If any filing deadlines are postponed, the IRS will publish the tax relief in your area and publish a notice and, if necessary, publish it in the Tax Code, Tax Procedures, Notices, Announcements, or other guidance in the IRS Bulletin. Visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief to find out if your filing deadline is postponed in your area.

If the IRS delays the filing deadline, the following taxpayers are eligible for the delay. Any individual whose principal residence is located in a disaster area as defined in the following section. Any business or sole proprietorship whose principal place of business is located in a disaster area. Any individual who is a disaster relief employee of the federal government or a recognized charitable organization and is engaged in disaster relief activities in the disaster area. Any individual, business or sole proprietorship who needs to maintain records to meet the delayed filing deadline, provided that the records are maintained in the disaster area. The principal residence or principal place of business of a business need not be located in the disaster area. Any estate or trust that needs to maintain tax records to meet the delayed filing deadline, provided that the records are maintained in the disaster area. The surviving spouse of a taxpayer who is eligible for the delay. Any individual, business or sole proprietorship that is not located in the disaster area but needs to maintain records to meet the delayed filing deadline and those records are located in the disaster area. Any individual who dies or is injured in the disaster area. Any other individual the IRS determines to be affected by the federal declared disaster.
This is a disaster area declared by the federal government, where the IRS has decided to postpone the filing deadline up to 1 year.

Some taxpayers who are affected by a declared federal disaster that occurs after December 20, 2019, may be eligible for a mandatory 60-day extension of certain filing and payment deadlines, such as filing or paying income, sales, and employment taxes; and making contributions to traditional or Roth IRAs. The period of extension begins on the earliest disaster occurrence date specified in the disaster declaration and ends on the 60th day after the earliest disaster occurrence date or the date of the declaration, whichever is later. For more information about disaster relief in your area, including extensions, visit IRS National News.
IRS can reduce interest and penalties on underpaid income taxes within the time period of the filing deadline extension.

You can get information from FEMA by visiting DisasterAssistance.gov (English), or by calling the following phone numbers. These phone numbers are only activated after a federal disaster is declared. 800-621-3362. Call 711 and provide the TRS dial 800–621–3362 if you are deaf, hard of hearing, or speech impaired.

A year of disaster is a year in which you suffer a loss caused by a disaster declared by the federal government. Usually, a loss from a disaster is carried over for the year of the disaster. However, a loss from a disaster can also be carried over for one year after the disaster occurs. For example: If there is a refund claim with a reasonable prospect of recovery, no part of the loss that can be claimed is carried over until there is a basis for being able to determine whether you will receive a refund.

Generally, you must deduct losses from damage in a disaster year. However, if you suffer a loss from damage caused by a disaster declared by the federal government to have occurred in a disaster area (or both), you may choose to deduct the damage on your tax return or an amended return for the tax year before the disaster year. If you make this election, the damage is treated as having occurred in the year before. The list of disaster areas (or both) is available on the FEMA website at FEMA.gov/Disaster (English). You must make the election to claim a loss from damage in a disaster year before the later of 6 months from the normal due date for filing your original tax return (not extended) for the disaster year or the due date for filing your 2023 return, including extensions, to claim a loss from damage in 2024.

If you filed a return for the previous tax year, you can elect to claim a loss from disaster on your income of that year by filing an amended return. For individuals, file an amended return using Form 1040-X. (see How to Report a Disaster Loss on Form 1040-X, later.) To make this election, complete Part I of Schedule D of Form 4684 for 2023 and attach it to your 2023 original or amended return to request the deduction for the disaster loss. You must make the election to claim a loss from a disaster in the year before no later than 6 months from the normal due date for filing your original return (not extended) for the disaster year. For individuals filing a calendar year return, the deadline to make the election to claim a 2024 disaster loss on your 2023 return is October 15, 2025. See the 2023 Form 4684 Instructions for more information about how to report these losses on your 2023 original or amended return. If you claimed a deduction for a disaster loss on your return for the disaster year and want to claim a loss from a disaster in a prior year, you must file an amended return to remove the disaster loss deduction from before or before the date you filed your return or amended return for the prior year, which included the deduction for the disaster loss. Claiming a qualified disaster loss on your prior year return may result in a lower tax for that year, which usually creates or increases a refund of money.

Complete Part II of Item D on Form 4684 for 2023 if you want to cancel your election of 2024 disaster year to deduct disaster losses declared by the federal government in the prior tax year. Attach the completed Form D to the amended return for the prior year (i.e., the tax return for the year with the disaster loss). The amended return with the purpose of canceling your election must be filed no later than 90 days after the due date for making the election and on or before the date you file any tax return or amended return for the year with the disaster loss. Your amended return (canceling your prior disaster loss election) must recalculate your tax liability because of the cancellation of the election. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes and penalties due because of the cancellation of the election.

Loss due to natural disasters includes personal injury from a disaster or theft of personal property caused by: A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Harvey Tropical Storm; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; The California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; and A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act and that occurred in 2018 and before December 21, 2019 and continues through January 19, 2020 (except for the California wildfires in January 2018 that received prior coverage). A major disaster declared by the President during the period from January 1, 2020 to February 10, 2025. In addition, the disaster must have a period of disaster beginning on or after December 28, 2019 and on or before December 12, 2024 and ending no later than January 11, 2025.

The alternative minimum tax replacement adjustment to the standard deduction cannot be applied retroactively to qualified disaster losses. See Taxpayers who must file Form 6251, Alternative Minimum Tax for Individuals, 2024, in the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information.

If your home is located in a disaster area declared by the federal government, you may postpone reporting any income you receive if you spend money to repair or replace your home. Special rules apply to replacement property relating to damage or destruction of your principal residence (or contents therein) if located in such areas. For more information, see Income from a home in a disaster area, before.

If your home is located in an area declared a federal disaster area, your state or local government may order you to tear down or move your home because it is no longer safe to live in due to the effects of the disaster. If this happens, consider the loss of value to be a loss due to damage from a disaster. Your state or local government must order you to tear down or move your home within 120 days after the area is declared a disaster area. Calculate your loss the same as for a loss of personal-use property. (see Calculating loss in the previous section.) To determine the FMV reduction, use the value of your home before you move or tear down as its FMV after the damage occurs.
EIC is a tax credit for certain people who work and earn less than $66,819. A tax credit means more money in your pocket. It reduces the amount of taxes you owe. EIC can also give you a refund.

No, you may be eligible for EIC even if you don't have qualifying children if you are at least 25 but under 65 and your earned income is less than $18,591 ($25,511 if married filing jointly). See Chapter 3.

If you can request EIC, you can request IRS to calculate your credit, or you can calculate it yourself. To calculate it yourself, you can complete a spreadsheet in the instructions for the form you file. To find out how IRS calculates your credit, see chapter 4.
Yes. You can use the Standard Assistant for EITC at IRS.gov/EITC to find out if you qualify for the credit. The Standard Assistant for EITC is available in English and Spanish.

Your AGI must also be less than the amount just listed that applies to you. To find out more, see Rule 1) and 15. Investment income. The maximum amount of investment income you can have and still get the credit is $11,600. See Rule 6 — Your investment income must be $11,600 or less.

Your AGI must be less than: $59,899 ($66,819 for married filing jointly) if you have three or more eligible children with valid SSNs, $55,768 ($62,688 for married filing jointly) if you have two eligible children with valid SSNs, $49,084 ($56,004 for married filing jointly) if you have one eligible child with a valid SSN, or $18,591 ($25,511 for married filing jointly) if you have no eligible children with valid SSNs.

If you are married, but qualify to file as head of household or as separate taxpayers under special rules for married taxpayers who do not live together (see Rule 3), and live in a community property state, your AGI includes your own salary and that of your spouse or domestic partner that you must include in your total income. This is different from community property rules applied under Rule 7.

To claim EIC, you (and your spouse if you file a joint return) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) no later than the filing deadline for your 2024 tax return (including extensions). Your eligible child must have a valid SSN on or before the filing deadline for your 2024 tax return (including extensions) in order for you to claim a higher EIC based on that child. If you have at least one child who is eligible for you to claim for EIC purposes, but that child does not have a valid SSN on or before the filing deadline for your 2024 tax return (including extensions), you may claim EIC for yourself if you are eligible. You may be eligible to claim a single EIC if you are eligible. To learn about how to complete Form 1040, Schedule 1, Line 17 if your child is eligible but does not have a valid SSN issued on or before the filing deadline for your 2024 tax return (including extensions), see Form 1040, Schedule 1, Line 17. A valid SSN for EIC unless it is issued after your 2024 tax return filing deadline (including extensions) or it is issued only for the purpose of applying for or receiving a federally-funded benefit and is not permitted to work. An example of a federally-funded benefit is Medicaid. If you, your spouse, or your child have a Social Security card with “Not valid for employment” printed on it and your immigration status has changed so that you, your spouse, or your child are now a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request SSA for a Social Security card that does not have the “Not valid for employment” notation.
If you are a US citizen when you receive your SSN, you have a valid SSN.
Please note that the translation should be accurate and correct.

If your SSN or your spouse's SSN is missing from your tax return or is incorrect, you may not receive EIC. If your SSN or your spouse's SSN is missing from your tax return because you or your spouse did not have a valid SSN on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extended filing periods) and you later receive a valid SSN, you cannot file an amended return to request EIC. However, if you or your spouse were issued an invalid SSN for EIC, but on or before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extended filing periods), you or your spouse are eligible to receive a Social Security card without the “Not valid for employment” printed on it, you may request EIC on your original or amended 2024 return even if the Social Security card is not updated before the filing deadline for 2024 (including extended filing periods).
You cannot claim EIC if instead of SSN, you (or your spouse if you file jointly) have an individual tax identification number (ITIN). ITIN is issued by IRS to non-citizens who cannot have SSN.

If you don't have a valid SSN on file or before the filing deadline for 2024 tax return (including any extensions), enter “No” in the dot-dot-dot box next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR). You can't claim EIC on the original return or an amended 2024 return.

If you are due to file a tax return and you still do not have a SSN, you can request an automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return. You can get an extension by filing Form 4868, Application for Automatic 6-Month Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. For more information, see the instructions for Form 4868. Instead of filing Form 4868, you can request an automatic extension by making an electronic payment by or before the due date.
If you are married, you usually have to file a joint return to qualify for EIC. However, there are special rules for separated couples.

If you are a nonresident alien for any part of the year, you cannot claim the EIC unless your filing status is married filing jointly. You can use this filing status only if your spouse is a U.S. citizen or a nonresident alien who is a resident alien and you elect to be treated as a U.S. resident alien. If you make this election, you and your spouse will be taxed on worldwide income. If you need more information about this election, get Publication 519. If you are a nonresident alien at any time during the year and your filing status is not married filing jointly, enter “No” in the dot at line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR). See Nonresident aliens and dual-status aliens in the Form 1040 instructions for more information, including information about making an election to treat your spouse as a nonresident alien or a dual-status alien who is a U.S. resident alien for the entire tax year.

You cannot claim EIC if you file Form 2555, Foreign Earned Income. You file this form to exclude foreign earned income from your total income, or to deduct or exclude the amount for foreign housing. Foreign country of residence is not the United States. See Publication 54 for more details.

You cannot claim EIC if your investment income is $11,600 or less. If your investment income is more than $11,600, you cannot claim this credit. Use Table 1 in this chapter to figure your investment income.

This credit is called the earned income credit because, to qualify, you must work and earn income. If you're married and filing a joint return, you meet the rule if at least one spouse works and has earned income. If you're an employee, earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer. Rule 15 has information will help you figure your earned income. If you're self-employed or a statutory employee, you'll figure your earned income on Schedule EIC B in the instructions for Form 1040.

Income earned includes all of the following types of income. 1. Wages, salaries, tips, and other income paid to employees. Income paid to employees is only income earned if it is taxable. Income paid to employees that is not taxable, such as some dependent care and adoption benefits, is not income earned. However, there is an exception to nontaxable combat pay that you can elect to include as income earned, as explained later in this chapter. 2. Net income from self-employment. 3. Total income received as an employee.
The wages, salaries, and tips you received when you worked are reported to you on Form W-2, in box 1. You should report this amount on line 1a of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

Other types of income not reported on Form W-2, in box 1, include home employee wages, unreported tip income to your employer, some Medicaid-exempt payments if you choose to include non-taxable payments in your earned income for EIC purposes, dependent care benefits taxed, employer-provided adoption assistance from Form 8839, Form 8919 wages and other earned income. You should report these on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, line 1b to 1h.

You can choose to include your non-taxable combat pay for the purpose of receiving EIC. Your non-taxable combat pay must be shown on your W-2 form, in box 12, with code Q. Including non-taxable combat pay in earned income may increase or decrease your EIC. For more information, see Non-taxable combat pay in Chapter 4.

Rental income or housing allowance provided to a minister as part of the minister's general salary is generally not taxable but is included in net self-employment income. For this reason, it is included in earned income for the purposes of the EIC (except in cases described in Form 4361 or Form 4029 approved in the following part).

You are a statutory employee if you receive a W-2 form on which box 13, “Statutory employee (Nhân viên pháp định)” is checked. You report your income and expenses as a statutory employee on Schedule C (Form 1040).

Benefits paid to you as a strike or closure benefit, including cash and the reasonable market value of other property (not a gift in kind), are generally taxable. If strike or closure benefits are taxable, they are generally earned income. You should report your taxable strike or closure benefits on line 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.
Each form approved is exempt from social security tax on a certain amount of income. Each form discussed here on what is earned income or not earned income to request EIC.

Whether you have Form 4361 approved or not, the money you receive to perform your ministerial duties as an employee is considered earned income. This includes wages, salary, tips, and other employee compensation that is taxable. If you have Form 4361 approved, housing allowance for housing expenses or non-taxable rental value of a home will not be considered earned income. Also, money you receive to perform your ministerial duties, but not as an employee, is not considered earned income. Examples include fees for performing weddings and compensation for speaking engagements.

Whether or not you have a Form 4029 approved, all tips, wages, commissions, and other employee compensation that is taxable is considered earned income. However, the amount you receive as a self-employed individual is not considered earned income. In addition, when calculating earned income, do not deduct any losses on Schedule C or F that were reported on line 1a through 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

If you are disabled and receive Social Security disability benefits from your employer's disability insurance program, these benefits are earned income until you reach your minimum retirement age. The minimum retirement age is generally the earliest age at which you can receive Social Security retirement or survivor benefits if you are not disabled. You must report your disability benefits as earned income on line 1h of your Form 1040 or 1040-SR until you reach your minimum retirement age. Starting on the day after you reach your minimum retirement age, your benefits will be taxed as retirement benefits and not as earned income. Report your taxable retirement benefits on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, line 5a and 5b.

The payments you receive from a disability insurance policy that you have paid for are not earned income. Whether you have reached the minimum retirement age or not. If the policy is administered by your employer, the amount may be shown in box 12 of your W-2 form with code J.

Examples of non-earned income include profits and dividends, pensions and annuities, social security and retirement benefits (including disability benefits), alimony and child support, social security benefits, workers' compensation benefits, unemployment insurance benefits (unemployment insurance), non-taxable nursing home payments, and veterans' benefits, including rehabilitation benefits. Do not include any of these in your earned income.
The money you receive for the services you perform while in prison is not earned income for the purposes of EIC.

The cash payments made to a recipient from a state or local agency that administers a work assistance program funded by the federal TANF program are not earned income for purposes of requesting EIC. These are payments made to a recipient in exchange for a certain type of work activity, such as (1) work experience activities (including home repair or public housing repair) if there is not enough work in the private sector, or (2) community service program activities.

If you are married, but are eligible to file as head of household or as separate returns for married couples who do not live together (see Rule 3), and live in a community property state, your income to qualify for EIC does not include any amount that your spouse earns that is considered to be yours under those laws. That amount is not income to qualify for EIC, even though you must include it in your total income on your tax return. Your income includes all the money you earn, even if part of it is considered to be your spouse's under the community property laws of the state where you live.

If you are a same-sex domestic partner registered in Nevada, Washington or California, the same rules apply. Your income to qualify for the EIC does not include any income your partner earns. Your income includes all income you earn. For more information, see Publication 555.
If you are receiving Social Security retirement or disability benefits at the time you receive any CRP payments, then your CRP payments are not earned income for which you can claim EIC.

The amount of non-taxable military pay for members of the Armed Forces is not considered earned income for the purpose of claiming EIC. Examples of non-taxable military pay are combat pay, Basic Housing Allowance (BAH) and Basic Allowance for Subsistence (BAS). See Publication 3 for more information. Combat pay. You can also choose to include your non-taxable combat pay in your earned income to claim EIC. See Non-taxable combat pay in chapter 4.

If you meet all the rules in Chapter 1, use this chapter to see if you have a qualifying child. This chapter discusses Rules 8 through 10. You must meet all three of these rules, in addition to the rules in Chapters 1 and 4, to qualify for EIC with a qualifying child. Follow these rules if you have a qualifying child who meets the requirements to be your qualifying child for EIC purposes, even if the qualifying child does not have a valid SSN issued into or before the due date of your 2024 return (including extensions). When you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, you must attach Schedule EIC to your return if you have at least one qualifying child who meets the requirements to be your qualifying child for EIC purposes even if the qualifying child does not have a valid SSN into or before the due date of your return (including extensions). For more information about how to complete Schedule EIC if your child does not have a valid SSN, see Schedule EIC. If you meet all the rules in Chapter 1 and this chapter, read Chapter 4 to find out what to do next.

Schools may be elementary, secondary, or post-secondary, college, university, or technical, commercial, or mechanical. However, on-the-job training classes, distance learning schools, and schools that only offer online courses are not considered schools for the purpose of the EIC requirement.

Your child is totally and permanently disabled if both of the following apply. 1. Your child is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity because of a physical or mental impairment. 2. A physician determines that the impairment has lasted or is expected to last at least one year or is expected to result in death.

Substantial gainful activity means engaging in activities that are significant in terms of both the amount of time spent and the level of effort involved while working for compensation or profit, or in work that is normally performed for compensation or profit. Full-time (or part-time work performed at the convenience of the employer) in competitive circumstances at the minimum wage level indicates that the child is engaged in substantial gainful activity. Substantial gainful activity is not work to care for oneself or one's home. It is not work that is not compensated for by a hobby, therapy or institutional training, attending school, clubs, social programs, and similar activities. However, engaging in such work may indicate that the child is capable of engaging in substantial gainful activity. The fact that the child does not work for a period of time does not by itself indicate that the child is not capable of engaging in substantial gainful activity. For examples of substantial gainful activity, see the instructions for Schedule R (Form 1040).

Your child must live with you in the U.S. for more than six months in 2024. You can't claim EIC for a child who hasn't lived with you for more than six months, even if you've paid most of the child's living expenses. IRS may ask you to provide documents showing you lived with a qualifying child. Documents you may want to keep for this purpose include school records and child-care records and other records showing your child's address. The sections below explain the residency test.

Your home can be any place where you regularly live. You don't need a traditional home. For example, if your child has lived with you for more than six months at one or more homeless shelters, your child will meet the residency requirement.
Members of the military stationed outside the U.S. during an extended period of active duty are considered to be living in the U.S. during that period of service for the purposes of the EIC.

The time you or your child is temporarily absent due to a special circumstance is the time the child lives with you. Examples of special circumstances include illness, school, business, vacation, military service, and incarceration of a juvenile.

If you adopt a child in 2024, and the child is legally adopted by you in 2024, or the child is a qualifying temporary ward who lives with you in 2024, the child is considered to have lived with you for more than half of 2024 if your principal residence is the child's principal residence for more than half of the time the child is adopted or lives with you in 2024.
An exception to the standard joint filing rule applies if your child and spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated tax.

If you have more than one child who is eligible and only one child has a valid SSN, you can only claim that child for the higher EIC amount. To learn more about SSNs, see Rule 2). If “Not Valid for Employment (Không hợp lệ cho việc làm)” is printed on your child’s Social Security card and your child’s immigration status has changed so that your child is now a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request a Social Security card without the notation.. If you have a child who meets the requirements to be a child eligible for the purpose of claiming EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN, you may be eligible to claim an EIC for yourself.

If you and another person have the same eligible child but the other person cannot claim EIC because they are not eligible or their AGI is too high, you can treat the child as an eligible child. See Examples 6 and 7. But you cannot treat the child as an eligible child to claim EIC if the other person uses the child to claim any of the 5 other tax benefits listed earlier in this chapter.

To find out more, see Publication 501. If a child is considered a child of a non-custodial parent under the special rules for divorced or separated parents (or parents who do not live together), only the non-custodial parent may claim the child as a qualifying child for the child tax credit or other child-related tax credit. However, only the custodial parent, if eligible, or other eligible taxpayer may claim the child as a qualifying child for the EITC. For details and examples, see Applying the special rules for divorced or separated parents (or parents who do not live together) in Publication 501.

You are not a qualifying child of another taxpayer (and thus may not be eligible to claim EIC) if the person with whom you have met the relationship, age, residency, and joint filing requirements is not required to file a tax return and: Does not file a tax return, or Files a return only to claim a refund of income tax withheld or estimated tax paid.

You are married and file a joint return with your deceased spouse who died in August 2024. You are 67 years old. Your spouse will reach 65 years old in November 2024. Since your spouse is under 65 years old at the time of death, you meet the age test.

If you are not filing a joint return, you meet this rule if you do not check the box below your name that says “Someone else may claim you as a dependent”. If you are filing a joint return, you meet this rule if you do not check either of the two boxes that say “Someone else may claim you as a dependent” or “Someone else may claim your spouse as a dependent”. If you are not sure whether someone else can claim you as a dependent, see Publication 501 and read the rules for claiming a dependent. If someone else can claim you as a dependent on their return, but they do not claim you, you still cannot claim the credit unless the person who can claim you on their return is not required to file a return for their income and does not file a return or only files a return to claim a refund of income tax withheld or estimated tax paid.

Generally, you cannot be claimed as a dependent by someone else if you are married and file a joint return. However, someone else can claim you as a dependent if you and your spouse file a joint return solely to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to claim a refund of estimated tax paid. But you and your spouse cannot both be claimed as dependents by someone else if you claim the EIC on your joint return.

Generally, you can't be a qualifying child of a different taxpayer if you're married and file a joint return. However, you can be a qualifying child of a different taxpayer if you and your spouse file a joint return solely to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated tax that you've already paid. But you and your spouse can't both be qualifying children of a different taxpayer if you claim the EIC on your joint return.

You are not a qualifying child of another taxpayer (and thus may not be eligible to claim EIC) if the person with whom you meet the relationship, age, residency, and joint filing standards is not required to file a tax return and: Does not file a tax return, or Files a return only to claim a refund of income tax withheld or estimated tax paid.
Your home (and your spouse's home if you file a joint return) must be in the United States for more than six months. If not, enter “No” in the dot-dot-dot box next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

Your home can be any place where you regularly live. You don't need to have a traditional home. If you have lived in one or more homeless shelters in the United States for more than six months, you meet this requirement.
Quân nhân Hoa Kỳ đóng quân bên ngoài Hoa Kỳ trong thời gian tại ngũ được gia hạn (được định nghĩa trong chương 2) được coi là sống ở Hoa Kỳ trong thời gian nghĩa vụ đó cho các mục đích của EIC.
You must meet one more rule to qualify for EIC. You need to know your income to see if you meet the rule in this chapter. You also need to know that amount to calculate your EIC.

Your earned income must be less than: $59,899 ($66,819 for married filing jointly) if you have three or more eligible children with valid SSNs, $55,768 ($62,688 for married filing jointly) if you have two eligible children with valid SSNs, $49,084 ($56,004 for married filing jointly) if you have one eligible child with a valid SSN, or $18,591 ($25,511 for married filing jointly) if you have no eligible children with valid SSNs.

Income earned means wages, salary, tips, other employee-related taxes, and net income from self-employment. Employee-related payments that are not taxable, such as some dependent care benefits and adoption assistance, are not income earned. However, there is an exception to non-taxable combat pay that you can elect to include as income earned. Income earned will be explained in detail in Rule 7 in Chapter 1.

If you are a self-employed individual, statutory employee, or a member of the clergy or a church employee filing Form 1040, you will calculate earned income by using the table in Step 5 of the instructions for Form 1040, line 27, and completing Part 4 of Schedule EIC of the instructions for Form 1040. Make sure to view the instructions for Clergy or Church Employees, whichever applies, before completing the table in Step 5.

When you complete the form in Step 5 of the instructions for Form 1040, line 27, enter the Medicaid payment you excluded from income on Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8s, unless you choose to include this amount in your income. If you and your spouse both received Medicaid payments during the year, you and your spouse may make different choices about whether to include all of your payments in your income. Enter only the amount of the Medicaid payment you and your spouse, if you file a joint return, do not want to include in your income. To include all of your nontaxable Medicaid payments in your income, enter -0-. For more information about these payments, see Publication 525. Your nontaxable Medicaid payments may have been reported to you on Form W-2, line 12, with Code II (Code II). If you and your spouse both received Medicaid payments during the year, you and your spouse may make different choices about whether to include all of your payments in your income.

IRS will figure your EIC for you if you follow the instructions in line 27 of the Instructions for Form 1040. Please don't ask IRS to figure your EIC unless you're eligible. To be eligible, you must meet Rule 15 in this chapter as well as the rules in Chapter 1 and Chapter 2 or Chapter 3, depending on which rules apply to you. If your credit is reduced or not allowed in any year after 1996, the rules in Chapter 5 may also apply.

You must complete both Part 1 and Part 2 of the EIC Schedule if all of the following apply to you. 1. You are married and file a joint tax return. 2. Both you and your spouse have self-employment income. 3. You or your spouse file a Schedule SE and the other does not.

The statutory employee reports wages and expenses on Form C. They do not file Form SE. If you are a statutory employee, enter the amount from line 1 of Form C in Part 3 when you complete Form 1040 Schedule 1.

If your EIC for any year after 1996 is denied (not allowed) or reduced by the IRS, you may need to file a Form 8862 to request that credit for 2024. The Professional Responsibility Office is generally responsible for matters relating to the conduct of the practitioner and is responsible for discipline, including disciplinary procedures and penalties. The Taxpayer Identification Number Office is responsible for matters relating to the issuance of PTINs, processing of applications and managing the testing and continuing education for designated groups.

The following individuals must comply with the Regulations in IRS Revenue Procedure 230. However, any individual who is authorized to practice in general (a recognized representative) must be designated as the representative of the taxpayer and file a written statement with the IRS stating that they are authorized and qualified to represent a specific taxpayer. Form 2848 may be used for this purpose.

Due to their special relationship with the taxpayer, the following individuals may represent the specified taxpayers before the IRS, provided they present valid identification documents and, except as provided in paragraph (1) below, evidence of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. An individual. An individual may represent himself before the IRS and is not required to file a written statement of qualifications and authority. 2. A member of the family. An individual may represent immediate family members. The immediate family includes spouse, children, parents, and siblings of the individual. 3. An officer. An officer of a corporation (including a parent corporation, subsidiary corporation, or other affiliate), association, or organized group may represent the corporation, association, or organized group. An officer of a unit, governmental agency, or unit of governmental authority, while acting in the course of his official duties, may represent the unit, governmental agency, or unit of governmental authority before the IRS. 4. A partner. A general partner in a partnership may represent the partnership before the IRS. 5. An employee. An employee who is regularly employed on a full-time basis may represent his employer. The employer may be, but is not limited to, an individual, partnership, corporation (including a parent corporation, subsidiary corporation, or other affiliate), association, trust, estate, organized group, governmental unit, agency, or unit of governmental authority. 6. A trustee. A trustee (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, beneficiary, or guardian) stands in the position of the taxpayer and acts as the taxpayer, not as a representative.

Any individual may represent a person or organization outside the United States before IRS employees when the representation occurs outside the United States. See section 10.7(c)(1)(vii) of Rev. Proc. 230.

The Tax Commissioner, or designee, may authorize an individual who is not licensed to practice before the IRS to represent another person on a specific tax matter. The potential representative must request the authorization in writing from the Office of Professional Responsibility. However, the authorization will be granted only in extremely compelling circumstances. If granted, the Commissioner, or designee, will issue a letter setting forth the conditions relating to the representation and (the) specific tax matter(s) for which the authorization is granted. Do not confuse the authorization letter with a letter from an IRS center notifying an individual that he or she has been assigned a Centralized Authorization File (CAF) number. The assignment of a CAF number does not indicate that an individual is recognized or authorized to practice before the IRS. It merely confirms that a centralized file for the authorization has been established for the individual by that number.

A student working at the Low Income Tax Center (LITC) or the Student Tax Center Program (STCP) must be authorized to represent a taxpayer before the IRS as a law, business, or accounting student. The request for authorization must be sent to the Taxpayer Advocate Service. If approved, a special representative letter of a student, detailing any conditions related to the representation, will be issued. The student receiving the letter of authorization generally may represent a taxpayer before any IRS function or office depending on any conditions in the letter of authorization and must be under the direct supervision of an individual authorized to practice before the IRS. If you intend to have a student represent you, review the letter of authorization and ask the student, his or her supervisor, or the Taxpayer Advocate Service if you have any questions about the terms of the authorization.

Generally, individuals will lose their tax preparer status with the IRS in the following ways. Failing to meet the registration extension requirement (such as continuing professional education). Becoming a retired inactive representative. Being suspended or disbarred or determined to be ineligible to practice by the Professional Responsibility Office or by the Tax Court or by the IRS due to violations of the regulations in IRS Revenue Procedure 230 or the standards in IRS Tax Practice 81-38. Losing a state license to practice law or accounting, regardless of the basis for revocation.

Individuals who have registered and who have an AFSP Certificate of Completion but who do not meet the requirements to be eligible for renewal will be notified by IRS. Individuals who have registered must file an application for an extension within 3 years and meet all the requirements for an extension after being placed in an inactive status. Individuals who have registered for non-active retired status will not be eligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to comply with all extension requirements. All individuals practicing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary processes and may be disciplined, suspended, disbarred, or fined for violating any regulation in the IRS's Regulations. This includes engaging in conduct that reflects incompetence or misconduct. For more information, see What Is Incompetent or Misconduct Conduct Under the Tax Practice Rules, in the back of this publication. Suspended or disbarred practitioners are not permitted to represent taxpayers before the IRS during their suspension/disbarment. A practitioner may request the Professional Responsibility Division to restore his or her status before a specific suspension or after 5 years of suspension. See What Is Tax Practice Before the IRS, in the front of this publication. If a practitioner seeks to restore his or her status, the practitioner is not permitted to practice before the IRS until the Professional Responsibility Division approves the restoration. The Professional Responsibility Division may restore a practitioner's status: If the practitioner's future conduct is unlikely to violate the regulations, and If allowing the restoration would not be contrary to the public interest. Depending on other conditions within a reasonable period of time.

The rules governing practice before the IRS are set forth in the United States Code of Federal Regulations at 31 C.F.R. Subpart A, Part 10 and are issued in electronic form as Treasury Department Circular 230 (Circular 230) of the Department of the Treasury. The regulations may be accessed at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals (English). Attorneys, CPAs, registered representatives, registered retirement plan administrators, and registered appraisers are authorized to practice before the IRS (hereinafter referred to as a practitioner) and are required to perform certain acts and are prohibited from performing other acts. In addition, a practitioner is prohibited from performing certain acts that are deemed to be unprofessional. Any practitioner who fails to comply with the practice rules or who performs acts that are deemed to be unprofessional or unworthy of trust is subject to discipline. In addition, non-registered taxpayers must comply with the practice rules and conduct requirements to perform the limited privilege of practicing before the IRS. There are two specific sets of rules that apply, both of which are set forth in Circular 230: 1. Duties and limitations relating to practice (Subpart B of Circular 230), and 2. Acts deemed to be unprofessional or unworthy of trust (Subpart C, Section 10.51 of Circular 230).

Individuals subject to IRS Notice 230 must promptly file the appropriate and lawful information requested by IRS officials or employees, unless the tax practitioner has a reasonable and good faith belief that the information is privileged. The relevant communication concerning tax advice between a federally authorized tax practitioner (see Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 7525) and a taxpayer is generally treated in the same manner as the communication would be privileged between a taxpayer and an attorney if the advice relates to: Non-criminal tax matters before the IRS, or Non-criminal tax litigation, brought to federal court by or against the United States.

A person who complies with Circular 230 knows that his or her client is not complying with the tax law or has any errors or omissions in any returns, documents, declarations, or other necessary forms, has the responsibility to advise the client immediately of the non-compliance, errors or omissions, and the consequences of the non-compliance, errors or omissions.

Assuming that the choice of the responsibility has been made will be applied in cases of reliance on the work product of others if the participation, supervision, training and evaluation of the person is done in a careful manner appropriate, taking into account the nature of the relationship between the 230 and the person.

Individuals who follow IRS Circular 230 are prohibited from knowingly, directly or indirectly, doing the following: accepting assistance from, or assisting, any person who is disqualified from practicing before the IRS if the assistance relates to matters that are considered to be practice before the IRS. Accepting assistance from any former government employee if the regulations of Circular 230 or any federal law are violated.

The Secretary of the Treasury, or his designee, after notice and opportunity to be heard, may reprimand, suspend, or revoke the license of a person engaged in business under the regulations in Subpart B; or who is found to be incompetent or guilty of misconduct, failure to comply with the regulations in Subpart B; or who is found to be guilty of fraud, deceit, or willful and wanton deception or intimidation of clients or prospective clients.
