You may represent yourself or you may authorize a person to represent you before the IRS. If you choose to have someone else represent you, that person must be qualified to do so before the IRS. See Who Can Practice Before the IRS, in the front section.

The power of attorney is a written authorization by you to an individual to receive confidential tax information from the IRS and to act on your behalf in certain respects. If the power of attorney is not limited, the individual generally may do all that you may do, except for entering into an agreement or certifying a check. The authority granted to registered retirement plan representatives, registered statistical agents, and registered tax preparers with a completed annual tax return preparer certification is limited. To learn about the limitations relating to those with a completed annual tax return preparer certification, see Revenue Procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance (English).

Attorneys, certified public accountants, and registered representatives may perform the following actions: 1. Represent you before any IRS office or employee. 2. Sign a proposal or waiver of a tax limitation or tax deficiency, or a notice of non-allowance of a tax credit or refund. 3. Sign an agreement to extend the statutory period of limitations for assessment or collection of taxes. 4. Sign an agreement to terminate.

When the return is signed by the representative, it must be accompanied by a power of attorney (or a copy) authorizing the representative to sign the return. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 2848.

A recognized representative may substitute or appoint another recognized representative to act on your behalf only if you specifically authorize such action on the power of attorney. After the substitution, only the new recognized representative will be recognized as your representative by the IRS. If a power of attorney has been executed, both the original representative and the appointed representative will be recognized by the IRS to act on your behalf.

Your representative cannot enter into agreements to authorize IRS to disclose tax returns or return information to a third party unless you specifically authorize your representative to do so on line 5a of Form 2848.

The power of attorney is usually terminated if you become unable or incompetent. However, the power of attorney may continue in the event you become unable or incompetent if you authorize this on line 5a “Other acts authorized (Other acts authorized)” on Form 2848 and if your long-term IRS-issued power of attorney meets all the requirements to be accepted by IRS. See Power of Attorney Not on Form 2848, in the back.

Submit a power of attorney when you want to authorize an individual to receive your confidential tax information and act on your behalf before the IRS, whether or not the representative engages in any other conduct described in the Power of Attorney Is What. A power of attorney is often required when you want to authorize an individual to act on your behalf in performing at least one of the following actions. 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS. 2. Prepare and send written responses to IRS requests.

Use IRS Form 2848 to designate a recognized representative to act on your behalf before the IRS. The individuals recognized as your representative before the IRS are listed in Part II, Declaration of Representative, of Form 2848. Your representative must complete that part of the form.

You must also attach to the Form 2848 a signed and dated statement from your representative. This statement, called the Representative's Statement, is included in Part II of Form 2848. The statement should include: 1. I am not currently suspended or disbarred from practice before the IRS or from practice in any other capacity by any other agency, 2. I am in compliance with the regulations in Rev. Proc. 230 (31 C.F.R., Subpart A, Part 10), as modified by the regulations governing practice before the IRS, 3. I am authorized to represent the taxpayers identified in the power of attorney, and 4. I am (state the scope of authority that the representative is exercising, as listed in Part II of Form 2848.)

IRS will not accept a non-IRS Form 2848 if it does not include all of the information listed above. You may sign and send a completed IRS Form 2848 or a new non-IRS Form 2848 that contains all of the information. If you cannot sign a substitute form that is acceptable to IRS, your authorized representative may complete (for IRS acceptance) your non-IRS Form 2848 by using the process described below.

According to the following conditions, the attorney-in-fact named on your IRS non-model Form 2848 may sign Form 2848 on your behalf. 1. Your original IRS non-model Form 2848 must have been executed to authorize the handling of federal tax matters (e.g., general power to perform any act). 2. The attorney-in-fact attaches a statement (signed under penalty of perjury) to Form 2848 that states that the original IRS non-model Form 2848 is valid under the law of the jurisdiction where the attorney-in-fact resides.

The IRS has a centralized computer database system called the CAF System. This system contains information on the authority of the representative of the taxpayer. In general, when you send an authorization document to the IRS, that document will be processed to be entered into the CAF System. The entry of your authorization into the CAF System allows IRS employees, who do not have a copy of your authorization, to verify the authority of your representative by accessing CAF. It also allows the IRS to automatically send copies of notices and other correspondence from the IRS to your representative if you designate that your representative will receive such correspondence. You can have your IRS non-form authorization entered into the CAF System by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and filing it with the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, in practice, your attorney-in-fact must sign the Declaration of Representative (see Part II of Form 2848).

IRS will accept a copy of the power of attorney sent by fax. If you choose to file the power of attorney by fax, be sure that the IRS office is equipped to accept this form of filing. Your representative may file Form 2848 electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative may visit IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848 to authorize electronic signature, do not file Form 2848 with IRS. Instead, give it to your representative, who will keep the document.

Submit any updates or changes to the existing power of attorney by mail. Your signature (or the signature of the person(s) you authorize to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by mailing an updated Form 2848 or IRS non-model power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously filed the original, including the service center where the tax return(s) in question was or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or appoint if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or appoint in the original power of attorney. To substitute or appoint, the representative must file the following with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney is filed. 1. A written notice of substitution or appointment signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written statement by the representative, signed by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that permits the substitution or appointment.

A new power of attorney filed in relation to the same matter will cancel the previously filed power of attorney. However, a new power of attorney will not cancel the previously filed power of attorney if it specifically states that it does not cancel the previously filed power of attorney and either of the following documents is attached to the new power of attorney. A copy of the previously filed power of attorney that has not been cancelled, or A signed statement by the taxpayer listing the name and address of each representative authorized under the previously filed power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to name a new representative, you must write “REVOKE” (“REVOKE”) on the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date immediately below this note. Then, you must send a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation note to the IRS, using the Where to File Chart (Chart of Where to File) in the Instructions for Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific issue, send it to the IRS office handling the issue. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney that you want to revoke, you must send to the IRS a statement of revocation indicating that the power of attorney has been revoked, listing the issues and years/periods and listing the name and address of each recognized representative whose authority has been revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you completely revoke the authorization, write “remove all years/periods” (“remove all years/periods”) instead of listing the issues and specific years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw as your representative, they must write “WITHDRAW” (“THU HỒI”) on the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date right below the notation. Then, that person must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the notation of revocation to the IRS in the same way described in Revocation by the Taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that they want to revoke, they must send to the IRS a statement of revocation indicating that the power of attorney has been revoked, listing the issues and year(s)/period(s), and listing the name, TIN and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date the statement. The student power of attorney will be retained in the CAF system for 130 days from the date the file is received. If you authorize a student to represent you after that time, you will need to send a new updated Form 2848.

For tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which eliminated the TEFRA audit and litigation procedures and the rules for selecting large partnership companies and replaced them with a new concentrated partnership audit regime, eliminated the role of the “tax matters partner” and replaced it with the “partnership representative”. According to Treasury Regulation Section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships may elect to apply the new regime to partnership returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015 and before January 1, 2018.

The power of attorney will be recognized after the IRS receives, reviews, and determines that the required information is present. However, until a power of attorney is entered into the CAF system, IRS employees may not be aware of the authority of the person you have named to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, IRS employees may request that you or your representative bring a copy to any meetings with IRS.
How the power of attorney is handled depends on whether the document contains all the necessary information or not.

If Form 2848 is not fully completed, IRS will attempt to obtain the missing information by writing or calling you or your representative. For example, if your signature or date of signature is missing, IRS will contact you. If information relating to your representative is missing and there is sufficient information to contact (such as address and/or telephone number) in the document, IRS will attempt to contact your representative. In both cases, the power of attorney will not be valid until all required information is entered in the document. (The) individuals whose names are listed as (the) representatives will not be recognized as practicing before IRS, on your behalf, until the document is completed and accepted by IRS.

If the power of attorney is valid and complete, IRS will take action to recognize the representative. In most cases, this includes processing the document on the CAF system. Recording data on the CAF system enables IRS to forward copies of the letters to the authorized representatives and easily identify the scope of authority granted.

Authorization papers for specific purposes are not processed on the CAF system (see Preparing Forms — Useful Tips, in the previous section). For example, one-time or specific-purpose authorization papers are not processed on the CAF system. These documents are still kept with the case files. In this case, you should select the box on line 4 of Form 2848. In these situations, the representative should bring a copy of the authorization papers to each meeting with the IRS.

After a valid power of attorney is filed, IRS will recognize your representative. However, if it appears that your representative is delaying or unreasonably hindering the resolution of an IRS issue by not providing the required information after multiple requests, IRS may contact you directly. For example, in most cases where a power of attorney is recognized, IRS will contact your representative to set up appointments and provide your representative with a list of required items. However, if your representative is absent, does not respond to repeated requests and does not provide the required items (other than those items considered privileged), IRS may bypass your representative and contact you directly. If your representative engages in the behavior described above, the issue may be referred to the Professional Responsibility Office for consideration of possible disciplinary action.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are secure and safe. You can make electronic payments online, by phone, and from your mobile device using the IRS2Go app. Electronic payments are faster, easier, and quicker than mailing a check or money order. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your checking or savings account without a fee. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment tool to pay online, by phone, and from your mobile device. Electronic Funds Transfer: Only available when you file your federal tax return using tax software or through a tax professional. Federal Tax Electronic Payment System: Best for businesses. Registration is required. Checks or money orders: Mail your payment to the address on your notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at a participating retail location.
Access IRS.gov/Notices to find more information about responding to an IRS letter or notice.

We can help you resolve problems that you can't resolve with the IRS. And our service is free. If you are eligible for our help, you will be assigned a representative, who will work with you throughout the process and will do everything possible to resolve your problem. TAS can help you if: Your problem is causing you or your family or your business financial hardship, You are facing (or your business is facing) an immediate threat of adverse action, or You have repeatedly tried to contact the IRS but no one responds or the IRS doesn't respond by the promised date.
TAS operates to resolve large-scale issues affecting many taxpayers. If you know about one of these common issues, please report it to us at IRS.gov/SAMS.

The Low-Income Taxpayer Center (LITC) is independent of IRS. LITC represents taxpayers with income below a certain level and need to resolve tax issues with IRS, such as audits, appeals and disputes over tax collection. Additionally, the centers can provide information about rights and responsibilities of taxpayers in various languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are provided free of charge or for a small fee. To find a center near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap (English) or view IRS Publication 4134: List of Low-Income Taxpayer Centers (English).

Access IRS.gov/Account to securely access your federal tax account information. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review your payment history for the past 18 months. Visit IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the identity authentication process required.

How to get the highest tax refund? Combine using direct deposit and IRS e-file. Direct deposit is a safe way to transfer your tax refund directly into your financial account. 8 out of 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their tax refund. IRS issues more than 90% of refunds within 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, IRS cannot issue refunds before February 2018 for tax returns that require valid EITC or ACTC. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the parts related to these credits.

Access IRS.gov/Tools for the following tools. The Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) (IRS.gov/EIC) determines if you qualify for the EIC. The Employer Identification Number (EIN) Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get your employer's tax ID number. The IRS Income Tax Withholding Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you must withhold from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The Tax Credit Assistance for First-Time Homebuyers (English) (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer (English)) tool provides information about your refund and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (English) (IRS.gov/SalesTax (English)) calculates the amount you may claim if you deduct each item on Schedule A (Form 1040), select not to claim state and local income tax, and you did not keep receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

Access IRS.gov/Refunds. Due to legislative changes, IRS cannot issue refunds before February 2018 for returns that claim the valid EIC or ACTC tax credits. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the portion related to these credits. Download the official IRS2Go app to your mobile device to check the status of your refund. Call the automated refund hotline at 1-800-829-1954.
